PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health drew attention to an article in the Melbourne Sun-Herald of 29 April in which there was extensive discussion of a constitutional issue currently before the High Court. The issue concerned freedom of the press and the rights of members in so far as the law of defamation is concerned. The honourable member raised the issue of the rights of the House and its members to comment on matters before the High Court in such circumstances.

PARA.TAB: I have examined the honourable member's remarks. I do not believe that any matter of privilege is involved, but I will take the opportunity to consider the application of the sub judice convention in the varying circumstances which can be of legitimate interest to members. I will make a more detailed statement to the House in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Bennelong—

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair—He is not in the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —He raised as a matter of privilege a report in the Australian Financial Review to the effect that the proposed appointment of a Mr Roger Boland to a position on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission was not proceeded with because of evidence Mr Boland had given to a Senate committee investigating the industrial relations legislation. The honourable member mentioned in particular the Minister for Industrial Relations.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bennelong is correct in stating that statutory provisions exist to ensure the protection of persons who give evidence to parliamentary committees. The honourable member also alluded to the fact that, under the general provisions relating to contempt, each house has the ability to protect witnesses from interference, penalty and so on, on account of their participation in committee inquiries.

I have examined the honourable member's remarks and the article on which his remarks were based. I have to advise the House that if the facts are as alleged, while they may involve a member of this House, they would concern a committee of the Senate. Accordingly, as I cannot see that the allegations go to the powers, privileges or immunities of the House, its committees or its members, I am not willing to allow precedence to a motion on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to address the House on this matter. We, of course, take note of your observations and will be interested to see what observations are made by your counterpart, the President, in the other place. At the same time I would draw your attention to the fact that the minister concerned is a member of this House and, as such, I think it an interesting ruling that you suggest that a matter that involves a member, for all that he is a minister of this chamber, in what we see as a possible transgression is one that therefore should only be for consideration within the other place. However, we take note of your findings and subject to proceedings in the other place we may seek another opportunity to canvass that. My colleague is now here. But we shall see what happens in the other place, Mr Speaker.
—The member for Bennelong, do you wish to speak?
—I am sure that the right honourable member for New England has given a more than adequate response.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Mr Kerr:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not happy to be speaking on this child sex tourism legislation. It is a moment of shame for our nation that we need this kind of legislation. We have all known for years that the child prostitution racket is very widespread in Asia and that it exists in Australia. This legislation is long overdue and I will be pleased to vote for it. My view is a basic, common one: sex is an activity for adults. The coercion of children in this world—coercion by drugs, force, or poverty—is against all the mainstream values that Australians hold as sacred. It is fitting that this parliament should respond to the rising tide of objections from our Asian neighbours and use an Australian law to try to curb the gross behaviour of some Australians in Asia.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I support this legislation, I am not especially confident that it will be effective on a day-to-day basis. We should not be discouraged by this. We need the law as a backstop. Australians should always know that this law exists and that it will be used. Whilst it may not be perfectly effective, an offending Australian will never be sure whether or not it will suddenly be effective towards him. This fear is a good thing and hopefully will give some benefit to abused children in Asia.

Of course, Australians are not the only offenders. Many of these children are literally sold for cash money by their parents to brothel keepers in the cities. I know that cultural differences exist between Australia and other places, and we must be sensitive to these cultural differences. However, there must be a limit to how far an act can be described as culturally different before it becomes anti-human. I suggest that selling one's children into prostitution is anti-human.

That Australians would exploit this tragedy does great damage to our international standing. We are very quick to sit in judgment on the moral failings of others. It is therefore appropriate that we should give legislative backing to our professed high moral standards. In recent years, the United Nations has taken an ever greater involvement in the question of children's rights. This is to be encouraged. I have served on the national board of UNICEF Australia for the past seven years, and I applaud the work that it has done in regard to the protection of children.

I note that the legal basis for this legislation arises out of the external powers provision of the current Australian constitution. The opposition in recent weeks has been attacking these powers in relation to the Tasmania case, yet soon it will vote in support of this bill, thus agreeing to the use of the external powers provision and the UN declarations. Australia would be well served if the opposition could get its act together and decide whether it approves or disapproves of the external powers provision and then act consistently.

The main provisions of this amendment are quite complicated. As gaol terms of 17 to 14 years are very serious, we need to look carefully at the amendment. The offences being legislated against fall into two categories: those involving children under 12 years of age and those involving minors between 12 and 16 years. In Australian law, absolute precision surrounds these ages. We can achieve such precision because we have birth certificates which are kept accurately and which are available as a public documents. This is not the case to the same degree in Asia. In Australia, to provide a birth certificate that shows that a minor turned 16 the day before the charged offence would see the charge collapse. This level of precision does not operate in Asia. Where a sentence of 14 years is pending, it is a very serious problem. Section 50FA of the amendment bill gives a jury the right to estimate the age of a child where the court is satisfied that there is insufficient evidence to establish the matter otherwise. I think that this section should require a jury to hear an opinion from the court appointed doctor and take that opinion into consideration when deciding on this vital issue of the age of the child in question.

The defences that can be brought forward by defendants are basically two: the defendant believed that the child was aged 16 years or older, and the defendant believed that the child consented to the relevant sexual conduct. These defences are reasonable and in line with Australian practice. Indeed it is difficult to see what defences other than these could be allowed. Again I would stress the problem of determining age and consent.

A great deal of the child sex business in Asia, as in Australia, is big business and big money. In those circumstances the question of consent becomes very difficult. A way out of this problem may be to simply turn the whole prosecution on determining the age of the child and declaring a child under 16 legally incapable of consenting to any sexual relations outside a valid marriage with any Australian. I note that this bill does not take this option.

The idea of taking evidence by video link from outside Australia is fraught with peril. What is to stop the substitution of a younger child for the actual child who had sexual relations with the Australian defendant? What is to prevent a blackmail attempt by interested parties outside Australia? Perhaps, as Australian embassies are actually Australian territory, it would be better to convene a Federal Court in an Australian embassy on any occasion when this legislation is the basis for a prosecution.

I notice that the age of 16 years is used as an age of consent for both males and females outside Australia. This is not the case within Australia. I can see a legal challenge to state age of consent laws when this legislation is passed. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) should attempt to obtain a uniform age across Australia for both males and females. What the age is is the question for negotiation. What is essential is that the age be uniform and applicable to all Australians, male and female, in or out of Australia. It would be most unwise to have convictions overturned on appeal due to conflict within laws. These matters should be ironed out before the laws are used to deal with this problem.

This legislation should become the law of Australia. This parliament should say to Australians that our public norms apply to them no matter where they go. We have a duty to maintain our international reputation. I am fully confident that we are doing the right thing in passing this legislation. It may not always be able to be used but its existence will add a note of fear into the degenerate Australians who molest children in Asia. This fear is a good thing. I am pleased to vote for this bill, and in doing so give some hope and encouragement to those in Asia fighting the good fight on behalf of Asian children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill because of the concerns of Western countries over the sexual exploitation and abuse by Western nationals of children overseas and in Asian countries in particular. Similar legislation has already been introduced in several European jurisdictions, including Germany, Sweden and Norway. Our obligations to take action are further highlighted as Australia is a party to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which was ratified by Australia on 17 December 1990 and came into force in Australia on 16 January 1991. Article 34 of the convention provides:

SPEECH.PARA: States Parties undertake to protect the child from all forms of sexual exploitation and sexual abuse. For these purposes, States Parties shall in particular take all appropriate national, bilateral and multilateral measures to prevent:

PARA.TAB: A) The inducement or coercion of a child to engage in any unlawful sexual activity;
B)The exploitative use of children in prostitution or other unlawful sexual practices;
C)The exploitative use of children in pornographic performances and materials.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding that this bill was presented to the state Attorneys-General in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General meeting in February 1994 and has their support. Some states and territories are also considering passing supplementary legislation dealing with child sex tourism.

PARA.TAB: This bill is important to our international reputation. It is also important that I support the views expressed by my learned colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) in calling for this bill to be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Closer scrutiny now will result in better legislation to enforce the law against these ugly Australians who abuse children in other countries. We need to ensure that when this legislation becomes law it will impose a standard of behaviour on Australians visiting other countries in relation to sexual contact involving children.

In considering the legal arguments we also should be prepared to look at the same picture as the international community sees when it examines child prostitution in countries like Thailand. We cannot legitimately argue that the problem of child prostitution in Asia is not ours or that the Australian legislation can have no meaningful impact on the situation and, therefore, is futile and pointless. I accept that the primary cause of child prostitution in Asia stems from the problems in the countries in which it exists. Children in Asia become prostitutes because of their poverty. The impoverished guardians of these children may be tricked, but are more usually forced, into delivering them into prostitution. Alternatively, street children become prostitutes by an act of free will. However, I use the term `free will' advisedly since the options available to street kids are probably limited to destitution or prostitution.

Australians are not solely responsible for the demand which the impoverished of the Philippines and Thailand in particular are driven to supply. In the bars and on the streets where paedophiles go to buy young children, there can be found a mix of nationalities. Child prostitution in Asia exists to satisfy not only Australians but also Americans, Europeans and other Asians. These are factors which limit the impact we can have on the problem in its entirety but should not deter us from action.

Looking at it from a different perspective, perhaps we cannot afford to leave it to other governments to punish those in our community who are creating the demand that is the lifeblood of the child sex industry. The government in Thailand has pledged to end child prostitution but the police seem to have made few inroads. By its very nature prostitution among street kids defies policing, yet even when prostitution is organised through established institutions police have had little permanent impact. It has been suggested that many police are closely bound up with prostitution through bodies and part ownership of establishments that profit from the sex trade.

Perhaps the reluctance of the Thai police to pursue child sex customers and profiteers may also be attributed to the ease with which such offenders once arrested can secure their freedom. While Thai offenders can escape a gaol sentence through the payment of a small fee, foreigners can simply call in their embassy and seek deportation. Amongst the customers and the profiteers there is the belief that the sexual exploitation of Asian children carries immunity from the law. At present this belief does not seem entirely unwarranted.

Both principal and practical realities demand that Australia develop the legislation that will make it a criminal offence for Australians to engage in sexual relations with children overseas or to organise or promote child sex tourism. By ratifying the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, we have committed ourselves to the principle of protecting children from exploitation.

Thanks to the bravado of those involved, perhaps one of the worst kept secrets in this country is that many Australians travel to Asian countries for the primary purpose of buying sex. Although there are approximately 300,000 Australians visiting Asia each year, it is estimated that only about 200 of these are undertaking sex tours. The media coverage of Australia's paedophiles in Asia has been extensive and damaging, blasting any comfortable perception we may have had of loud but generous Aussies in Asia for a bit of harmless fun. The participation of Australians in the Asian child prostitution industry is anything but harmless; it is destructive, and even when it leaves no physical scars it is no more than an act of violence.
Paul Robinson, writing for the Sunday Age, enlightened readers about prostitution in Bangkok. I quote from his article:

SPEECH.PARA: A non-descript Australian who calls himself Andrew sits on a stool gazing rapturously at rows of young, naked Thai girls dancing at the infamous Hollywood bar in Bangkok.
Andrew, in his late thirties, says he is a Sydneysider . . . "the North Shore".
He is on a sex tour of Thailand.
Andrew said he had been in Bangkok for about a week and had already slept with three young girls.
Andrew liked them young, very young.
. . . leering at a young Thai girl loitering near the entrance of the bar, Andrew drained his Singhai beer, paid the bill and sidled up to the girl.
Soon after he was seen leaving the notorious Nana Plaza girlie bar complex with her.
She looked no older than 15.
The two walked hand in hand across Sukhumvit road, heading for the anonymous Grace Hotel.
Outside the Hollywood bar Ning, an attractive 17 year old, had just completed her third contract for the night.
The rings on all her fingers were jammed with 100 baht ($5) notes.
Her eyes were filled with tears and her face was grey with shame.
Her last client was a 45 year old man from Wodonga, on a business trip to Bangkok.

There are other stories of elderly and middle-aged Australian men procuring boys as young as 13. It is claimed by Mr Robinson that the Victoria Police and Australian Federal Police have closely monitored the activities of travel agencies and more than 15 known paedophiles after the detection of several organised sex tours to Asia. The Victoria Police have successfully infiltrated one travel agency owned by two men whose home is in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. The targeting of travel agencies follows revelations by Philippines authorities that they have banned at least 10 Australians for allegedly molesting Filipino boys.

PARA.TAB: Mr Robinson further claims that an unpublished Victoria Police report on child prostitution in Asia completed about two years ago, which was a joint police-customs operation, has already uncovered a number of prominent Australian male offenders involved in an international boys association. They were travelling to both Thailand and the Philippines for sexual liaisons with boys of the same age who would normally be committed to their care in their organisation.

The demand for prostitutes grows daily as sex tourists to Asia increasingly want sex with children rather than adults, whom they may previously have targeted. This shift of preference is widely attributed to the misguided perception amongst sex consumers that the young are AIDS free, which is surely a rather twisted implementation of the safe sex principle.

The exact number of child prostitutes in Asia is not accurately known, but it is conservatively estimated to be about 200,000. Some argue that it could be 800,000. The prevalence of AIDS amongst young child prostitutes in Asia is extremely high. One organisation which rehabilitates child prostitutes has found that 40 per cent of the children it rescues are HIV positive. Other authorities put this figure at 50 per cent. On the one hand, it is tragic that the lives of these children will be cut short by AIDS. On the other, our population is put at greater risk when Australian paedophiles, sometimes family men who are nearly always sexually active when in Australia, engage in sex with AIDS infected children overseas.

In Bangkok, the public health ministry, which has instituted an extensive testing program, estimates that between 200,000 and 400,000 Thais are infected with the AIDS virus. Australian Professor John Dwyer calls Thailand and Burma, the nexus of sex and drug trafficking, the epicentre of the epidemic on the continent. Thailand's projected population growth has already been affected by the epidemic. The Thai Red Cross estimates that, by the year 2000, one-third of all deaths in the country may be caused by AIDS. Meanwhile, the Bangkok Post assures visitors, who get free copies of the daily delivered to their hotel rooms, that there is no AIDS or HIV amongst the bar girls in the red light districts.

In one of the most explicit official acknowledgments of the connection between the AIDS crisis and international economic relations, Dr Michael Merson, the director of the global program on AIDS of the World Health Organisation, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it's extremely important that developed nations understand that the focus of this epidemic is going to end up being in Asia and the Pacific. We are all dependent for survival in having this region of the world becoming prosperous.

There has been a conspiracy of silence in this country and an unwillingness to condemn the exploitation of Asian children in the same way that we condemn the sexual abuse of Australian children. Quite rightly, we are outraged by any adult who seeks his or her pleasure in the sexual exploitation of Australian children.

PARA.TAB: We grieve for the young people when trust in the adults they rely on for protection is betrayed. We use our criminal system to punish those responsible. We should have no lesser response to the betrayal of Asian children. Asian children are no less worthy of protection than Australian children.

In terms of self-interest, it is also imperative that such legislation be created. Our material wellbeing is increasingly a function of our relationship with Asia. We prosper to the extent that Asia turns to us for resources, products and services, yet the trade relationship is as subtle and complex as any other relationship. Certainly one buys from the most competitive supplier, but sentiments such as respect and trust also weave themselves into the trade calculation. Australian paedophiles in Asia earn this country contempt. Our economic interdependence with Asia means that this is a luxury we cannot afford.

I have no doubt that enforcing this law, which will evolve from this debate, will not be easy. There will no doubt be some financial costs. Cooperation between state and federal police and governments of other countries will be essential. But the benefits will be significant.

I commend the government for taking this initiative and the minister for agreeing with the request of my colleague the honourable member for Tangney that this bill be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indeed pleased to see the opposition support the passage of the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 through the House of Representatives and, I hope, through the Senate. In saying that, I draw the attention of the opposition to comments by Senator Kemp last night on Lateline where, on behalf of the opposition, he attacked the government for its use of the external power and the way that Australia, at a Commonwealth level, increasingly uses its involvement through United Nations treaties and conventions to exercise legislative power. It is strange to be today listening to members of the opposition support the use of the external power after having listened to Senator Kemp last night attack the government for the very legislation that is now passing through this House with great support.

PARA.TAB: This legislation involves the exercise, constitutionally, of the external power. The legislative base upon which the Commonwealth puts the legislation to the House is the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which was ratified in Australia on 17 December 1990.

Over a large number of years, Australia has entered into a wide variety of international treaties and conventions, including the international labour convention, which was very largely the genesis of the industrial relations legislation brought down in the House that the opposition opposed. So I really think that in many ways the opposition has to get its act together and understand that the Commonwealth today, through the external power in the Australian constitution, now has a much enlarged capacity to pass legislation for the benefit of this country as a whole.

The bill before the House raises interesting issues of morality and culture in the very large worldwide industry of prostitution, be it male or female prostitution or adult or child prostitution. It raises questions as to why, for example, when the industry thrives everywhere in the world, countries are still refusing to regulate it. It is a nonsense to suggest that we are going to control the sex industry anywhere in the world by this legislation, by pretending that the industry does not exist or that it can be, in health terms, controlled by keeping it an illegal activity. Prostitution in Thailand is illegal; prostitution with children in Thailand is illegal; and prostitution in Australia is still largely illegal.

It raises the very question: is it not time that we recognise, whether we like it or not, that prostitutes have existed in the past, do exist now and will exist in the future? I support fully the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), that health is surely now one of the major concerns about this industry. If we are going to have an effect on that industry, it can only be achieved by recognising this point and imposing some regulatory control over the industry so that those engaged in it, be they adults or children, get health coverage and are taught to use hygienic methods that reduce the health problems associated with their activities. I for one call on all Asian governments, not just the Thailand government, and Australian states to recognise that very simple fact.

Prostitution is the source of great criminality. It is the source of large sums of illegal moneys which pad the activities of international organised criminality. We can control organised criminality only by taking away the source of funds. We know that in the area of drugs. We know also that in the Asian countries, certainly, prostitution and the international drug market are very much interrelated.

It is no secret that many drug couriers are Asian prostitutes who carry the drugs into this country in various orifices of their bodies; for example, packed into condoms. We all know that various numbers of condoms can be inserted into various parts of the body, be they swallowed or anal or vaginal. It is a large source of the importation of illegal drugs into this country.

We know that a large number of Australian males who will buy a kilo of No. 4 heroin in Thailand at the cost of $A12,500 will engage the services of prostitutes by paying their fare to import the drug into this country. That one kilo of No. 4 heroin is worth approximately $250,000 once it has landed in Sydney. So it is more than just prostitution that we should be concerned with in this debate; it is the activities of internationally involved organised criminality.

I for one would urge all countries, ourself included, to look seriously at the prostitution industries they have and to recognise once and for all that to make such activities illegal is a nonsense and a joke. It is time we gained the degree of maturity required to understand that it will continue to exist in various forms and guises. This legislation, unfortunately, will not stop those activities overseas or in Australia.

Very few Australian males who have travelled widely in Asia have not been propositioned. Very few Australians that I know who have travelled to Bangkok, for example, have not visited Soi Cowboy or Patpong. Most Australians, male and female, who have visited Thailand are well aware of the tourist nature of the sex industry in Bangkok. It is one of the big selling points of Bangkok. It is no different elsewhere.

I recall back in 1975, when I first visited Jakarta, one night an Australian expat who was living there took me to an underpass near the cemetery, where I first saw transvestites—incredibly beautiful people, I might add. That was one of my early experiences of the sex industry of Asia. I was quite astonished to realise that these were not women but were, genetically, men. I do not know how people tell the difference.

Prostitution is an enormous industry right throughout Asia. Having visited Bangkok on a number of occasions and sat back in the bars of Soi Cowboy and Patpong, I think it really is offensive and I find it sad. I have two daughters who are young adults. I have sat down and watched these young Thai women, naked, dancing in front of me and offering themselves to me. One night the going price was $A20. I cannot help thinking of my own daughters and imagining them in the same position. Frankly, I find the entire industry offensive—whether it be children or adults, boys or girls. The industry is huge.

Having come to a friendship with many Thai people and stayed with them in their private homes, I understand that prostitution is very much a part of Thai culture. It is wrong for us today in this House to criticise westerners for going to Thailand for sex tours when the largest sex industry in Thailand is internal Thai sexual relationships. There is not one small town anywhere in Thailand that does not have prostitution available for Thai men.

I do not profess to understand the nature of the culture in which this practice operates. I have never quite come to grips with the sexual mores of Thailand. They completely baffle me. It is true that I have been invited to attend army messes to receive massages as a gift from the officers there. It obviously is very much a part of the Thai nature and Thai culture. So we should not be sitting here today pretending that by passing this legislation we are going to have any impact whatsoever on the enormous sex industry which exists right throughout South East Asia.

I do not use Thailand as the only example. I first went to Singapore way back in the early 1970s. We tend to forget that there was a place called Fats and there was Buigis Street. Back in the 1970s, Buigis Street was the heart of the sex industry in Singapore. Mr Lee can come to Australia and preach to this country about all sorts of political mores, but I do not think Mr Lee has managed to solve his own organised crime problems in Singapore or many of the other similar problems that all countries face. I wish sometimes he would worry about his own place rather than worrying about us. I do not think we need lectures from anyone on morality or on political propriety.

I guess that, as a normal, healthy male, having travelled widely through Asia over a number of years, I have been more than aware of the nature of the sex industry. It really is grotesque to think that young boys and young girls, particularly from the northern parts of Thailand and Burma, are purchased as slaves. We really are talking about a white slave trade. They are taken away from the area which they know. Usually they are quite illiterate and uneducated. They are not even used to the ways of larger cities like Chiang Mai, let alone the megalopolis that is now Bangkok. They are taken to a place where they are sold, primarily to westerners, as virgins for quite enormous sums of money.

How grotesque can human beings be to each other? We are talking about slavery in the 20th century. I take the view that anything we can do to influence the trade, particularly in the paedophilia area, is desirable. But I am cautious. I do not think that, until there is a will in the countries concerned to take their own actions to regulate their industries and to impose their own controls upon them, this legislation will reduce the sex industry or the availability of young boys and girls for western tourists in those countries.

The reality is that it is not just Australians who are involved. Wandering through the streets of Patpong at night, every language spoken on this planet can be heard. The Japanese are frequent and very wide users of the sex industries in Asia. The Japanese openly advertise in Japan for sex tours. Whilst I think we are going down the right track, there is still much more to be done. I think the United Nations should be congratulated on moving down the track.

Again I stress the point that it is the countries of source that are going to have to do something about those industries. There are many Thai people who are greatly concerned. But whilst there are such large sums of money available for corruption through the industry, because of its illegality, it is not going to change. We know that in Australia. If we have learnt anything about organised crime, it is the point that I keep stressing: it is the illegal activities that create the profits.

Organised crime operates on demand marketplaces. It can survive only on a demand market. Hence, drugs operate on a demand. The industry does not create the demand. The demand already exists. We are a drug taking nation, whether it be valium or any other prescribed drugs. Our biggest problem is not illegal drugs; it is prescribed drugs. There are more people addicted to serepax, rohypnol and valium than there are to heroin. We need to look at that problem rather than to waste a lot of money trying to control the heroin trade. That also applies to the prostitution area.

As a traditionally trained English common lawyer, I do have some concern about the nature of the extraterritoriality of the legislation. We are here in Australia saying that an act committed in another territory over which we do not have jurisdiction will be a criminal offence for the purposes of Australian law if committed by an Australian resident or an Australian citizen. That is an extension at common law of the jurisdictional rights of Australian courts. It is a very fundamental and very wide extension. It also raises very big questions about the nature of the evidence which will be required to successfully prosecute such a case in Australia.

Quite properly, we are not going to change the evidentiary burden which would be placed upon any prosecution. Hence, in order to be successful in a prosecution, the prosecutor would first need to establish the age of the victim. That would be the first and the fundamental evidentiary burden placed on the prosecution. Are we then going to pay to bring people from Thailand to Australia to give evidence, or are we going to establish other means whereby the evidence can be taken in Thailand, subject to Australian evidentiary burdens of proof, and then accepted in an Australian court?

Questions arise of whether or not the victims would be willing to be part of such a prosecution process and, if they were willing, whether their lives would be put at further risk. Let us make no mistake about this. Organised criminality does not hold human life very dearly. The people who are involved in organised criminal activities and who use child prostitutes in an Asian country are not going to take very lightly attempts to bring them to justice by using the children as witnesses. So in some senses, understanding the way these things operate, I have some concerns that if we are indeed going to try to use young children from other countries as witnesses in an Australian prosecution we may be placing them at some degree of risk. In that sense, I believe this country is going to need to provide adequate financial assistance to enable the children to structure a life away from criminality and to ensure that their lives are protected in the country where they want to live.

All in all, this bill has my support. I think it is indeed a very brave act by this parliament to pass legislation affecting behaviour in a country other than Australia, and I think we should recognise that that is in fact what we are doing. I hope members of the opposition look very seriously at the way the external power is now operating. I make no bones about it: I am a centralist, and the longer I have stayed in this parliament, the more centralist I have become. In fact, the greatest thing this country could ever do is abolish the states and get it over and done with once and for all, because they are nothing but a financial drain on the entire Australian economy, no matter which political party runs them.

If we can ever do that, we will then have a country. We will have a national approach. We will get rid of these stupid embassies on the Strand run by states. When you go to England, no-one knows who runs this country—New South Wales, Victoria or South Australia. It is really a joke. I am very pleased about the way the external power is starting to operate and the way it is giving the Australian parliament greater ability to act as a national parliament affecting Australia as a whole and to pass laws by just ignoring those things we call the states, which are an anachronism from colonial days. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I would like to say that I am in strong support of the intent of the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill and certainly in general support of the wording of the bill. In saying that, I recognise there are many technical difficulties associated with the bill, particularly in gathering evidence in other countries and in prosecuting people for acts that are perpetrated overseas. It is estimated that something like five million tourists worldwide visit Asia each year. Something like 300,000 of those come from Australia and, of that number, something like several hundred to several thousand visit centres like Bangkok and Manila to have sex with children, something that the great mass of people in this country do not find acceptable.

PARA.TAB: These people partake in acts that, if they were perpetrated in Australia, would lead to prosecution and gaol here. I think these acts on child prostitutes overseas are despicable. They are condemned by something in excess of 99 per cent of the people who live in this country and contribute to harming these children overseas, both mentally and physically. I will have something more to say about that later. The Australians who do this damage our reputation overseas, and the term `ugly Australian' which grew out of the 1950s is now taking on a new and more sinister meaning.

There have been reports that Australians have owned up to one-third of the brothels in the red-light district in Manila at one stage or another. Ron O'Grady—a New Zealander who is the director of ECPAT, End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism, which is a non-government agency working in 25 countries—has said that many brothels there have Australian themes. You only have to walk down a street in the Manila district of Ermita to see that every second bar is The Happy Kangaroo, The Jolly Swagman or The Drunken Wombat. Mr O'Grady says that among the worst offenders in these areas are Australian tourists. That is something that this country certainly cannot be proud of.

A number of countries overseas have already introduced legislation or taken measures to ban their citizens from engaging in child prostitution in Asian countries. Amongst these are Germany, France, Norway, Sweden and other Scandinavian countries. Of the five million tourists from countries around the world who visit Asian countries each year, the worst offenders engaging in child prostitution come from Australia, Germany, the United States, Japan and Britain. Some travel agents openly organise sex tours to these countries. Though, unlike the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), I have never been to any of these particular Asian countries myself, I am told that just to sit in a plane going from Australia to, say, Bangkok and witness the lurid behaviour and expectations of the travellers on that plane, especially amongst those in the 50- to 60-year-old age bracket, can make one ashamed to be an Australian citizen.

The reasons why children engage in prostitution are many and complex. They are usually a combination of many things, not the least of which is poverty. Parents often deliberately put their children into these positions or, in some cases, are actually tricked into putting their children in these situations. The parents may be told that the children will be paid big money to act as models or to wash dishes or whatever and find out later that the children end up being child prostitutes. Once trapped in this profession, it is very hard for the children to get out of it until they become too old or clapped out at what we would still consider the tender age of perhaps 20 or 25. Once in this profession, the children are exposed to many detrimental things, not the least of which are things detrimental to their health profile. Something like a quarter to half of the child prostitutes in some countries are HIV positive. As tourists wanting to avoid getting AIDS demand younger and younger children, so the pressure on younger children to become prostitutes escalates.

There is also a physical danger to these children. The anal and vaginal tissues of young children tear much more easily than those of adults, and this makes them more prone to infection. In many cases, paediatricians have to sew them up. There have been many horrific cases. One highlighted recently was a case of a 10-year-old Filipina who died after being vaginally abused by a 33-year-old Austrian or German doctor who, after finishing doing what he wanted to do with her with his own body, put an electrical vibrator into her which broke and caused her to bleed. He left her and she ended up dying.

The doctor was charged, but I believe he was released afterwards on a number of technicalities, not the least of which was a dispute over her age. I am pleased that in this legislation the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is looking to overcome the problem of those sorts of technicalities being used by perpetrators of these crimes in order to get off their charges.

There are also mental dangers to these children. They feel betrayed by the adults who manipulate them, and in some cases it is their parents. They are exploited by the pimps who take virtually all the money earned by the children who engage in these sexual acts. These pimps force more and more customers on the children. They charge these young girls and boys, in some cases, for food and board. Often these charges end up being more than what the children are being paid for the work that they do; therefore, they are in perpetual debt.

It is a combination of poverty and greed on the part of the children and the pimps and the weird sex drives of the tourists who go there that generates this industry. It is estimated that there are at least 100,000 child prostitutes in Thailand under the age of 14 and perhaps 700,000 to one million worldwide. There are probably about one million prostitutes of all ages in Thailand alone. Most of the child prostitutes in Thailand and the Philippines are young girls, although the number of young boys is increasing. I believe that the gender of the child prostitutes in Sri Lanka is predominantly male.

I want to speak briefly about the perpetrators of these crimes. They tend to be—although I stress not always—the worst of society's specimens. They range in age from the relatively young to the quite elderly. A disproportionately high percentage of them are deviants and obnoxious characters who have difficulty fitting in socially in this country.

Asian countries are starting to crack down more on child prostitution, which is a trend I think we would all welcome. When adults who engage in these crimes are caught, there is often a reluctance in these Asian countries to commit money, scarce resources and time to prosecute these people fully. If people are alerted that they may be charged or if people are charged and then let out on bail, they usually end up fleeing the country, and I am sad to say that that is often in compliance with the embassies in those countries. The Asian countries are usually satisfied with that.

Obviously, if this legislation is passed, as it will be, we will have to work more closely with officials in those countries to assist and facilitate them. That will not always be easy to do because bribery and corruption are rife in many areas. The police in those countries are under-funded, as are the legal services. Often the populace is ignorant of what has to be done and is compliant with what happens. This is particularly so in the villages, which is where a lot of these girls come from to work in the bigger cities.

I believe there is scope for us to assist by working with them, advising them, offering training and providing money in some cases. I believe we could spend some of our foreign aid money, of which we spend a lot each year, in a worthwhile manner. We could spend it on educational campaigns in those countries. We could advise them and assist them in printing leaflets which could be distributed in the villages of those countries that supply a lot of the girls. I believe we could also do much more by supplying leaflets advising of the dangers and the penalties to tourists who go out of Australia to those target destinations.
It is really horrific to read what happens. I refer to the New York Times Magazine of 16 January this year. An article reads:

Nit, a peasant girl from the north, was sold for the price of a television. In the Bangkok shelter where we met, she sat politely on the edge of a sofa, fidgeting with her hair. At 13, she still looked small and guileless enough to play with dolls. And she talked only in whispers. Five months ago, an agent paid her father 8,000 baht (about $320). The agent, a soldier, told her she would wash dishes; instead he took her to a house with 15 other girls.

Nit showed no emotion over what happened next. She kept looking at the ceiling. She whispered that she was very frightened when she faced her first client, an American. She was also impressed: he had to pay her boss 8,000 baht because she was a virgin. It did not occur to Nit that this settled her debt.

Since her deflowering, Nit has seen her price drop like bad stocks. Her second and third clients—from Hong Kong—had to pay her boss 4,000 baht. Number five and six paid only 1,500. After that she lost count and went down to the "normal" price of 200 baht—$8 for an hour. Her boss kept all the money. Nit seemed oddly resigned to her plight, perhaps because it was her father's decision. But now, she whispered, she would prefer to go home.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of these girls who do get out of this profession or who are rescued are counselled by charitable organisations. The same article refers to one of the church organisations. It reads:

PARA.TAB: For Sister Michele, the session is astonishing. In the four years she has worked with prostituted children, moments when the children let out their pain are very rare. She says they bury their feelings and hide their experiences even when they visit the doctor, sore with venereal diseases. Some girls so effectively block out the past that they forget their home address or even their parents' names. Sister Michele says she is only just learning how troubled the children are, how much attention they need. "We have to talk things out very, very slowly," she says. "The children feel so worthless, they believe they are dirty, that they are bad."

SPEECH.PARA: If more Australians gave some thought to what they are doing to these children, perhaps they would be less inclined to engage in these despicable activities. Australia supports, and is signatory to, four international instruments that are relevant to this legislation here today: the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which is particularly relevant. Article 34 of the children's convention imposes an obligation on states to protect the children from all forms of sexual exploitation and abuse. It requires that:

State Parties undertake to protect the child from all forms of sexual exploitation and sexual abuse. For these purposes, State Parties shall in particular take all appropriate national, bilateral and multilateral measures to prevent:

PARA.TAB: (a) The inducement or coercion of a child in any unlawful sexual activity;
(b) The exploitative use of children in prostitution or other unlawful sexual practices;
(c) The exploitative use of children in pornographic performances and materials.

SPEECH.PARA: Under article 35, states are to take all appropriate national, bilateral and multilateral measures to prevent the abduction, sale or traffic in children for any purpose or in any form. I think everybody in this chamber would certainly support that, although I note that the previous speaker, the honourable member for McEwen, berated the coalition for having doubts about some of these international treaties that we are becoming signatories to.

PARA.TAB: All we on this side of the chamber are asking is that these international treaties, which impact on laws—particularly state laws—come before this House for consideration before we sign them. I do not think that request is unreasonable in any shape or form. Although we support all of the matters which I have read out, there are many others which we do not support. The very least we can do is bring the treaties before this chamber for consideration before we sign them.

I strongly support this legislation. There will be difficulties, but so be it. Once this legislation is passed, I believe we will stop the majority of Australians from engaging in this type of activity. That in itself makes it very worth while. Perhaps we will be successful enough to stop 90 per cent or more of the Australians who engage in these activities from doing so—even if we can do that by instilling fear in them by making them aware of the penalties that are involved.

I am pleased to say that the penalties contained in this legislation for engaging in sexual acts on children are very severe indeed. The maximum penalty for engaging in sexual intercourse with children under 16 years old is 14 years imprisonment and with children under 12 years old it is 17 years imprisonment. This legislation seems to cover every angle—not just engaging in sexual activity. If a child is induced to commit, submit to or participate in, or be present while a third person commits acts of indecency in the presence of the person but they are not committed by or on him or her, 10 years imprisonment applies in the case of children under 16 years old and 12 years imprisonment in the case of children under 12 years old. So every conceivable type of activity is covered.

Finally, I note that the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), put forward a proposal to refer this legislation to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration so that some loose ends could be tied up and the bill be made as effective as possible. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has agreed to that, and an advisory report will come back from that committee by 30 May 1994. That process will make the bill more effective and as comprehensive as possible. I am delighted to say that the bill has the bipartisan support of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all others who have spoken to the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill, I am pleased to be able to speak on this very important bill. I place on record my congratulations to my parliamentary colleague the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and his department for pressing ahead with this very important piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: People in my electorate might wonder why the Australian parliament should involve itself in drafting new laws to protect children from a neighbouring country from sexual abuse. Why can these countries and why will these countries not ensure that sexual exploitation of their children is stopped? A visit to these countries would show that many of them are trying to curb this awful trade in children, but they are faced with many other daunting political, social and economic problems which tend to dominate their governments' thinking, planning and strategies. These countries are welcoming Australia's involvement in curbing the sexual exploitation of young children in countries to our north.

Debate in Australia continues unabated on our role in the area of international treaties and conventions and the obligations they place on our federal and state governments. Being from Tasmania, I am probably more mindful of this than most other members in this House. Various groups continue to raise questions over the impact of Australia's ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. However, I am positive that, despite the differing philosophical stances, when it comes to our obligation to protect children at both the national and international levels from sexual exploitation and abuse, all parties would be of one mind: this practice must end.

For too long we in Australia have turned a blind eye to the exploitation of children throughout the world and, more importantly, in our neighbouring countries to the near north. Far too many Australians salve their consciences in the yearly gift to overseas aid organisations and then forget to press their elected representatives to address problems such as this. Child exploitation is a problem which many of us find too difficult to discuss. We need to address in a very real sense the lot of children in overseas countries. As I said before, I commend the minister for taking on the issue of child exploitation as I believe that will encourage Australians to discuss the issue rather than neatly tuck it away out of sight and out of mind, creating a further advantage to those sick and twisted people already exploiting children for sexual pleasure.

In Australia we reel in horror when the media highlights the occasional instance of children being abused, when they are sexually molested or murdered. Unless we are fortunate enough to travel overseas to less developed countries we will never experience at first hand just how widespread the problem of child exploitation and abuse really is.

I remember an attempt in the 1980s to discuss the issue of child exploitation in Australia. Unfortunately, the discussion of this important issue was initiated by an organised paedophile group. This group justified the act of sex between adults and children, using the spurious argument that children are capable of making up their own minds about whether or not they want to have sex and that other adults have been impairing these children's rights. What a spurious argument that was—one which was totally rejected by the Australian community. Of course, children do have rights in this country but they are also protected from adults whose experience and cunning may be used to take advantage of the natural naivety of young children.

Australians as a whole will not tolerate the sexual exploitation of children in our country. We therefore have a responsibility to ensure that Australians travelling overseas do not sexually exploit children in neighbouring countries or anywhere else in the world. The attitudes and beliefs which we have developed as Australians must be carried with us when we are the guests of other countries.

I really cringe when I hear about groups of Australian men—as highlighted by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb)—who visit South-East Asian nations and engage in the type of behaviour that tarnishes Australia's reputation. However, it is not easy to change behaviour; it requires a very strong message. The amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 relating to child sex tourism offences are strong and will filter through to the extent that other forms of unacceptable behaviour are changed.

Child sex tourism is an emerging industry which must be stopped right now. Possibly due to our physical isolation as a nation, Australians are naive in regard to the responsibility we have as tourists and the power we have through our financial capacities. The sexual abuse of children in developing countries, particularly by people from wealthier nations, is the most powerful and awful abuse of human rights. This abuse of human rights can also reflect the disparity of wealth within a nation.

Legislators have a responsibility to show clearly what is right and what is wrong. This is an awesome responsibility, and on many issues legislation requires vigorous debate. Human rights and the protection of the rights of children are matters on which all members in this House are unified in their agreement. We can be proud as Australians that we are now addressing the problem of child sexual exploitation quickly and strongly.

As a parent I am really upset when I read that, in some countries, child prostitution is at a level which seems so great that it now appears to be out of control. Statistics show there are a staggering 800,000 underage prostitutes in Thailand, 400,000 in India, 250,000 in Brazil and 60,000 in the Philippines. These are heartbreaking numbers. It is staggering and horrifying to realise that somewhere in the world more than one million children become prostitutes each year. These statistics reflect the very worst of the world's male population and, indeed, provide a very clear message that the male species has a long way to go in changing its attitudes and beliefs to those which would make this a more caring, peaceful and tolerant world.

The implications for children and their communities of the child sex tourism industry and child prostitution are devastating. When a visiting Australian male participates to any extent in the child sex tourism industry, he is supporting and condoning the kidnapping of children from their families, violence and the suffering from many sexually transmitted diseases including, in many cases, AIDS. In Australia the same men who participate in child prostitution in these foreign countries would not tolerate the same terrible implications if it were to relate to their own families. This is hypocrisy at the most horrendous level.

The commandment and golden rule `Do unto others as you would have them do unto you' has been a part of the Australian ethos from time immemorial. Australians are now living in an age where travel to overseas countries has redefined who our neighbours are. It is essential, therefore, that the philosophy behind this commandment is brought into a modern day context when dealing with children in these foreign countries. A mutual respect for other people, whether at home or abroad, underpins the very nature and substance of Australian society.

We, as Australians, are keen to develop relationships with our Asian neighbours—relationships which not only apply at the trade level. It is vitally important that our neighbours know who we are, what we think, what we believe is right and, more importantly, what we believe is wrong. It is those understandings that will surely underpin any trade agreement or relationship based upon business and economic growth. It is alarming to note that some corporations now use sex, just like alcohol, to service clients and socialise with their colleagues. Australia has a proud record in fighting for human rights in other countries. Australia also has an enviable record in addressing health issues, such as AIDS. It may be that, apart from what we are contemplating in this bill, we are able to assist with our expertise in the area of AIDS and sexually transmitted disease research to go some way in redressing the problems that Australian males have, in part, created.

This federal government has the courage and fortitude to address issues that are of critical importance but also difficult for many Australians to discuss. The amendments to the Crimes Act 1914, child sex tourism offences, is such an issue. I thank and commend the minister for his very strong and productive efforts to help Australians come to terms with this problem. I understand that the Minister for Justice has been able to obtain a commitment, through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Australasian Police Ministers Council, to ensure cooperation between federal authorities and state and territory police forces in the investigation of offences under the proposed legislation. I have also been advised that, as a further means of deterrence and control of child sexual exploitation, the standing committee has also agreed to develop a common approach to dealing with the financial activities of paedophile groups within Australia and to focus on the possession, production, sale and distribution of child pornography.

This bill is comprehensive in the way that it not only deters visitors to other countries from sexually exploiting children but also sets in place formal arrangements by which those people who are committing these sick crimes can be brought to justice. I truly commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —One thought which comes to mind when we stand before the House as parliamentarians who have been elected by our people to represent them is that children are our most valuable resource. Last year's national child protection week theme, `Children are people too', is a wonderful adage to keep in mind. As individuals, children are entitled to the same human rights afforded adults.

PARA.TAB: Ironically, though, children need protection and, sadly, it is often adults from whom they need to be protected. I am proud to say that the federal government is protecting them and is doing its utmost in the context of today's legislation, the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994. I am also pleased that this legislation has bipartisan agreement in this House. What better time than our International Year of the Family to introduce such legislation. As a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the federal government must meet its obligations to protect our children. We, as a government, recognise the importance of enhancing the quality of children's lives and, hence, society's future. This legislation aims to provide a real and enforceable deterrent to the sexual abuse of children, outside of Australia, by Australian citizens and residents.

As the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has stated, unfortunately a minority—and I stress `a minority' but still too many—of Australian citizens and residents are now known internationally as major offenders in several Asian countries. They exploit the vulnerability of children in foreign countries where laws against child sexual abuse may not be as strict or as consistently enforced as they are within Australia.

The bill before the House aims to ensure that crimes committed against children outside of Australia and which are not prosecuted in the country in which they are committed are dealt with effectively in Australia. The bill also focuses on the activities of those who promote, organise and profit from child sex tourism. If they operate from Australia or have a relevant link with Australia, they also can be prosecuted for their contribution to the abuse of foreign children.

I support this bill wholeheartedly. I am genuinely disgusted with abuse of children, all children around the world, regardless of the form that abuse takes. I am particularly incensed that some adults use their power to exploit our children. This bill will impose substantial penalties, ranging from 10 to 17 years imprisonment or, correspondingly, high pecuniary penalties if a company is involved. I suppose, personally, I would go a lot further than that. But we must at least have a beginning. Important too is that the defendant's rights to fair and proper hearings are ensured, given the difficulties in using overseas evidence and, of course, child witnesses.

But I reiterate here in this House: protecting children is of paramount importance. The appalling stories of sexual abuse of our children are many and varied. I know that many honourable members, in speaking to this bill, have brought up examples. Of course, various media reports have attributed the gravitation to children for sex to the fact that adults fear the catching of AIDS. Presumably, these exploiters do not feel concerned about transmitting AIDS to our young people or perhaps naively they believe that children are immune from catching or transmitting AIDS.

I know that recently in one country it was estimated that 1,000 young boys and girls are now selling their bodies. In the case of those boys and girls, it is to feed themselves. That is a significant increase in recent years—and the country to which I refer is not an Asian country. According to another recent report about sex tours, men questioned about involvement believe that they are contributing to the country's economy by visiting and exploiting young girls in that particular country. With that kind of attitude, obviously today's legislation is more than timely.

That report, which I read also, stated that sex tours now have become part of accepted and entrenched business practices. It has been mentioned already by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick), that some corporations are now using sex, just like alcohol, to service their clients and to socialise with their colleagues. Young impoverished girls come from vast squatter areas offering sex services to business and other foreign tourists. It is critical and crucial that countries like Australia—I understand that Germany is also introducing similar legislation—persist in stamping out these abhorrent practices of exploiting young children. If we are blase and continue to be complacent, then any action or publicity about the subject will just dissipate.

For instance, in January of 1990 the arrest and subsequent conviction in Bangkok of a well-known American paedophile on charges of molesting teenage boys made local headlines for a whole two weeks. Angry letters appeared in Thai language newspapers expressing shock and disgust about the incident and the condemnation of paedophiles, but after the initial outrage the story just died down and became just another item to be filed away and forgotten by all. Despite media reports that scores of other foreign paedophiles are arrested in Thailand, many people do not realise that Thailand now is the major destination for international paedophile tour groups.

The Bangkok based non-government organisation End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism, ECPAT, claims that organised groups of paedophiles in a number of developed countries are using places such as Thailand as their hunting ground. How disgusting to think it is young children that these people are hunting. According to ECPAT, paedophiles set up regular sex tours in which children, some as young as eight and nine, are used to satisfy customers. ECPAT has also stated that paedophile groups are the base of a highly profitable international market for child pornography produced in various Asian countries.

Getting the public in Thailand, and in the rest of the world for that matter, to believe that paedophile organisations exist is difficult. The executive secretary of ECPAT stated that around the world it seems to be that the idea of an adult having sex with a child is so repulsive that people do not even want to think about it. We cannot continue to be ostriches and put our heads in the sand. It is hard to imagine such things, but whether it is hard to imagine them or not, the fact of the matter is that it is happening. That is why the Australian government is introducing this bill.

Reading various publications and articles on child prostitution truly is a revelation. Reports are common of westerners regularly visiting Asian countries where `they have a warehouse full of young boys and you can do whatever you want with them.' Tourists actually purchase a slave for their own use. For a few hours that slave can be required to do whatever the tourist-master desires and that child ceases to have any rights whatsoever in that relationship. The power imbalances and exploitation are obvious.

There are many other such appalling stories. Another example is of a European tourist who took a young girl to a hotel where he and other men beat her black and blue and then raped her. But there is often very little available information on offenders. An ECPAT social worker said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: Every time someone looks into the issue of child sexploitation, they look at the children instead of the adults.
She went on to say:
There have been television documentaries and newspaper articles about child prostitutes that don't think twice about prying into the background of the children.
She continued:
Now, whenever a journalist wants to interview me on the subject, I ask them why they don't go and study the paedophiles instead.

That is just what legislation of this ilk can do: concentrate more on the perpetrator of crimes rather than on the victims.Aligned with sex exploitation is the highly exploitative practice of child pornography. On a worldwide scale child pornography is already a lucrative business and the demand for it is increasing. Unfortunately, in many Asian countries it is easy to exploit the poor and to buy children because the laws of their countries do not provide adequate protection for them.

PARA.TAB: Sex exploitation of children is really not the only issue of current concern to the Australian government. Physical violence is another aspect that we must continue to monitor. Saving our children from all forms of abuse is imperative. The federal government must continue to embark on ways to prevent child abuse. Most of us in this parliament, I believe, know of, have heard of or have read about child abuse. I am not talking just about overseas countries.

Even in our own country, the media tends to focus on sensational stories of battered and abused children. I think we were all horrified by reports of recent tragedies, such as the death of Daniel Valerio in Victoria. We learned then how people dealing with that case really were privy to information about what was happening to him but failed to act quickly enough. We do not need that in this country.

The underlying causes and reasons for child abuse are less well known and they are now harder to define and quantify. We see sensational media stories which often suggest that solutions are easy. That is not the case. Apart from sexual abuse, maltreatment of children takes many forms ranging from emotional abuse or excessive discipline to severe beatings or, as in the example I just referred to, death.

Child abuse is a multidimensional problem. It is caused by many factors impacting on families across a wide variety of our social structures. Alarmingly, statistical information on the subject of the abuse of children even within this country has stated that there were some 49,721 cases of child abuse and neglect reported to our welfare departments between 1 July 1990 and 30 June 1991. That is only one year. Child abuse or neglect was substantiated in 45 per cent of the 46,769 cases finalised in that financial year. This is here within Australia and does not take into account what is happening overseas. Even within our own country, in 64 per cent of substantiated cases of abuse of children, a parent or guardian was identified as responsible either for the abuse or neglect of that child.

Childhood abuse and neglect has long-term ramifications for our young people. We have seen studies that have stated that it could substantially contribute to the development of mental illness and behavioural and emotional disturbances. Leaving aside the emotional and physical cost to the abused children, we must at all times remember that it is our obligation as legislators to protect those who cannot protect themselves.

I have always believed that mandatory reporting of child abuse, while it is at the moment a state and territory government responsibility, must operate all over Australia. Through the Commonwealth government's National Child Protection Council, comprised of Commonwealth, state, territory, local government and community representatives, the federal government is seeking to implement national uniform standards. That will, I believe, encourage state and territory governments to provide sufficient resources for proper follow-up of cases reported within our country—to take action to improve child protection and to take those protective measures early.

The federal government's strategy, I am pleased to say, will provide a framework within which professionals can work for the prevention of child abuse. Some of those key elements, while it may not be relevant to this particular bill, I think need to be repeated in debates such as this. We hope through that strategy to raise the awareness of the nature and extent of child abuse and encourage adults to relate to children in a positive way. We hope to teach parents, service workers and children about child abuse prevention skills. We need to encourage other programs to take account of children and to develop efforts which contribute to preventing child abuse. We need through that program to provide early intervention support services and the program will also develop local prevention initiatives to make it easier for parents to ask for help and easier for people to offer help.

I applaud our government on this very important program and for the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 before this House today. I commend the Minister for Justice, as other speakers have done. The bill has enormous potential to stem abuse against children. We must continue to have our government introduce a host of comprehensive policies which benefit and serve the needs of all Australians and also assist in preventing effects for children all around the world. At the nub of all we do and all we strive for must be the protection of our children. Accordingly, I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always very encouraging to speak on a bill that has the bipartisan support of the House. Very often we are in a confrontationist position with our colleagues on the other side and very often that is the community's view of the parliament. In many instances, including the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill that we are debating today, a very positive position is taken by all parties in the debate. I hope that the wider community hears about these debates. It was pleasing to see that the debate on genital mutilation got some good press coverage.

PARA.TAB: I have listened with interest to my colleagues' contributions. I am very pleased to support this bill. I applaud the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) for this legislation. We can be immensely proud of this government's law reform agenda, particularly in relation to human rights, to the rights of families, women and children, and to the protection of the innocent. The principal aim of the bill is to provide a real and enforceable deterrent to the sexual abuse of children outside Australia by Australian citizens and residents. This is groundbreaking work and we are taking an international leadership role in this area.

Essentially, this bill is looking to provide a deterrent to two categories of people who feed off the `sick' industry of sexually abusing children from overseas countries: firstly, the perpetrators of these insidious acts and, secondly, those people or organisations who promote, organise and profit from this vile form of tourism—the child sex trade. What we are essentially talking about is one of the most vile forms of colonial exploitation. Colonialism, I believe, should be dead and buried, but in this we can see a new form of colonial exploitation.

Principally, the Philippines and Thailand are the foremost countries in which these sexual acts are carried out on vulnerable children by foreign tourists. As has been said by previous speakers, poverty and ignorance in the victim countries contribute to this shocking trade. Other Asian nations such as China, Sri Lanka and Korea also have developing sex-based tourism industries which effectively exploit children. It is important to state that our foreign aid objectives are very important here. We can assist in solving this problem in the countries of origin by making sure that the standard of living, which will include effective population control strategies, is maintained. We are doing all we can to help our neighbours in this regard.

It has been estimated that over one million children become prostitutes each year, with many of those being in Asia. Many of these children are forced into prostitution after being sold or abandoned by their parents who cannot afford to look after them. Others have been stolen from their villages. Some parents have been deliberately misled by traffickers in the child sex trade and are unaware of the fate that awaits their children in the towns and cities where this trade is carried out. It would be fair to say that parents care for their children. We should have a more effective understanding of our Asian neighbours, their culture, their religions and their social organisation.

Despite the unreliability of figures, most members in this House would be aware that a number of Australians have, for many years, knowingly exploited children of overseas countries by their involvement in child sex tours. This has been referred to by previous speakers. In several Asian nations Australians are major offenders in these practices. These people epitomise the ugly Australian stereotype and are truly the white trash of Asia. This should be seen as a national scandal. It does nothing to improve our standing in the nations that we seek to effectively integrate as our trading partners and friends in our area of the world.

It is no good for people to turn a blind eye and dismiss the activities of a minority of Australians because they are not happening in our backyard. As we move towards greater economic and social ties with our Asian friends, I would argue that these crimes against Asian children are taking place in our backyard. To continue our push towards integration with Asia would be hypocrisy if we are going to let some of our nationals get away with these practices. It would show an ignorance and lack of respect to our friends in the countries to our near north. As a self-respecting nation concerned about its international reputation, we cannot let this situation occur. I commend the Minister for Justice for his leadership in this area.

The Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill is an internationally responsible piece of legislation similar to existing laws already introduced in Germany, Sweden and Norway. In fact, Australia is already earning an international reputation for doing something about the problem. This legislation complements the strategy adopted by the Australian Federal Police of targeting travel agencies catering to paedophiles. It is important to remember that illicit sex tourism is an international responsibility. Francois Lefort, a French priest and doctor who has dedicated his life to fighting child prostitution throughout the world, has said:
