SPEECH.PARA: This problem is not just Bangkok's, Colombo's, Manila's. It is Paris', Brussels', Rome's.

I suggest that this problem is also Canberra's and Australia's, and this bill concurs with those sentiments. The sexual exploitation of children is in direct conflict with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child which Australia ratified in 1990. It states:
. . . parties undertake to protect the child from all forms of sexual exploitation and sexual abuse.

This UN convention alone compels Australia to act on the magnitude of the problem. Australia proudly played a key role in the development of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Australian government is committed to pursuing the aims of that convention. This legislation is part of delivering on that commitment.

PARA.TAB: The bill aims to achieve these ends by creating sexual offences relating to conduct outside Australia by Australians, which will be punishable in Australia. It will be an offence to encourage, facilitate or profit from child sex tourism which may be committed in or out of Australia and will be punishable in Australia provided there is a relevant association with this country.

All these offences will have substantial penalties ranging from 10 to 17 years imprisonment or correspondingly high pecuniary penalties if a company is involved. I think this is very important because until we legislate and provide penalties we are not sending a clear message that such behaviour is not to be tolerated. We condemn this sort of behaviour, as is shown in our legislation.

The bill has the support of all Australian jurisdictions through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. State and territory governments are also committed to providing supplementary legislation should any perceived gaps eventuate. It is a good example of the positive use of the external affairs powers of the constitution, which can forward our national goals and is being used very effectively by this government.

The bill creates prescribed sexual offences committed overseas against children under the age of 16 and aggravated sexual offences where children are under the age of 12 years. The prescribed sexual offences are: engaging in sexual intercourse, maximum penalty 14 years imprisonment or 17 years for the aggravated offence; committing an act of indecency on, or in the presence of, a child in the prohibited age ranges, 10 years imprisonment or 12 years for the aggravated offence; inducing children to have sexual intercourse with others in the person's presence, 14 years imprisonment or 17 years for the aggravated offence; and inducing children to commit, submit to or participate in, or be present while a third person commits acts of indecency on, or in the presence of, the person, 10 years imprisonment or 12 years for the aggravated offence. There are further offences of encouraging or benefiting from child sex tourism, carrying a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment.

The bill presents a number of challenges to Australian legal conventions. These include: difficulties with obtaining overseas evidence; problems of the age of consent, which for the purposes of this bill is set at 16; the age at which the aggravated offence of child sex abuse occurs, which this bill sets at under 12; ensuring that the rights of the defendant are not compromised—the bill is not a witch-hunt or an attempt to impose our will on other countries in the region—and difficult-to-detect offences in some countries due to the nature of law enforcement practices in those countries.

I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) has suggested that this bill be sent to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and I understand that the justice minister is prepared to support that. Overall, the bill highlights the need for cooperation between law enforcement bodies in Australia and overseas to continue the massive challenge of tackling this problem. Any finetuning that the standing committee can do will be welcome because obviously we want to have this bill optimally drafted.

I can appreciate that many people would still be unaware of the need to legislate in Australia to confront problems created by child sex tours. It is still true that Australians would like not to have to face and confront the unpalatable facts of child sex exploitation in our own country. An historical consequence of Australia's past paternalistic society has encouraged some men to indulge their sexuality and their need to abuse their power in relationships not only with children in this country but also with children in other countries who are seen to have less of a personhood due to our own ignorance and racism. We cannot allow these practices to go unchallenged.

Responsible Australians need to do everything possible to reduce the number of Asian children entertaining two to four foreigners per night. Resulting health statistics are that 50 per cent of Thai child prostitutes are assessed as being HIV-positive. Not only is this going to lead to alarming consequences for the health and welfare of those children, but it will spread the HIV virus throughout Asia and into those colonial exploitative countries.

Whilst it would be fanciful to suggest that this legislation will wipe out child prostitution, it is a very important step to take responsibility. As the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) said in her speech before I began my contribution to the debate, we are talking about the abuse of power. As Ron O'Grady mentions in his material on the subject of child sex tourism:

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is the selling of dreams. It gives ordinary middle class people from Western nations the chance to live like royalty. In their own country the tourist income and savings may appear modest and they may have a somewhat boring and servile occupation, but once they enter a poor country they have the instant capacity to live as if they were rulers.

This is nowhere seen more clearly than in child prostitution. Thomas, an American paedophile, is a carpenter. He travels as a tourist to Thailand and the Philippines as often as he can afford to do so. In Bangkok, he says:
They have a warehouse full of young boys and you can do whatever you want with them.

The meaning is clear. The tourist is purchasing a slave for his own use. For a few hours the slave can be required to do whatever the tourist master desires and the child ceases to have any rights in the relationship. This form of modern slavery naturally opens the door to all forms of sadism. I think this is one of the worst forms of exploitation of foreign children in that because of ignorance and racism it allows an absolute abuse of power, which these people know is not tolerated in their own country. I quote further from Ron O'Grady's material:

On January 31 1984 fire broke out in a brothel in Phuket province in the south of Thailand. Firemen sifting through the ashes were shocked to find the bodies of five young girls, burned to death because they were chained to their beds and could not escape. One of the girls had been bought from her parents for $200.

This sort of shocking abuse is happening all over South-East Asia. It will do nothing to forward the economic future of those countries or our reputation if Australian nationals are, as they are—and it is well known—taking part. I quote further from the material:

There are villages in north east Thailand where it is hard to find any children at all. Parents in some cases are selling their children from the earliest years. There was a public outcry in 1990 when a Thai newspaper reported that a pregnant young woman in the north had sold her child into prostitution even before the little girl or boy was born.

This is not an indictment on this particular woman; it is an indictment on the alarming poverty in these countries which leads to such situations. I refer back to the speech of my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) on the involvement of Thai culture in this tourism. O'Grady suggests that widespread prostitution really developed as a consequence of the Vietnam War. O'Grady says that by the end of the Vietnam War in 1975 the sex industry had become firmly established. But the end of the war also raised questions about the future of several million people whose livelihood had been built around the inflow of American war dollars.

PARA.TAB: Two things started to emerge at this time. The first was the growth of a large indigenous sex trade. Thai men who had not been particularly avid customers of brothels in earlier history suddenly began to cultivate a new lifestyle. Tens of thousands of out of work prostitutes became available to Thai men, even in the poorer suburbs. Older and handicapped prostitutes began to sell their bodies for as little as a few cents. Now it has been claimed that 450,000 Thai men visit a prostitute every day. So it would appear that this is a relatively new historical phenomenon in Thailand and the result of a very unfortunate episode in Western history in Asia; one of the side effects of one of the last colonial exploitations in South East Asia, the Vietnam War.

With the recent visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Asia and the opening of the new friendship bridge we have a very important opportunity to gain a significant reputation as a friend to our Asian neighbours. This legislation sends another clear signal into Asia that we respect Asian people, that we regard them as our friends and that we will not tolerate our nationals exploiting Asian people, who are going to be our friends and colleagues in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994. The amendments to the Crimes Act clarify the government's position, which is to ensure that Australian citizens and residents who sexually exploit children overseas will face prosecution under Commonwealth law if apprehended in Australia. It will also be illegal for members of the tourist industry to help those exploiters achieve their sick objectives. It appears that although Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in 1990 to fulfil Australia's domestic obligations, now there is a need to respond to the appalling behaviour of some Australians overseas.

PARA.TAB: Studies have shown that Australian tourists have been identified as significant sexual abusers of children overseas, particularly in Asia. In the Third World there are an estimated 800,000 underage prostitutes in Thailand; 400,000 in India; 250,000 in Brazil; and 60,000 in the Philippines. The newest areas to become involved are Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and China.

While in the Philippines last year the Australian ambassador spoke of the `ugly Australians', as he called them. He told me how they arrived in Manila with the sole purpose of exploiting young women and children of the area. Sometimes it was in the disguise of taking a wife, but when the same person has been back three or four times it is hard to feel anything but disgust and shame for our fellow Australians.

Prostitution is an age-old profession and provided there are strict rules to ensure the safety, health and dignity of the women involved there is little that can be done to prohibit the activity in some countries. It may be the only way uneducated women can find some form of employment to feed their families. However, when it comes to selling children from poor families into slavery and these kids then become objects for sale to tourists, it becomes sick and alarming. It is hard to imagine that we have ordinary Australians from all sorts of backgrounds setting off to buy child sex from agencies in such countries as Thailand, the Philippines and other parts of Asia. So much for our image as a clean, green country, as reliable business partners or as a socially just society. This shows our other side as Western dominators, our suspected superiority over other cultures, our racism that lurks beneath our benign exteriors. We are really kidding ourselves.

I am sad to think that this legislation is needed in Australia, but I know that it is from hearing from our ambassadors and trade people oversees, from reading the exposes in various magazines and newspapers. We are no better than the Japanese, western Europeans or the Americans when it comes to child prostitution. People both in this country and overseas are making a fortune out of it, leaving the youngsters involved with little or no money, sick and dying, and slaves to their own poverty. Once the young are in the business there is little or no way out, except in a coffin.

Similar laws to this one, I understand, are being considered in Germany and may have only a limited effect, but they are important from a moral point of view and say something about us as a country. This law will mean we are taking responsibility for our own citizens' behaviour overseas. It will act as some sort of deterrent and will be the first step towards solving the problem of people targeting children in less developed countries.

But we need to do more. We need to assist these countries to provide better working conditions for their people, better pay and training, better health and education so they can break away from having to sell their children to survive. Ron O'Grady, international coordinator for a Bangkok based campaign to end child prostitution—my colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) quoted him on several occasions in her speech—seems to have a lot of information and seems to be one of the leaders in this area of understanding the situation. He stated in an article:

SPEECH.PARA: Incidents are becoming increasingly prevalent in Asia but only in certain selected countries. Tourists are obviously careful about the places they visit for sexual purposes and their choice has been governed to a large extent by the reputation of the country for tolerance in sexual matters. Poor countries have an obvious attraction for paedophiles from affluent countries.

PARA.TAB: Children and their parents are more desperate for money and are therefore easy targets for procurers. The government has greater priorities than the fate of a few thousand street children and police will often turn a blind eye to events in exchange for a supplement to their meagre wages.

SPEECH.PARA: Hence one of the major problems that I saw in Asia: lowly paid and poorly trained police forces. While there is a market and the police are part of the pay-off, there will be no great change. Everything becomes a commodity, even the human beings. This situation has to change and these amendments to the crimes law are only one way that Australia can take responsibility for its own citizens. I hope Germany goes down the same path and that all other countries who are known to have tourists seeking this sort of gratification also seek to change their laws to give the same recognition as we have.

PARA.TAB: But this is only the tip of the iceberg and we need to deal with the poverty these countries face. We need to get rid of the need for families to sell their children into slavery. The underlying reason why they sell their children is poverty. If we do that, then the rest of the chain can be easily broken and they can move towards a more just society.

I commend the bill and commend my colleague the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) for bringing this bill into the parliament. I understand it will be referred to a committee to be looked at even further. I hope it is not too long before the bill comes back into the House and is passed.
Debate (on motion by Mr Costello) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Kerr)—by leave—agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Justice from moving a motion to refer the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and an advisory report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994 be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and an advisory report; and
(2)the committee present its report to the House by 30 May 1994.

In so moving, let me acknowledge that the suggestion of this course of action was initiated by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), who proposed to me that we might use this quite unusual mechanism to allow the House to undertake a close examination of this bill and to trial the process through the House committees, which processes are at present more customarily conducted in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Previously such a suggestion has been put to me and I indicated that, subject to receiving suitable understandings in relation to the courses of the Senate, I would be content with that course. I have spoken to Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats, who has indicated that he is content not to refer this bill again to a Senate committee should it be subject to examination in the House. He, in any case, proposed that his specific concerns be addressed in debate and discussion in the Senate sitting as the Senate. Being so reassured and with the shadow Attorney indicating that the opposition is content that its concerns be addressed through this process, I am pleased to be able to facilitate this procedure.

I regard this process as somewhat of a trial. It has some novelty, but I think we will test the goodwill and approach of members on both sides of this House. I hope that the very obvious public concern that has been manifested by speakers on all sides of the House in relation to this matter also carries through in the committee and that we are able to deal with the bill expeditiously upon its return.

I certainly look forward to members of this House being able to progress the bill before the end of this session and for the Senate to be able to deal with it in the same session so that it can become law without delay. I commend the speakers who have addressed this subject in the course of the debate. Both in the House and watching the debate on closed circuit television, I have been impressed by the sincerity and obvious concern of members on both sides of the House.

I note the comments that have been made by a number of speakers, including the last speaker, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams), that this issue also raises broader social questions about how Australia can most effectively deal with international poverty and the way in which people in many countries are induced into the sale of their children or their own exploitation in this pernicious trade. These are matters with which this government has very much concerned itself. In that context, I also note the work that Brian Burdekin, the human rights commissioner, is undertaking on behalf of the international community to ensure that the international community has this whole issue quite high on its agenda.

With those few remarks, I commend this process to the House. I look forward to the bill returning on 30 May with suggestions for such improvements as the committee sees fit. I flag now that the government will not resile from its determination to proceed on these matters and to ensure that the interests of innocent children overseas are not abused by paedophiles in the manner that this bill proposes to prevent.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support the motion. As the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) said, this request came initially from the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangey (Mr Williams). The minister has taken it up and moved the motion. We commend him for it. It is an example of cooperation which I hope will lead to the thorough vetting of legislation and eventually, if necessary, the improvement of legislation.

PARA.TAB: As has been made clear throughout the debate, those on this side of the House consider this trade an appalling business. We support the principle of the legislation, which is to halt it and halt the involvement of Australian citizens in it. We also think it is important, however, that since it has wide repercussions in relation to applying law to external territories—an action done in foreign countries—it be thoroughly investigated and that all questions of proof and evidence and the protection of the legal process be looked at by the committee. When it is looked at by the committee, the legislation should be such that it can achieve its aims, which, after all, are to bring to an end the involvement of Australian citizens in appalling practices overseas.
We commend the Minister for Justice for taking the course that he has. We will be supporting the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 3 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends seven acts, five of which are administered within the transport portfolio and two of which are administered within the communications and the arts portfolio. Most of the amendments are of a technical nature and represent a finetuning and clarification of provisions of various acts administered within the portfolio.The amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes, although some of the amendments introduce minor policy initiatives. I will not deal with the minor technical amendments in this speech, but will instead concentrate on each of the more significant amendments in turn.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Air Navigation Act 1920

PARA.TAB: All of Australia's bilateral air services agreements and arrangements embody an obligation that `substantial ownership and effective control' will reside in the nationals of the contracting party. The agreements generally provide authority for a contracting state to withhold, revoke or suspend operating permission if the party which has made the designation cannot demonstrate that its designated airline or airlines meet national ownership and control tests. Australia is bound under the Chicago Convention to supply to other contracting states and/or the International Civil Aviation Organisation information concerning the ownership and control of any particular aircraft registered in Australia and conducting international air services.

It is common practice in other countries to either exclude, or limit the extent of, foreign ownership in airlines. The government's decision to limit equity holdings by foreign airlines in Australia's international airlines to 35 per cent in aggregate and to 25 per cent by a single foreign airline was announced on 22 December 1992. The object of the amendments in this bill is to enable the government to ensure that any Australian carrier seeking designation or already designated on an international route can demonstrate its compliance with bilateral requirements that it is substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act 1991

PARA.TAB: The bill will change the name of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act 1991 to the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 to reflect a change in the name of the company under section 382 of Corporations Law of the ACT. While the application of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act to the company was unaffected by the change of the company's name, alignment of the name of the act with the name of the company will avoid any confusion on the part of the public. The company continues to trade in Australia as `Telecom Australia' and internationally as `Telstra OTC Australia'.

There are a number of consequential changes to the act consequential upon the name change of the company. Schedule 3 of the bill amends a number of other acts not within the transport and communications portfolio consequential upon the change of name.

The Navigation Act is amended to consolidate into one section a number of provisions that allow exemptions to be granted from the requirement to comply with the act. Those provisions were inserted into the Navigation Act at various times, and there is some overlap between the provisions.

Six existing sections in the Navigation Act are being combined by this bill into one section to provide that the minister or the Australian Maritime Safety Authority may exempt a person or a vessel from the operation of specified provisions of the act. The amendment of section 377L will ensure that there is a right of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision not to grant an exemption or to grant an exemption subject to conditions. Clause 4 of the bill will ensure the continued validity of any existing exemptions.

This bill amends two acts which deal with marine pollution issues. In brief, the amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 will provide that any loss, damage, costs or expenses incurred by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in performing its obligations to combat pollution in the marine environment will be able to be recovered at law.

Secondly, the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 will be amended to explicitly state that the act extends to the exclusive economic zone and to provide for the detention of foreign ships which are suspected of or have actually committed a pollution breach in the territorial sea or in Australia's exclusive economic zone.

Detailed safeguards are provided to ensure that any detention is consistent with the requirements of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and that any detained ship will be released with the minimum of delay after investigations and any necessary subsequent action have been completed or appropriate financial security provided.

The bill makes a minor amendment to the Telecommunications Act 1991 to implement the government's decision that the Indian Ocean territories—Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands—are to be treated as part of Australia for the purposes of Commonwealth law. The amendment is consequential upon a 1992 amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act which provided that Australia include Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

This minor amendment to the Telecommunications Act is the only amendment to the act necessary to implement the decision. It requires external territories to which the universal service obligation does not extend to be prescribed. The universal service obligation provides that access to and supply of the standard telephone service and payphones must be provided throughout Australia. Currently the obligation specifically does not apply in the external territories to which the act extends. The amendment will ensure that the universal obligation applies to the Indian Ocean territories.

The measures contained in this bill are expected to have no significant effect on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure. However, the amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 will provide more surety that costs of combating pollution can be recovered. Details of the minor technical amendments in the bill, which I have not referred to in this speech, are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the opposition as shadow minister for transport with special responsibilities for surface transport in Australia—that is, shipping, roads, the waterfront and rail. My colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) will be speaking after me to represent the opposition in the aviation matters that have been outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe).

PARA.TAB: This is an issue that I have had a long and genuine interest in over the five years that I have been looking after this portfolio on behalf of the federal coalition. It brings me a great deal of pleasure to see the parliament of Australia, the government of this country, moving in the direction that we are moving in, and have been for some time now—that is, to try to tidy up a number of important issues relating to our maritime industries. These are issues that relate to the safety of ships at sea and to the protection of our marine environment. All of them are terribly important to Australia, our being a major maritime trading nation.

I think we have the fifth largest maritime task in the world. Of course, we have one of the largest coastlines in the world, and that needs to be protected. In particular, we have some of the most famous parts of the world's coastline around the Great Barrier Reef. All of them are very important tourist income earners for Australia, and they need proper protection. This bill adds to those bills that have preceded it in this House over the last year or two. It further protects the Australian maritime environment, our coastline, and tightens up some areas of ship safety.

For my part, the opposition will not be opposing the bill, as we have not opposed, and indeed have supported, so many of these bills over recent times. As I have said on other occasions, whilst I am responsible for this area of the federal opposition's interests, we will always support sensible, reasonable, rational legislation that improves safety at sea and improves our ability to protect our maritime environment and our coastline.

This is an area of genuine bipartisan support. I think the people of Australia can rest assured that what can be done is being done. We are prepared to accept government initiatives. Likewise, we would like to think that the government would accept sensible, rational and reasonable propositions that are put forward from this side of the House in this area. Over time we have put forward a number of reasonable propositions. I would like to see those picked up by the government in legislation.

I now turn to the aspects of the bill that relate to my portfolio. The first is the Navigation Act 1912. There are some minor amendments tidying up the act. The industry regards these as sensible, and so do we. The second aspect of the bill that is pertinent to me involves the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993. There is a minor amendment enabling the Governor-General to make some regulations. As has often been the case in recent times, it raises the question of why it was omitted from the original act, which was passed through this parliament just last year. We so often see legislation introduced into the House and within a matter of months or a year or so it is brought back for some tidying up. Whilst we cannot get everything right all the time, it does raise the fact that we need to be more careful in the drawing up of these bills to ensure that we do not have to take up the time of the parliament, which is at a considerable cost to the taxpayer of Australia, in overcoming minor amendments like this which reflect shortfalls in the drafting of legislation.

The third aspect involves the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981. This provides for recovery of loss, damages, costs or expenses incurred by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in the combat of pollution. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is the body that looks after all of Australia's maritime regulations. It looks after navigation equipment, navigation aids and all those things that are important to the maritime industry in Australia. It operates through a cost recovery process. Whatever costs it incurs on behalf of the government, the government has to pay for. It runs like a normal business, but it has a very important task. In light of that, this amendment will now enable it to recover any costs or damages incurred by it through its role of combating pollution at sea. This is very important because any pollution caused at sea can run into very large dollars.

As people will remember, probably the most spectacular pollution at sea incident in Australia in recent years was the break-up of the ship Kirki off the Western Australian coastline, when the bow of the ship fell off and oil poured out into the water. The cost of cleaning that up and rescuing the crew and all those other things can be and should be recovered. This legislation ensures that is so. It can run into tens of millions of dollars and in some instances even hundreds of millions of dollars. Probably the most spectacular internationally known oil pollution incident occurred with the Exxon Valdez in Prince William Sound a few years ago. I think the cost involved in tidying that up ran to about a billion dollars overall. So we are not talking about a little bit of pocket money here. It is very substantial. This bill enables AMSA to pick up any costs it has incurred in that area.

The Australian Chamber of Shipping, which primarily represents foreign flag vessels, was concerned that AMSA's right of recovery would be limited to recovery from parties proven responsible for a pollution breach under legislation and that this would obviate the need to draw on funding through the oil pollution levy. It was concerned to know whether this was the case. In fact, it is the case.

Not so long ago, this parliament, supported again by the opposition, passed legislation enabling Australia to contribute to the international compensation fund. Funds are paid into this international fund by all ship operators around the world. If there is a major oil spill or some form of pollution at sea, the cost of cleaning it up can be recovered from that fund. What we are doing here enables us to bypass calling on the international compensation fund and go directly to the person who it is proven is responsible for the cause of that pollution and charge him or her for the cost of it. This means that the cost of cleaning up pollution at sea can be focused right back onto the people responsible rather than being a burden on the international shipping community at large.

The fourth aspect relevant to my responsibilities is the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. This provides for the detention of foreign flag vessels suspected of violations within Australian territorial waters.Some representations from the Australian Chamber of Shipping expressed concerned about some aspects of this. We referred the matter to a Senate committee. Our colleagues in the other place established a committee to look into this particular concern, and the Australian Chamber of Shipping representatives had a chance to outline their case there. It was properly heard and the committee made its judgment. But the chamber felt that the legislation unfairly discriminates against foreign flag vessels by preventing them from sailing whilst Australian flag vessels are free to trade on. The Chamber of Shipping made it clear that it did not seek to protect disreputable shipping operators but, rather, to ensure that the powers in the legislation were not used to detain foreign flag vessels while investigations were carried out to determine the cause of a pollution incident.

It is worth noting that, whilst foreign flag vessels—if they are suspected of causing pollution in Australian waters—could be detained at port whilst tests are carried out to see who is actually responsible for the cause of pollution, Australian flag vessels are not detained. There is a good reason for this: Australian flag vessels technically never leave Australian jurisdiction, whereas a foreign flag vessel within a couple of hours steaming time of a port can leave Australian jurisdiction and never return. Hence, if it is responsible for that pollution, we have no opportunity to recover the costs incurred in cleaning it up or to penalise those people for causing that pollution in the first place. Whilst it does seem on the surface to be unfair to foreign flag vessels, on balance, when one considers that Australian flag vessels never leave Australian jurisdiction whereas foreign flag vessels can, then we would consider this aspect of the legislation to be reasonable.

The Australian National Maritime Association, which is the body that represents Australian flag vessel owners and operators, pointed out that Australian flag vessels are already subject to stringent legislation domestically, and this legislation makes foreign flag vessels similarly liable. In the view of the Australian flag operators, this legislation puts Australian flag ships and foreign flag vessels on an even footing. ANMA argues that no responsible shipper would object to measures to protect waters from ships poorly maintained and staffed, and that is a view that I have confirmed from my own experience. Most Australian shippers are aware of the down sides of bad publicity if some pollution occurs at sea, and they generally act very responsibly. It is not the case with every single shipper, but I think it is fair to say it is the case in general. The Chamber of Shipping agreed with that sentiment. Its concern was that undue delay not be imposed, and it wanted to ensure that any delays to the movement of member ships were avoided and to remove any inequity.

It is worth noting that the legislation being brought into the House today is in line with provisions of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. About 80 countries around the world adhere to this particular law making Australian vessels subject to the same provisions and the same supposed inequities in non-Australian ports. So, on balance, my colleagues in the opposition and I think that this is a fair amendment to the legislation and that it is the only way to maintain jurisdiction, since none applies to a non-port state flag vessel once it has left the jurisdiction of a port state.

The Senate committee shared ACOS's concerns that unnecessary delay should not result. It did not extend that concern to poorly maintained vessels but it felt, as I think most people would feel, that poorly maintained vessels should have the wrath of God brought down upon them whereas others should not. I think the Senate committee probably reflected the general view in the community.

The committee said that AMSA will have to put in place a very efficient system for the collection and analysis of samples. In the case of vessels that have departed port, this could mean intercepting ships to obtain samples. The committee also said that AMSA must streamline the system of securing financial responsibility through P&I clubs and that it should be possible to arrange for samples to be obtained without having vessels return to port. Interestingly enough, the AMSA witnesses at the committee confirmed that return to port would be required only in an extreme case. The committee observed that this should be the case even where a number of ships are being investigated for a breach, even if they are still in port. So delay need not occur and, indeed, in most cases should not occur.

The committee found that there was no basic inequality in the provisions of the legislation. The committee did, however, say it would watch the progress of investigations under the legislation and would respond to any industry representations that are made about unusual or lengthy delays resulting in ships being detained. So it is a matter of saying, `Let's try it and see how it is works and, if unreasonable delays are being incurred by foreign flag vessels, perhaps that will be a chance to look at it again.' But, given the assurance that AMSA has offered us, we are satisfied at this stage to let AMSA prove that it will detain vessels only in extreme circumstances. If that is the case, then we will be very happy with that.

This bill is a piece of legislation which we think, on balance, is worth while and, therefore, we will be supporting it. Ultimately, it will only add further to Australia's excellent reputation as a maritime nation. The Australian flag industry is renowned throughout the world as being a reputable one. We are fast gathering a reputation for being tough on ships of shame, as they are now commonly called; and AMSA is gaining a reputation for being able to pick up a number of these ships that are not up to standard, although from time to time ships do sneak through the net. Indeed, even the Kirki slipped through the net. If memory serves me right—I am sure if I am wrong my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) will point it out—AMSA even inspected the Kirki before it sank and found it to be up to scratch, even though it obviously was not. So, from time to time, things do go wrong but AMSA is doing a reasonable job. I think all of us would like to see more inspections undertaken by AMSA to ensure that as many vessels as possible are inspected to enable us to be satisfied that few ships slip through the net.

As I have said, we have a very high standard here in Australia but it is worth making the point, as I have made on other occasions, that safety and proper operating procedures are only the product of a viable shipping industry. It is absolutely important that, whether we are talking about shipping, aircraft, road transport or whatever, safety depends upon the viability of the industry. One of the craziest things that I have seen go through this parliament in recent times was the decision made by this government in the last budget to increase the excise on fuel. This particularly hit hard for the Australian shipping industry. Bunker oil had the excise on it almost, but not quite, doubled. Some late negotiations reduced the proposed new excise, but there was a huge increase in cost to the Australian shipping industry.

If memory serves me right again, there was an increase of about $287,000 per vessel per year as a result of the fuel excise increase, when on the same day as the budget the shipping industry had just completed its latest round of reforms reducing crew sizes, saving it $217,000 per vessel per year. So here we have Australian shipowners making a genuine attempt to reduce their costs, to make them genuinely internationally competitive, to enable them to have an industry with a future, to enable them to offer people who work within that industry a job in the long term—all being done by the industry in a most satisfactory fashion—and the government in its budget statement taking away all of that advantage the industry had just created for itself, and some, by loading an extra excise on bunker oil, whacking up the cost of running the average ship around Australia to the tune of about $287,000 a year. That is stupid and I think my colleagues on the other side—particularly those who take an interest in this area, like the honourable member for Throsby and the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris)—though they may not agree with me publicly, would agree with me in their own hearts that that is a silly thing to do and the government should be condemned for doing it.

It is worth making the point in these sorts of debates that, if we are to be talking about ship safety, occupational health and safety and proper operating procedures on Australian vessels, then we must take into account the ability of Australian shipowners to operate their businesses viably. Decisions like the one we saw in the last budget hinder that process and only harm Australia's capacity to have a world renowned high standard of safety within its shipping industry. They therefore also reduce our ability to protect the Australian coastline because, if we cannot afford the best safety procedures and the best operating procedures, one of these days one of our ships will run up onto the reef and do a great deal of damage to the reef, our tourism industry and our international reputation.

It is silly to treat the Australian shipping industry as some sort of cargo cult mentality. We have to look at the viability of it; we have to stop increasing taxation on the industry; and, if we do that, we have to ensure that the industry will respond, as it has done in the past, by maintaining very high standards so that we can protect Australia's coastline, protect Australian seamen who operate in our coastal vessels and protect Australia's reputation as a country which is clean and healthy and a great tourist destination with a very reputable shipping industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in this debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) invited me to make a correction, which I will do in the spirit in which I was invited to. It was not so much AMSA that made the inspection of the Kirki; rather it was the German Classification Society that gave the Kirki its clean bill of health.

PARA.TAB: As I have done before in this chamber, I publicly state that I agree with what the honourable member for Hume, who has just resumed his seat, said about the levy on fuel. The government made a most unfortunate decision in the last budget. We are one week away from the next budget, and let us hope that levy will be dropped. But I have no argument with what the honourable member for Hume said about the impact of that levy and the other comments he made. I am not ashamed to publicly state that I am in total disagreement with my own party with respect to that measure it took in last year's budget.

As has been pointed out, this is an omnibus bill which will make a number of largely non-contentious amendments to legislation administered by the transport and communications portfolio. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) has pointed out, the principal amendments will be to provide the minister with the power to require divestiture of foreign airline shareholdings in an Australian international airline where those shareholdings exceed 35 per cent of the total value of the issued share capital or in an individual foreign airline which has shareholdings exceeding 25 per cent; to provide for the recovery of any loss, damage, cost or expenses incurred by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in combating certain pollution discharges or disposals; and to provide for the detention of foreign vessels suspected of causing maritime pollution in an Australian port or Australian territorial sea or exclusive economic zone.

I thought the honourable member for Hume made an important point when he explained how important it was to detain foreign vessels, as opposed to Australian vessels, which are always detained here as they are always in Australian waters. I have no argument with that.

During the debate, I will mainly confine my comments to the amendments dealing with navigation and the amendment dealing with marine pollution legislation. Given that we are an island continent with thousands of miles of coastline and a nation more dependent than most on sea traffic for our imports and exports, we have been remarkably free of marine pollution. I have said before in this chamber that this is more through luck than anything else, especially considering that much of the trade to and from Australia is currently traversing through our prime tourist attraction, the Great Barrier Reef.

It is appropriate that we are debating this issue at the very time that there is a push in some quarters to sell off the Australian National Line. If we as a nation are short-sighted enough to sell off the ANL, we will need this legislation much more than ever before. By selling off the ANL, we will be opening our sea lanes up to the rust buckets of the world. Much has been written in recent years about the threat to our coastline by oil spills. We have seen dramatic film footage of the Kirki incident to reinforce this. It had the potential to not only pollute much of the coast of Western Australia but also wipe out the crayfish industry in that area.

Perhaps an even greater danger to our coastline and our marine environment is posed by the operation of ships carrying noxious liquid substances in bulk. We do not hear very much about this. I suppose we hear a lot about oil spills, as they are very visible. If something happens, there is often dramatic footage, as there was in the case of the Kirki incident. But there are ships in somewhat disgraceful condition which are plying up and down the Australian coast carrying all sorts of liquids which are posing perhaps an even greater danger than that posed by oil pollution.

Despite reports such as Ships of shame, in many cases the condition of shipping is getting worse. This is because we are not building replacement ships and, consequently, the world's shipping fleet is ageing. So what is Australia's response to the economic, social and environmental challenge of the world's ageing fleet? Some are proposing that we opt out; that we sell off our national line. Honourable members can be assured that, as soon as we sell off the ANL to overseas interests, other Australian flags will also opt out. For example, the BHP fleet could be owned by Hong Kong interests, registered in Cyprus and flying the Cyprus flag, with Greek officers and a crew which is a mixture of Burmese and Filipinos. These well-maintained and well-crewed ships would decline.

Not to put too fine a point on it, it would be an act of economic stupidity to sell off the ANL. It would diminish our standing in the international shipping forum. The honourable member for Hume made much of Australia's standing in the international forum, and I agree with him. Australia has a good reputation amongst maritime nations. We are regarded as being rigorous—some say that we are overly rigorous—in inspecting foreign ships coming here.

Our Australian flagships are of a high standard. I believe that our reputation has been enhanced by the recommendations of the Ships of shame report, the majority—not all—of which have been accepted by the government. But what will happen to that reputation if we sell our fleet? It is essential, in my view, that we maintain the ANL as an Australian owned, Australian flagged and Australian crewed shipping line where people are employed under Australian standards and conditions. I make no apology for saying that. I will fight with all my ability to see that that is maintained.

Are we prepared to put the future of our trade in the hands of foreign shipping interests? Make no mistake: if we sell off the ANL, this is what we will be doing. Instead of talking about selling off ANL, we should be talking about investing in more Australian ships. If we were really serious about protecting the Australian maritime environment, there would be no talk of selling off ANL. We are more likely to be able to protect our environment if we are dealing with our own registered flagged and crewed ships.

I note that there are recommendations in the proposed legislation about payment for the maritime damage. I have some worry about who would actually pay for the damage. I know the legislation makes specific recommendations. These recommendations are fine as long as the money is there. When we talk about a major environmental disaster, many millions of dollars are involved. Today, with the international markets as they are, it is often difficult to find out who owns a ship or a cargo. Ships and cargoes are traded on the international exchange like anything else. We often find that someone might own part of a cargo or a ship or have an interest in part of a ship for a journey or part of a journey.

I remember people telling me about a ship which almost went down in Norway. The only words the captain had as the ship was going down were, `Big problem, big problem.' The authorities in Norway were trying to find out who owned the ship, but they could not find out. The only thing they could find was a fax number in Tokyo. This is the sort of thing that we are increasingly facing in international shipping today.

The days when families owned the ships, treated the crew as part of the family and had a certain pride in maintaining standards and crewing have gone. Today ships and cargoes are traded. If someone owns part of a ship for part of a journey and that ship happens to go down and pollutes the Australian coastline during that person's part of the journey, who will pick up the tab? I know who it will be. It will be the Australian taxpayers. Those ships that are registered with a fax number in Tokyo make things very difficult. I know that we live in a technological age, but it is very difficult to get compensation out of a fax number.

During recent years I have personally inspected much of the substandard shipping detained around Australia. Members of the committee that produced the Ships of shame report were made familiar not only with the conditions of ships but with the appalling conditions the crews have to work under: starvation wages—and sometimes no wages at all—lack of food, physical and often sexual abuse. It is a sorry state of affairs. These ships are traversing the sea lanes around Australia. If we talk to the people in ports such as Newcastle or Port Kembla they would be able to repeat these stories. If we talk to the chaplains from the Missions to the Seamen, as I have many times—in fact, I am on the board of the Missions to the Seamen—they would confirm the conditions that many of the crew members, who are often from Third World countries, have to survive under.

If people doubt that the Australian coastline is under threat they have only to recall that late last year the Indian registered ship APJ Anand travelled from Albany in Western Australia to Gladstone in Queensland where on inspection it was found to have 147 defects—and they were only the serious ones. I was asked to go to Gladstone, which I did, and I attempted to inspect the ship but I was refused permission to go on board. I have spoken to the people who have been on board and I most certainly had a look at the ship from the outside. It was in an appalling condition. This legislation is being brought in to make sure that if those ships do go down, or do pollute the Australian coastline, they can be traced to the owner—not that it would be too hard to trace the APJ Anand. This is the sort of shipping that many are trying to open the Australian coastline to.

There is also another issue in regard to shipping that, although not specifically covered in this legislation, is an issue that I do not think we have given nearly enough attention to: the disposal of the ballast water that many of these ships bring to Australia. There has already been danger. There has been great damage done to the oysters in Twofold Bay in New South Wales where the ships come in from Japan to pick up our woodchip and take it back. In Twofold Bay they dispose their ballast water, which was picked up from Tokyo harbour or from wherever they picked it up, carrying all sorts of organisms which get into the oysters. People have told me about the conditions of the oysters now in Twofold Bay. It is yet another example of why we should not be exporting our woodchip. I do not think that as a nation, as a parliament, or even as a government, we have given enough attention as to how ballast water is disposed of and the dangers that it is posing to the Australian coastline and to the marine environment.

We have been very fortunate in Australia that we have not had a major maritime disaster. We have had no Exxon Valdez here nor have we had a Briar type experience, but we have had a few near misses—the most notable being the Kirki. Every time we debate this subject we bring it up. The danger with the Kirki was that it would have polluted a lot of the Western Australian coastline, and indeed wiped out the crayfishing industry in that area north of Perth. We have been lucky, but I wonder how much longer we can continue to rely on our good luck.

We must keep our shipping lanes safe and indeed we must keep our shipping line. If we are foolish enough to sell off the ANL we will be opening the Australian coastline to the rust buckets of the world, and the number of these rust buckets will increase despite the Ships of shame report and all other similar reports. The number will increase for the sheer economic reason that replacement ships are not being built anywhere in the world. Anyone who knows anything about shipping will say that within eight to 10 years there is going to be a major shortage of shipping throughout the world and there is going to be a major shortage of seafarers—and we are talking about selling off our own national line and the little bit of cargo that we carry. It is economic stupidity and must be resisted at all costs.

As other speakers have said, there is nothing terribly contentious in this legislation. It has given me a chance to present some of my other hobbyhorses, though. I have pleasure in commending the legislation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are seven acts within this Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill that are subject to our scrutiny today and it is my intention to concentrate on one, the Air Navigation Act 1920, as it falls within the responsibility of my shadow portfolio. While we have already addressed the particular topic that is covered in this amendment in the Qantas Sale Act 1992, the opposition welcomes the additional amendment to make sure that Australia can enter into the world of international aviation competition with confidence that we will be able to maintain our services.

PARA.TAB: It was on 12 February 1992 that we decided that we should introduce a scheme of multi-designation on Australia's scheduled airline services. There are bilateral arrangements which govern Australia's rights to designate Australian carriers for scheduled services. Each bilateral arrangement, to which Australia is a party, in fact includes a clause under which substantial ownership and effective control must be vested in the nationals of the country designating the airline or airlines. Under that particular clause the country to which a designated Australian carrier operates has the right to withhold, revoke or even suspend operating permission if Australia cannot demonstrate to the other country's satisfaction that its designated airlines meet national ownership and control tests. The object of these amendments is to enable the government to ensure that any Australian carrier seeking designation, or already designated on an international route, can demonstrate its compliance with bilateral requirements that it is substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals.

This amendment in fact gives the minister the power to require information as to the shareholding of Australia's international airlines and the power to require a vesture of foreign airline shareholding in an Australian international airline where equity held by foreign airlines and aggregate exceeds 35 per cent, or where equity by a single foreign airline exceeds 25 per cent.

It is probably timely that this particular piece of legislation be passed by the House. I say that for a couple of reasons. Firstly, we have already seen the sale of 25 per cent of Qantas Airways to British Airways. We are looking forward to the ultimate, although highly delayed, float of Qantas. The privatisation of the remainder of Qantas Airways does give foreign investors the opportunity to come in. That is where the 35 per cent shut off point comes in.

We were also interested to read in the last few days of a possible arrangement between Ansett Airlines and the German carrier Lufthansa. It has been suggested in some press reports that Lufthansa might be taking some equity in Ansett Australia. If that happens, we will also have that double problem: we will have some foreign ownership of both major carriers, Ansett and Qantas. There is also the possibility of a third international airline in Australia soon—if and when the funds can be arranged for that carrier to get off the ground and meet its obligations under the arrangements that have been made by the International Air Services Commission—to service China.

We have also seen evidence that some countries hold up the provisions of these arrangements very strictly indeed. The case comes to mind of the situation that developed with the privatisation of British Airways. Some major negotiation went on between the British government and the United States government on the rights of British Airways to operate into the United States; at one stage the foreign shareholding had slightly exceeded the 35 per cent mark. Also, there were major negotiations regarding the British Airways acquisition of a percentage of the US domestic and international carrier US Air. While I suppose one could suggest that they might have a little more to do with the bartering of air rights between the United States and Great Britain, British Airways could have been denied access to the United States if these procedures had not been under control.

If we look around the world at the arrangements that are being made at the moment with the grouping together of airlines, at the commercial arrangements that are being made between numbers of foreign carriers, obviously there is room for some countries to object to the access of particular carriers into their country if these provisions are not met. Therefore, the opposition welcomes these amendments to the Air Navigation Act so that we can make sure any Australian airline operating overseas has the capacity to meet those obligations and thus avoid any situation where an Australian carrier is denied access to a particular country, otherwise we might be subjected to protracted negotiations. The opposition welcomes and supports these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking today to the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, I will concentrate on the amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. This, I am quite certain, has been one of the main topics that speakers have spoken on this morning, and rightly so. I want to concentrate on what is happening in Western Port Bay, which is very relevant to this bill.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, though, I agree with what the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said of the ANL shipping line. To sell off Australia's only shipping carrier would be ludicrous. I think it was the Bruce government which tried to do that back in 1929-30. It got nowhere then, and I do not believe it will get anywhere now. We need our own shipping line. We are an island nation and it is important that we have our own ships, at least to know exactly what is going on in the shipping world with the transportation of our goods. We would be held to ransom if we did not have our own shipping line.

The Shell-Mobil Crib Point terminal handling facility at Western Port Bay is used by many Australian or ANL boats. Back in 1992, I started to oppose the use by Shell and Mobil of the old BP site there. I wrote to the then Minister for the Arts, Sport and Environment, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). A letter back from the then minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Approval of the project rests almost entirely with the Victorian Government, the only Commonwealth role being in the initial approval of the foreign investment for acquisition of the site. In considering that approval, the Treasurer has sought advice from the Commonwealth Environment Protection Authority, and has been made aware of the sensitivities of Western Port Bay with regard to the RAMSAR sites.

Ramsar, of course, is the agreement we have with overseas nations in relation to migratory birds. Briefly, what is happening at Crib Point is that Shell and Mobil are proposing to significantly increase the importation of heavy crude oil for the refineries at Geelong and Altona. They intend to do this in tankers—not their own—of around about 150,000 tonnes. Those tankers will be brought into Crib Point, which is a deepwater port. There they will offload half of the oil and transport the rest of it up Port Phillip Bay to their Altona and Geelong refineries.

PARA.TAB: The tanker traffic in the area will increase quite significantly. I think it is suggested that an extra 60 to 70 tankers per year will use Bass Strait and the confined waters of Western Port Bay. If this proposal goes ahead, it will mean there will be an extra 180 tanker passages between Western Port and Port Phillip Bay. Given the increase in the number of tankers that will be used, the risk of an accident happening must also increase.

The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics Report No. 70, Major marine oil spills: risk and response, 1991, concluded, amongst other things, that `the probability of one or more major oil spills occurring in Australian waters, from tankers, could be as much as 48 per cent in the next five years and 93 per cent in the next 20 years'. We are heading towards a 93 per cent risk of something happening. Just imagine what would happen if one of these tankers went aground at The Nobbies at Phillip Island at the entrance to Western Port Bay. It is not unusual for ships to be wrecked there; over the years many ships have been wrecked on the approaches to Western Port Bay.

Just around the corner from The Nobbies is a major Australian tourist attraction—the penguin parade. That is estimated to bring hundreds of millions of dollars into the Victorian economy—and, with Jeff Kennett there, we need hundreds of millions of dollars; we need every cent we can get. If it were wiped out—it could happen; we have had examples of hundreds of penguins being killed by oil spills just off the Otways—it would ruin this magnificent tourist attraction. It would destroy the economy of many people on Phillip Island and around Western Port Bay. I believe that it would even destroy the economy of Melbourne, because the Japanese tourists who flock to those particular penguin parades of a night would no longer go there. Therefore, the tourist trade would cease in Melbourne and on Phillip Island.

That is why I am so adamant that this expansion by Shell and Mobil should not go ahead. At the present time they have put it on hold because of the pressure that has been put on them by various groups throughout the community in the Western Port area. Those groups have done a tremendous job, pointing out the dangers to this huge conglomerate of two oil companies. They are continuing to point it out and I think they are winning. I hope that Shell and Mobil withdraw from the proposal they are putting forward.

I have asked continually that the minister request that an EIS be carried out in this area. That has not happened because there have been all sorts of problems. But I believe that legal advice has been given which says that the minister can direct the oil companies to carry out an EIS. Their reason for not carrying it out is that they went into an existing facility which started off down there in the early 1950s and was used by BP.

The MARPOL Convention, which deals with marine pollution, I do not believe allows for land based clean-up. MARPOL and the moneys which are connected to it will clean up the sea based pollution—that is what is in the water—but what happens when it washes onto the land? Would that also be covered by this piece of legislation? Looking around the chamber, I can see some nods. I am glad to know that.

I believe there should be a transportation levy placed on Shell and Mobil for shifting this fuel around. If they do go ahead with this proposed development and they shift fuel from Western Port to Port Phillip Bay there has to be a problem. There is a higher risk and therefore an oil levy should be placed on them, based on the amount of oil they transport. That would go into some trust fund, perhaps capped at a certain amount, say, $14 million or $15 million. When the contributions reach that level, then maybe the interest on that amount can be used for the Environment Protection Agency or for some research or something on the two bays. It is important that some fund is set up that can be used for rectifying any problem that occurs.

I know that a fund is being set up at the present time, but if this goes ahead I would like to see a fund particularly for that eventuality. The oil companies can afford it. I am quite certain that another couple of cents on a tonne of oil would not break them, even though they would oppose it.

Oil companies are actually importing oil from overseas and we are exporting oil. We are exporting it because of export dollars and we are importing it and paying more. Why they should do this is beyond comprehension. I realise that different sorts of oil are needed for making tar, bitumen or some sort of heavy road material, for example, which I believe we do not have in Australia, but I cannot work out exactly why we are importing oil that we can produce in Australia. We have plenty of oil here in Australia; we are finding it all the time. It is to do with export dollars and our balance of payments, and so on. I think a lot of it is to do with profits for some of our bigger oil companies.

The other area I would like to talk about, mentioned by the honourable member for Throsby, is the marine ballast. There has been quite a lot of talk about that. Recently in Victoria there have been outbreaks of various red algae in Port Phillip Bay. We are particularly concerned about the starfish that have appeared in Tasmania. The larvae of these starfish were taken there by ballast water. It is believed that if they were to be transferred to Victoria, Victoria's commercial shellfish industry, which is worth approximately $35 million a year, could be destroyed.

It is very easy for water to be transferred in the ballast of a ship. About 6,000 international ships come to Australia every year and 120 million tonnes of ballast water comes into Australian ports each year. That is a huge amount of ballast water—120 million tonnes of water being pumped into our ports all around Australia.

Anything can be in that water. There is this starfish. There is algae from places throughout the world. There is seaweed from places throughout the world. All of that is going into our water. Australia has this barrier of water all around it, but, stupidly, we are introducing water from other countries containing particular types of animals and flora which will destroy our own. A lot more work must be done in this area to stop importation of these pests to our own waters.

I have seen the television items about the starfish in Tasmania. Who knows where they are going to end up? They have started off down the Derwent River and are heading out to sea, so it is not too far to come across Bass Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be in Frankston!

—I do not want them in Frankston; we have to do something to stop them. How much money are we putting in to have surveys done by the CSIRO and to stop that starfish menace? Are we taking concerted action? The most important time in a battle is the first couple of days. These things have been around for a couple of years. If we do not stop them soon, they will be out of control and there will be no way to stop them. I think it is important that a lot of money be put into that.

PARA.TAB: I think the people who should put the money in are the people who actually brought the pests here: the shipping companies, the oil companies and the woodchip companies. They all should be hit with a levy straight away and that money should be put into research to try to rectify the problem. The people of Australia did not bring it in. I did not export any woodchips. I did not export any oil. It was the oil companies. They are getting the profits out of it and therefore they should rectify the problem. I would like that to be looked at fairly closely.

I noticed an advertising supplement to the Australian Magazine of 26 March 1994 relating to oil spills. I read it and thought, `Who is actually paying for this?' It was written in such a way that one would think those who produced it were having a go at the oil companies. But when I looked a bit closer I found that the people who actually paid for this are the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association; AMSA, the body set up by the oil companies to correct any spills; the Australian Marine Oil Spills Centre; Caltex; and the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. All of that goes to putting up this fairly neutral story on how oil spills are not really that bad, how they can be fixed and how we all should feel warm and fuzzy about them.

The supplement contained a list of spills that have occurred over the years. In 1968 the Korean Star spilt 600 tonnes off Western Australia. The Al Qurain spilt 184 tonnes. The Arthur Phillip released a slick off Victoria killing 200 fairy penguins. A slick is what I was talking about before. Can one imagine, say, 20,000 tonnes, which would not be unreasonable from a 150,000 tonne tanker, being spilt into Western Port Bay? I wonder how many fairy penguins would be killed then.

In 1991, the Sanko Harvest, wrecked off Esperance, lost 700 tonnes of oil and 30,000 tonnes of fertiliser. That should be a good mix for the ocean floor. The Kirki lost its bow in rough seas of Western Australia and spilt 17,280 tonnes. The Daishowa Maru, grounded in Twofold Bay lost 780 tonnes in 1992 and the Zera, ruptured by a tug in Spencer Gulf, lost 300 tonnes of oil. They give that as the total of the amount of oil that has been spilt on our coastline.

One that they also point out, which is most important and which the petrol and oil companies do not pay for, is that an estimated 16,000 tonnes of oil and petroleum products, equal to the biggest disaster in our history, are sluiced off our roads, driveways, parking lots and service stations and quietly released by industry or backyard mechanics. So 16,000 tonnes every year is being poured off into our creeks, our bays and then our oceans. Why should the petrol and oil companies not pay for this? Why should there not be a levy on them to fix this up? Why should we as consumers and users of the ocean and bays have to pay for the problems they create?

Esso in Western Port Bay did a nice little exercise recently. An article I have on the subject entitled `"Disaster" clean-up' stated: `Esso workers fight mock spill to test emergency equipment.' The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Esso workers snapped into action last Thursday—
I bet they were not warned about this or anything like that—
when the company staged a mock oil spill disaster to practice using its $10 million clean-up equipment.

PARA.TAB: About 50 workers moved swiftly to drag giant floating booms around an oil tanker . . . at . . . Western Port Bay.

SPEECH.PARA: It was probably in the middle of the day, on a calm sea and they would have all been ready for it. I do not think oil spills happen in the middle of the day. I do not think they happen in calm seas. Western Port Bay has quite a strong tide. I bet this was done at a time when the tide was not running too hard. We are told these sorts of things to try to soften our thinking in relation to what will happen if one of these tankers goes aground in Western Port Bay.

PARA.TAB: AMSA has a fairly large set-up, which is paid for by the oil companies, to try to solve the problems of oil spills. It claims that it can get anywhere in Australia within 24 hours, but it has not yet been tried. I would like to see the government stage a mock disaster somewhere and not tell AMSA about it to see how quickly it can get there. I do not think it will get there too quickly.

The audit office is currently doing an audit report on AMSA. From what I have heard behind the scenes, there is a real concern about the effectiveness of AMSA to do an oil clean up. I am waiting breathlessly to hear what the audit report has to say about AMSA. The Auditor-General seems to be able to comment on anything these days and it will be interesting to hear what he has to say on that.

I would like to touch on the imposition of fines on oil companies in relation to oil spills. In 1993 Shell was prosecuted. At the time the court case was under way, Shell was up for a fine of $125,000. Shell probably has a turnover of $125,000 a second throughout the world—I do not know; it is huge—so that fine would have been nothing. We have to have some decent teeth. If oil spills occur, we have to have harsh penalties in place to make certain that companies remember what they have done and take steps to rectify it.

Companies claim that they are doing these things and that they are spending some money, but I do not believe it is enough. A separate fund should be set up which puts a levy on all these oil companies. This will ensure that when they do breach regulations and there is a spill they pay for it. How much is one penguin worth? No-one can put a price on it. According to this article, it is worth a few hundred thousand dollars. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to support the general thrust of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and to join fellow members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, even if I have to be a little critical of the government on some aspects of its policy. This is an omnibus bill. However, I wish to restrict my comments to the two protection of the sea amendments which were included in the bill.

PARA.TAB: As already mentioned by previous speakers, while these amendments will ensure that foreign flag polluters or so-called ships of shame are held accountable while in Australian waters, I also wish to highlight today the ship safety anomaly which, if rectified, could stop polluters from being allowed to operate along our coastline in the first place. I appreciate what the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) said about the need to have some sort of trust fund. I understood that there was one in place. If we get to the root of the problem, rather than trying to fix up the mess at the end, we might be more effective.

The amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 provide for the recovery of losses, damages, costs or expenses incurred by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in the exercise of its duties to combat pollution of the marine environment caused by a discharge or disposal from a ship. AMSA's right of recovery would be limited to those parties which have been proven responsible for a pollution breach. Quite rightly, ship owners should be responsible for all forms of discharges from their vessels, from ballast waters, which, as the honourable member for Dunkley said, could contain harmful micro-organisms, to garbage and waste disposal and to fuel oil spills—all of which have a damaging impact on sensitive marine environments.

The second set of amendments deals with the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 and provides for the detention of foreign vessels suspected of causing marine pollution within Australian waters. The need for such detention powers over foreign ships can be seen in that the act allows legal action to be taken against Australian ships wherever they are.
