However, Australian jurisdiction over foreign vessels is limited to Australian waters only. AMSA should be given the power to detain foreign vessels that pollute, as Australian ships already face similar measures in foreign ports, including most EEC countries. Often the detention will only see the offending ship post a bond or security before sailing on—a sort of guarantee, if you like, until investigations are complete. I support the thrust of these matters.

It is, I believe, all about responsibility and making sure that the culprits pay. There is too much at risk, particularly in my electorate where there are busy ports operating on the doorstep of the Great Barrier Reef. As an example, let us take the port of Gladstone in Central Queensland, one of the most efficient and modern ports in Australia. Last financial year, 1992-93, it handled a record cargo throughput of 33.1 million tonnes valued at $2.8 billion, including 23.9 million tonnes of exports to 32 countries valued at $2.1 billion and imports from 12 destinations totalling 9.2 million tonnes worth $700 million.

Almost 700 cargo vessels visited Gladstone last year, carting such diverse cargoes as coal, alumina, grain, cement clinker, petroleum products and caustic soda. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would recognise many of them as potentially deleterious to the Great Barrier Reef or coastal environments. These vessels must navigate at least part of the way through the Great Barrier Reef, which is not only a totally unique and pristine environmental marine park but also the backbone of Queensland's tourist industry which generates billions of dollars for both state and national economies.

While the measures debated in the bill today allow us to detain and seek compensation from ships that pollute our waters—action at this stage is important but often simply too late—the damage has been done and the clean-up might not really compensate us for what has been done. Ideally we must stop these polluters or ships of shame before they damage our marine environment. We need to have a culture of vigilance and a mechanism of intelligence.

I would like to highlight a recent `ship of shame' story with which I am familiar and which was referred to by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). It is something which we should be able to avoid easily in the future if the government decides to take some positive action. I have raised this matter in the House before but it bears reiteration, especially in the context of the acts which we are discussing today.

This story involves an Indian registered bulk carrier, the APJ Anand, which set sail from Albany in Western Australia with a load of feed barley for drought stricken farmers in Central Queensland. According to vendors, WA Grain Pool and Grainco, the APJ Anand's credentials as a carrier were satisfactory and the vessel was issued with a single voyage permit to cart grain around the coastline with no safety inspection required. Ironically, the vessel's generators were so underpowered that they required on-wharf supplementation in order to load the grain. Further, it was responsible for a minor oily bilge spill just before leaving Albany, which had to be contained and cleaned up by the local port authority.

Given the fact that no AMSA inspector was based at Albany at the time, the derelict APJ Anand was allowed to sail on. The APJ Anand arrived in Gladstone in late September, but this time it was unable to unload as its lifting gear proved to be defective. AMSA authorities were alerted and a full inspection on 10 October revealed over 120 defects—I understand the honourable member for Throsby now has it at 147—including extensive wastage, corrosion and other structural problems; poor crew conditions, which I saw photos of, and they were filthy; and substandard lifesaving equipment.

The APJ Anand was impounded. Repairs had to be carried out to the lifting gear amounting to some $80,000. The Anand was later released and later allowed to sail off to Singapore for major repairs. The vessel was to have travelled on to Mackay, deeper into the Great Barrier Reef. That should again alert us to the danger of this situation.

Before we dismiss the Anand as just a one-off instance or one of a small number of substandard foreign vessels, there is another example of such a `ship of shame', one from the same shipping company, Pacific Rim Shipping Co. Pty Ltd. It had in its fleet another vessel of doubtful credentials known as Marine Blue. I concede that the Marine Blue is not a totally similar case to a vessel plying the coastal trade. This vessel carried a load of magnetite from Chile to Mackay. Mackay is on the doorstep of one of the great areas of the central Barrier Reef. When it arrived in Mackay it was found to have a rupture in the ship's chain locker which had been flooded through a crack in the hull. The ship's pumps were faulty and it had to undertake lifesaving and firefighting equipment restoration and improvements to crew facilities.

We do not allow maniacs on our roads. We do not allow semitrailers to run around with bald tyres. We do not allow tankers to spew out fuel onto our urban environment. Very tough conditions apply to tankers carrying petroleum and chemicals. That is fair enough. We all endorse that. The principles should be no less for vessels which ply the highways of the sea. A degree of responsibility rests with the flag states, the owners, the classification societies, the agents, the charterers, the insurance providers and the port and maritime authorities but the principal responsibility rests ultimately with this government.

There is a lesson in the Anand situation. It highlights the major anomaly in our ship safety regime. While foreign tankers must be fully inspected before being issued with single voyage permits to operate on Australia's coastal trade, such inspections are not a prerequisite for foreign bulk carriers. Yet these vessels, identified as the most at risk in the Ships of shame report, are left unscathed. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The catalyst for the inquiry was the loss in close succession of six bulk carriers off the West Australian coast between January 1990 and August 1991. During the inquiry it became clear that the loss of bulk carriers is a significant problem, posing considerable threat to the lives of seafarers, international trade and the marine environment.

Although the APJ Anand incident did spark a departmental review of procedures under the former minister Senator Bob Collins, from the advice I have received from the new minister, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), it appears that nothing further will be done. I quote from my letter to Senator Collins at that time. I said:

In speaking to the parties involved in the APJ ANAND saga, it is known that the classification society's previous rating of the vessel was grossly inaccurate and misleading. I'm sure you'll agree, therefore, we need to strengthen our inspection procedures.
Could you advise how the government proposes to address this anomaly in regard to the issuing of Single Voyage Permits for bulk carriers?
What additional resources has the Australian Maritime Safety Authority received since the handing down of the "Ships of Shame" report?
Sadly, when the new minister, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, replied to that letter he did not address those matters. He took a fairly superficial view of the matter. He said:
Unfortunately the APJ ANAND is a symptom of an international problem which potentially results in small numbers of sub-standard ships participating in the Australian trade.
I would have thought that for an environmentally sensitive government the damage from just one of these derelict ships would be just too high a price to pay. The new minister goes on to say:
The long term solution to the problem of substandard shipping can only be achieved through international action by those having responsibility for ship safety.
I do not accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much comfort in that.

PARA.TAB: Mr NEVILLE—No, there is not. Nor indeed have members of the government who are on this same committee as I accepted that point of view. Certainly that is an important dimension of it. We cannot duck the local issue. It is well and good to make those sorts of statements, but the APJ Anand in our case was hardly an international problem when it threatened our coastline.

I am not opposed to foreign vessels operating in Australian waters and I do not support any form of cabotage which might restrict competition in our seaways. Legitimate foreign vessels should not be made scapegoats for the government's failure to enforce its own maritime safety standards. As we have heard from the shadow minister, on the latest figures, ships of the Australian Maritime Association have been achieving savings on average of $217,000 per vessel per year in operating efficiencies. Then they have to turn around and lose $288,000 on average in petroleum and bunker oil excise. Those who would turn a blind eye to this form of government action on the one hand and then call for cabotage on the other are living in cloud-cuckoo-land. We cannot have it both ways.

It is a little like the situation in my own electorate, where we have a number of train lines under threat. These lines are struggling to maintain viability. Excise increases as of August this year will add $275,000 to the Gladstone-Moura line, raising its total excise contribution to $1.7 million a year or, in the case of the small and equally much threatened Maryborough-Monto-Gladstone line, $80,000 in additional excise for a total excise bill of nearly half a million dollars. One can see that there is a parallel case there. The government is demanding efficiencies on the one hand and then taking them away with the other in excise.

I share the concerns of the honourable member for Throsby regarding the future of Australian flag vessels, the ANL and others, but his government might well look to the cost it imposes on Australian shipping companies. To protect their future and to ensure that they stay in Australian hands we might well look at lowering their operating costs and allowing them to pass on at least some of their efficiencies so that vessel placement and legitimate shareholder expectations can be met and fulfilled.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could also lower the freight rates, too.

—That would help. We have to get fair dinkum about it. We have to start at the cost end and not try to patch up all the problems once the environment has been polluted. However, returning to the matter before the House, we must take greater responsibility for the protection of our coastline. Tightening the permit system to include foreign bulk carriers is a positive step. I am disappointed that the government has decided not to act more positively but rather to rely on the existing inspection regime, the same system which allowed the Anand to sail through the Great Barrier Reef unhindered. It is my personal view that there should be a greater resourcing of AMSA. I am conscious of what the honourable member for Dunkley said about an efficiency audit. At the very least, if we are going to maintain the current practice of only inspecting 25 per cent of these vessels on average we should add extra resources to AMSA by way of intelligence gathering facilities and staff so that we can be ready for such vessels when they come to Australian waters.

PARA.TAB: While I support the bill which is being debated today, which will see polluters brought to task, I cannot close my eyes to the outstanding ship safety anomalies which have not been addressed by the government like the single voyage permits for foreign flag bulk carriers. If this matter were addressed it would ensure that fewer ships of shame like the Anand and the Marine Blue plied the coastal highways of this great nation with the potential to pollute its waters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill. As has been mentioned by previous speakers, the bill encompasses amendments to a number of acts. A number of changes relate to the way the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 applies in the exclusive economic zone. It clarifies provisions which require foreign vessels to provide information to determine whether a pollution breach has occurred. It also clarifies the powers to inspect vessels in the economic zone and the express power to bring people into port, and generally tidies up some of the legislation that has already passed this House.

PARA.TAB: The issue raised by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) in respect of the APJ Anand is one of major importance to this country. It goes to the core of the operation of ships of shame—of substandard shipping—not only in Australia but around the world. The critical issue is the fact that ships operating on the Australian coast, until the incident with the APJ Anand, were not subject to port state inspection. The APJ Anand had been in Australia some years earlier at the port of Geraldton, where the condition of the vessel caused major problems and the port authority had a great concern about it. The vessel arrived later at Albany. Because there was not a surveyor from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority there, the vessel was not subject to AMSA inspection, but its defects were noted and the next port of call was advised of them.

That has led to the question of the inspection of vessels operating under single-voyage permits. We are looking at that in the current resumption of the inquiry into substandard shipping. We have had some information about that. I think it is fairly clear to most members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure that vessels operating under single-voyage permits must be subject to inspection, preferably a mandatory inspection. The Australian Mining Industry Council has called for the mandatory inspection of all vessels operating on the Australian coast under single-voyage permits, so what I have just said is not something that is radical. It is not something that is tougher for Australia than what is being put forward by the organisation that represents the major users, the Australian Mining Industry Council. That is something we are going to come back to later as we proceed through the consideration of the evidence being brought before the committee.

Let us look at the Ships of shame report, the very favourable response and acclaim that it has received across the world, and the momentum it has generated in trying to get rid of substandard shipping. There have been comments made at times that we, as an exporting nation, are being too tough on foreign shipping coming to Australian ports. They are put to rest completely by the consideration of the approach to substandard shipping going on in Europe and the United States at the moment.

There was recently a meeting of the transport ministers from the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, France and Belgium, looking at stamping out pollution. They were particularly concerned about vessels carrying hazardous cargoes travelling their waters. They were looking at bringing in a new convention of liability for ships carrying hazardous and noxious substances, to be enforced by the International Maritime Organisation, by 1996.

They also resolved that they would support research into the feasibility of identifying containers lost overboard. We had an incident with a lost container just a few days ago. The container was submerged, and a yacht struck it and was destroyed. Fortunately, everybody was rescued from the yacht. But containers that are lost overboard and remain afloat but are not always visible are a constant problem at sea.

They also took a decision that ship surveyors in each of those nations that I have mentioned would be exchanging information. They decided that substandard ships would be detained, as they are here, until they are upgraded to meet the international maritime standards. They discussed a further amendment to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea to provide that ships carrying oil, harmful substances and dangerous goods follow predetermined routes. That is, the route to be followed by the master of a vessel in completing its journey would not be one of his selection but would be a prescribed route, similar to what we have on the Australian coast in some areas.

The European Commission only a few weeks ago brought forward very tough plans in respect of port state control. Anybody who thought Australia's approach to port state control and its level of inspection were tough, on reading through and reflecting upon what the European Commission is now proposing and hoping to have in place by 1996, and on what the United States Coast Guard is doing in respect of substandard shipping, would see that Australia looks soft. If anything, we are too easygoing; we are too soft in our approach to substandard shipping in this country.

The developments from the European Commission and from the US Coast Guard are very welcome because they give a legitimacy to the sincere and deeply felt concerns of members of this parliament of both houses, of people out there in the community generally who are concerned for the welfare of seafarers from wherever they come. All of those people now will get some comfort from the fact that it is not a matter of Australia trying to do it by itself here; the major markets of the world, the United States and the European Community, are bringing forward tougher measures than even Australia is carrying out at the moment, so there will be some prospect of sweeping the seas of substandard shipping.

The EC plans, for instance, to look at how to ensure that vessels visiting European ports meet the requirements and that oil tankers that are five years or less away from being phased out under the MARPOL rules, the marine pollution rules, and that bulk carriers over 12 years old will all come under increased port state scrutiny. The proposals they are putting forward will all go to the European Council of Ministers, the European Parliament and, hopefully, will be adopted by the European Union by July 1996.

It touches also on the question of crewing of ships. It was said before that a good crew will save a bad ship in a time of crisis but a bad crew will destroy a good ship in a time of crisis. No matter the condition of the vessel, priority one has to be the competency of the crews.

If one were to look back—and I will not take up the time of the House with it now—over the recent ship accident investigation reports that have been released on the competency of crews of a trawler that was sunk by a foreign flag vessel, one would see that competency of the crew and crew not carrying out their responsibilities were the key feature. It was not the structure of the vessel or condition of the vessel; it was the performance of the crews on both vessels. So surveyors will seek to ensure, when they carry out these port state control inspections under these new proposals for Europe, that crews comply with minimum training standards and are aware of their duties on the master list.

That goes to the core of the problem: the training agencies themselves are a motley collection. We know that the Philippines is a major source of recruitment of seafarers. But many of those seafarers carry phoney qualifications. A few of the training agencies do have world standing and do meet competency standards but many of them do not. There has not yet been sufficient response around the world to this question of ensuring that crews meet competency standards. We made recommendations in our report that there should be a standard set and approved by the International Maritime Organisation. That has not had the response from government that we had hoped it would have. But this issue is not going to go away.

One of the previous speakers, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), referred to the shortage of crews and the shortage of officers—in total, about half a million by the end of this century. It is an enormous shortage. But what is happening is that farmers are going to sea. Effectively, on many vessels, we have seagoing labourers. Until the major trading nations of the world face up to this question of ensuring that crews are adequately trained, we are still going to have an extremely serious problem. I am very pleased to see that the European Commission in its recommendations to its ministers and to the European parliament is proposing that the competency of crews be taken into account.

Another issue that enables much of this substandard operation to survive and the dangers to continue to be created is the conspiracy of silence, as I like to describe it. I think it is most regrettable that in recent weeks the Salvage Association of the United Kingdom has determined that it will no longer release publicly the results of its inspections. It gives some reasons for that, saying that the number of vessels that it now inspects has declined considerably over the last decade. It expresses some reservation about the use to which that information is put. But to me, and I hope to this parliament, those excuses can be seen only as excuses. The effect of it will be to help cover up the abuse of seafarers, the exploitation of seafarers and the dangers of what is going on.

Contrast that with the recommendation from the European Commission, again to its ministers and the European Parliament, that each national administration be required to publish quarterly the number of detentions, including the names of ships, the International Maritime Organisation number, the flag state, the owner and the classification society which issued statutory certificates on behalf of the flag state.

That will help do what we have recommended here and what the Australian Maritime Safety Authority here in Australia has started to do, and that is to get it all out in the open. Much of this abuse can happen only because peculiarly in the shipping industry everything is to be secret; it is commercially confidential. It is that conspiracy of silence, that cloak, that enables these abuses to go on. So it is great to see that the European Community, hopefully, will pick up this recommendation from the European Commission and move now to publish that information. The US Coast Guard already makes that information available on a regular basis. It does not have any problem with it. What the European Commission has recommended to its ministers is supported by the United States Coast Guard and the tougher still approach that it is taking to substandard shipping.

Let me repeat that there is no case for anybody in this country to be offering some kind of puny excuse that in some way, by not turning a blind eye to substandard shipping or by enforcing our requirements under the Port State Control Convention, we are going to impinge upon Australia's terms of trade and our capacity to trade. Let the cargo owner who wants to use a substandard ship, a ship of shame, stand up, identify his or her business and product, and say, `I am prepared to create these risks and to endanger the lives of the seafarers on board that vessel to get the cheap rate that it offers.'

It is wonderful that the US Coast Guard is going even further than it has in the past and that the European Commission is looking to pick up the kind of measures that we recommended here in the parliament in December of 1992. The US Coast Guard is also moving to categorise those flag states which do not carry out their responsibilities as flag states. We know there are flag states that stand out as the home of substandard shipping: Malta, Cyprus, Panama. We could go on through the range of them. But what the US is going to do is to look at three-year averages on the number of vessels detained under those flags and publish that information. That will help put focus upon what is going on with a flag state and put pressure upon the flag state to carry out its responsibilities.

The US Coast Guard is also going to enforce checks on flag states. What the head of the US Coast Guard, Admiral William Kime, has said recently is that a mechanism should be set up that would enable the International Maritime Organisation to certify the capability of flag states to enforce the various safety and anti-pollution conventions.

Our capacity to enforce measures relating to the prevention of pollution is one of the issues covered in this legislation. The recommendation from the US Coast Guard in respect of the IMO hopefully will do something about those flag states which see the registration of ships as an easy source of revenue. It is an easy source of revenue without having to carry any responsibilities. That is one good measure that has occurred.

Another measure which I am greatly heartened by is the support being given to the view that I have expressed repeatedly: cargo owners are ultimately the people who trigger the use of substandard shipping. You can tie a substandard ship to the buoy, park it by the wharf, and it cannot do very much harm. Admittedly, the vessel can leak oil or whatever but, in relative terms, it can do little harm. It becomes a danger to those who work on it and it is a danger to the waters in which it travels when a cargo owner says that he wants to use that vessel. There are plenty of instances where the same cargo owners use the same type of vessel, obviously because it is the cheapest vessel that they can get.

The measures that I have proposed relate to cargo owners being held responsible for the operation of substandard ships. They unleash those dangers when they say, for example, `Yes, I will use the MV Bendigo owned by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). It suits me fine. Yes, it has got a problem.' They take a deliberate decision to unleash the dangers and the risks involved in the use of that vessel. The article in the Daily Commercial News dated 29 April 1994 states:

SPEECH.PARA: If a cargo owner charters a ship that is detained for being unseaworthy, it is the shipowner who has to pay for it—but the law should be changed to penalise the cargo owner.
That statement has come from Roberto Salvarani, the head of the maritime safety at the EC transport directorate. I was greatly heartened when he said:

. . . a survey had shown that it was legally possible and technically feasible for cargo owners to be held responsible for the consequences of trading substandard ships by an EC directive or IMO convention.

In other words, if we can get an IMO convention that will hold cargo owners responsible, it is a major solution to the problem. The ship will not have a cargo. It will not be able go to sea; it will go straight to the scrap yard. Similarly, it will solve the problem if the European Commission, in respect of its own shipping, makes a direction. We are not Robinson Crusoe. We have been trying to do something ourselves in respect of shipping. Australia stands tall in the world in respect of the credentials of its seafarers, its standards in respect of shipping, the role that it plays in the International Maritime Organisation and the lead it and this parliament have given to the issue of the safety of shipping and the protection of the lives of seafarers.

PARA.TAB: As a nation, we can only benefit from a better standard of shipping. There may be a temporary problem in that some firms might be able to continue to utilise substandard shipping, but that is going to stop. When I started this speech, I mentioned the Australian Mining Industry Council statement. It believes that every ship operating under a single-voyage permit around the coastline of this nation should be subject to a port state inspection to ensure that it meets the required international standards. I support the legislation that is before the parliament and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the legislation, in particular the amendments to the Air Navigation Act 1920 and the fashion in which they attempt to fulfil government commitments about producing competitive markets for international aviation in and out of Australia.This whole issue of competition is very important in aviation. It comes from a broad government agenda about competition; it comes out of the Hilmer report. In telecommunications and the whole range of infrastructure provision around the country there are important gains to be made in productivity from having competition between infrastructure providers, particularly in the aviation industry. It is important to understand not only do we need good legislation to provide competition between airlines but also we need a commitment to competition between airports. The competitive structure needs to be right for aviation as an industry—for the planes as well as their destinations.

PARA.TAB: Last week the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in a landmark speech in Melbourne outlined his important framework for achieving those goals. This is an issue that is very important to me as the member for Werriwa. When I contested the by-election, my leading promise was to establish an international airport at Badgerys Creek. It will be a very important competitor for the large aviation market currently serviced at Kingsford Smith in east Sydney. I mentioned this in my maiden speech. I cannot explain how flattered I was to have faxed through to my office later that day a press release from the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). The headline of the press release said `Latham shows Labor the way on Badgerys Creek'. For a new member to be the subject of a press release from a shadow minister was indeed a flattering moment in my parliamentary career. The release went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has two choices if it wants to see Badgerys Creek built.
Firstly, it could fund the airport from consolidated revenue.
I hope Mr Latham will continue to press his colleagues on this issue. While he may have woken up to the solution to this problem, the Labor Party remains crippled by inaction.

I have a sneaking suspicion that in a few hours time the shadow minister will have to draft another press release, this time praising this government for its very strong action on Badgerys Creek, the new Sydney west international airport. The shadow minister might also have to reconsider the matter of public importance he has listed about government administration of civil aviation, because there is no better way to administer the aviation industry than that being pursued by the Minister for Transport. His model for competition between airlines is reflected in this legislation, and his model for competition between airports is reflected in the landmark speech in Melbourne last week.

PARA.TAB: I note also that there has been some media speculation about how feasible the international airport in Sydney's west will be. The argument fed by the FAC is that it has done a survey of all the existing operators at Kingsford Smith. Many have said, according to the hypothetical survey, that they want to stay at Mascot, defend their existing investments and downplay the role of a second international airport in Sydney. Of course, that is what they are going to say in hypothetical circumstances. The existing operators, posed that question, will always say, `We will defend our interests and our large investment at our existing location. We will downplay the role of the second airport.'

We need to understand—this is a view shared by both sides of the House, I believe—that in a competitive market where there is a customer base infrastructure providers must follow their customers and cover the way in which competitors will break out of existing markets to establish themselves in large and growing markets.

A study in November 1993 by Economic and Energy Analysis and the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research in Melbourne showed that, by the year 2000, 26 per cent of air passengers in Sydney will live closer to Badgerys Creek than Mascot. That means there will be a catchment area for Sydney West international airport of more than five million passengers per annum. As well, one-third of companies exporting air freight out of Sydney will be located closer to Badgerys Creek than Mascot. That is, 48,000 tonnes of air freight per annum will be exported out of the catchment area for Sydney west international airport.

These are quite significant figures because this will be the third largest aviation market in Australia after Kingsford Smith and Tullamarine. Quite frankly, no airline and no freight forwarder can ignore such a market. If they do turn their backs on that sort of market, they run a very high risk from new entrants in a competitive airline industry locating at Sydney west international airport, tapping into the third largest—and fastest growing—aviation market in Australia, and making substantial profits. Once the hypothetical surveys are put to one side, the truth is that according to basic market forces those operators must follow their customers to the very large catchment in Sydney's west and south-west. It is an outstanding initiative for the government and the Minister for Transport to introduce competition across the board for aviation and airports, and for the government to recognise the importance of these reforms, as part of the white paper process.

For my region, in the south-west of Sydney—which has had high unemployment for a number of decades now, under governments of all persuasions, and a high proportion of long-term unemployed—this is a very significant day. It is the first time a national government in Australia has not only attempted to make the long-term unemployed jobs ready but also attempted in regions with high unemployment to make jobs available, to match up both sides of the labour market.

On the supply side, the government is reconnecting people into the work force. On the demand side, it is making sure that important infrastructure projects—such as Sydney west international airport—in a competitive environment are available to generate tens of thousands of jobs. So the shadow minister will be drafting his press release, and I am sure the Minister for Transport will be very happy with the outcome that has been achieved in such a short space of time.

With regard to the benefits to employment, a report by the national institute in 1991 detailed the substantial employment benefits of the new airport through competition, with the creation of at least 36,000 new jobs in the region over the next 20 years. That means much more than jobs coming out of airport construction or out of airport operation. It is a major regional economic development opportunity, because of the cluster of industries that will locate around the airport site. That is, the government is using infrastructure policy and competition policies at a national and regional level to achieve jobs in a region that badly needs them.

From the catalyst of Sydney west international airport manufacturing will regard Sydney's west as an attractive place for the location of its activities and joining the export push from Australia, and also for tourism industries. There is a large and growing tourism market in Sydney's west, spearheaded by the Blue Mountains. The new airport, of course, with the international length strip, will facilitate the benefits of tourism growth in our region. So these are very important things.

The study in 1991 also examined the discounted benefit of Badgerys Creek relative to the expansion of Kingsford Smith. It identified a net expansion of national GDP by $8.8 billion to the year 2010, which represents 2.5 per cent of our current annual output in Australia. The government is not only doing something that is good by the standards of regional policy, through competition between airports and in aviation, but also something that is, in its own right, a very important micro-economic reform for Australia.

We are going to be moving away from an airport at Kingsford Smith which, by any standard—particularly international standards—is inefficient. It is congested, and is running out of room for its expansion. What next—the fourth runway? We already see forecasts, even before its opening, about the third runway reaching capacity by the year 2000. The road network around Kingsford Smith is much too congested, and the curfew at night is a hindrance to the airline operators.

All these things will be avoided at the competitor airport in Sydney's west. There will be state-of-the-art technology, ideal for freight forwarders wanting to join the export drive. There will be no curfew at night hindering the operation of freight aircraft. There will be no congestion around the road network at Badgerys Creek. It will be, by international standards, Australian's first advanced, and best-practice designed, international airport. That is a tremendous initiative for this government to realise as a micro-reform, making the economy and our export drive all the more efficient.

I know that manufacturing enterprises in western Sydney, which have been growing substantially, are looking forward to an efficient airport to give them their best possible chance of joining the export push. No longer will they have to battle all that horrendous Sydney congestion on the roads to place their produce at Alexandria with the freight forwarding companies. At present, they have to wait a couple of days until the order comes through, and then wait until there is a plane available and, when they do put it on the plane, there are delays at the airport. All the while their customers in Asia are waiting desperately for these goods.

We will have in western Sydney a very efficient airport that overcomes all the problems at Kingsford Smith. It will also be very important for Sydney's urban and economic development, because there has been a substantial movement of manufacturing enterprises to Sydney's west and south-west. The government, following market forces, is facilitating further development of manufacturing by making sure that the international airport is there to efficiently carry goods to export markets.

One can look at the figures for employment change from June 1992 to June 1993 in Fairfield-Liverpool and the outer south-west, which is part of my electorate. Employment grew there in 12 months by 29,000 jobs, according to the DEET figures. That was an employment increase of 16 per cent. The inner Sydney and inner western Sydney figures are the exact opposite. There was a loss of 19,000 jobs in those 12 months, a decrease of 9.7 per cent. The benefits for urban planning in Sydney are substantial. As long as I have been alive, the battle in western Sydney has been to get the jobs in place before the development of the housing estates.

That, of course, is the great objective—not just to lower the rate of unemployment but to produce a much more efficient urban area, so that people do not have to travel long distances, in cars which are polluting the air, to find their place of employment. We need a region that is self-contained in terms of employment opportunities. These are very good goals that the government would be supporting through an international strip at Badgerys Creek. They not only produce a micro-reform of substantial benefit, not only producing more than 30,000 jobs in Sydney's west and south-west, through industry clustering over the next 20 years; not only producing greater efficiency and environmental benefits in Sydney's west by reducing commuter times; but also, in the inner city, ending the way in which the FAC for decades has misled communities about the potential growth and noise consequences of Kingsford Smith.

My colleague in the chamber, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), has led a campaign for many years to make sure that the FAC is kept honest, made responsible, and pushed into an environment of competition. For the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, the Minister for Transport, to be able, after only five months in the job, to produce these results is enormously to his credit. It is a tremendous thing for him to have achieved for the inner city and the western part of Sydney, as well as for the region that I represent in the south-west.

I look forward to support from across the Sydney metropolitan area for this sort of initiative. I hope the aviation writers can break free from the FAC drip and have a look at the very positive way in which market competition can make a real difference. It must be understood that the catchment in Sydney's west is the third largest in Australia for aviation purposes, and no company, no airline, and no freight forwarder—away from the hypothetical surveys—will ignore that sort of market opportunity. If they do, they will not be in the market for very long, because the new airlines that are establishing, and some of the existing players—particularly in freight forwarding—will most certainly take up those opportunities.

One can imagine how the next Compass in the domestic aviation market in Australia will not be messing around with restrictive trade practices on the counter space for Kingsford Smith, crowded out by the existing players. They will be straight out to Sydney west international airport, with equal opportunity on the airport design to market their services to the third largest aviation market in Australia. These opportunities reflect well on the legislation the House is now considering to make sure that not only domestic aviation competition works in this country, but also international competition.

The FAC has developed a flawed model about aviation movements in Sydney. It is called the residual development model, and it is something like a glass of water overflowing. The unrealistic assumption is that there will be no demand at Sydney west international airport until such time as Kingsford Smith has saturated its capacity. That is to say, when they cannot fit one more plane on the runways at Kingsford Smith or deal with one more freight forwarding opportunity, then—and only then—will these operators look to Sydney's west and its aviation market which is bigger than Adelaide or Brisbane, and bigger than any airport in Australia other than Kingsford Smith and Tullamarine.

That, of course, is a model which any first-year university student will tell us is fundamentally flawed. Its assumptions are wrong, because it rules out any notion of market competition, and any notion of companies being aggressive or innovative. The FAC has no interest in any of the things we talk about in this parliament, how companies in Australia in the 1990s need to achieve to be competitive and strong. I suppose one can understand that. It is a monopoly itself: a monopoly that has never been exposed to market competition, except for Cairns airport, which is a tearaway success, as identified by the McKinsey report. That report shows that Cairns has done a lot better than the FAC airport at Townsville, and that it has provided the sort of economic boost that we will now see in Sydney's west.

The FAC needs to bring itself up to date. It needs to read the Hilmer report, understand some of the basic rules of economics about competitive markets and how market forces produce benefits. It needs to break free of its monopoly shackles and understand that this is an airport well worth supporting.

The state government in New South Wales also needs to upgrade its point of view, because it has taken a very poor role in the planning process. The site at Badgerys Creek has been identified as the airport site since 1986, and in the eight years since then no state government has lifted a finger to do any of the basic planning—not for roads and not for rail. Nothing happened until the Minister for Transport took the initiative by putting in federal money for the road links and commenced federal planning about the rail links.

This airport can be operational by 1999. It will have an international length runway, fully serviced road and rail access, a growing manufacturing and freight forwarding market in Sydney's west, and 25 per cent of the passenger share of international traffic by the year 2000. All these figures are rising as Sydney's west and south-west continue to grow and mature as regional economies.

The share of freight imports into Badgerys Creek will increase from 31 per cent in 1995 to 42 per cent of the Sydney market by the year 2020. The share of exports from Badgerys Creek will rise from a third in 1995 through to 51 per cent by the year 2020. The passenger share will go up substantially after the year 2000, kicked on by the enormous tourism boost from the 2000 Olympics. That is in recognition of the fact that a number of the sporting events are located much closer to Badgerys Creek than they are to Kingsford Smith. This sort of initiative brings together a whole range of reforms, including competition policy reflected in this legislation, better urban planning, better noise control, less congestion in the inner city and more jobs for Sydney's south-west.

I will conclude where I began on the historical significance of this day, by stressing the broad sweep of how this parliament and how governments in Australia have formulated economic policy. This government has spent a lot of time working on making the Australian economy more competitive. Now it turns its focus towards making the regions more competitive. It is backing sensible and well targeted, cost-effective infrastructure development like Sydney West international airport.

It is the first government to do that. It is the first government in Australia's history to have an effective agenda for regional economic development. It is also the first government to take an active interest in the benefits and the welfare of the long-term unemployed. It is making the training market and the training agenda more effective. It is reconnecting the long-term unemployed to the work force.

On both sides of the labour market it is making the long-term unemployed jobs ready and making the regions jobs available. This is, by Australian standards, a major breakthrough for regions and electorates such as mine and for all those regions around the country that have been saying for many years that they wish to compete, and compete effectively. Come the end of today, we will be even more confident in Sydney's south-west of our chance to compete. It is reflected here in the legislation for international airlines.

We know that Sydney west international airport will not only compete against Kingsford Smith but it will win the competitive battle. It will win the competitive battle on the back of our substantially enhanced and growing region, growing population and growing economic strength. This is a very good initiative for all the people that I represent and for those in the broader metropolis of Sydney's west and south-west.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in making a few remarks on this omnibus bill, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, in particular on how it relates to air traffic. I commend the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) for the amendments to the Air Navigation Act and point out that my constituents are in favour of any move to rationalise aircraft operations. These amendments allow the Australian carriers to comply with international requirements in accordance with our bilateral agreements. They also allow the act to address capacity arrangements in line with a deregulated industry and our bilateral landing rights agreements. I agree with my colleague that it is a pity that the Federal Airports Corporation was not all that interested in a deregulated industry.

PARA.TAB: This bill clearly outlines a definition of what an Australian carrier is and prescribes permissible levels of foreign ownership, safeguarding the growth of our air industry. The airline industry is a growth industry, as the member for Werriwa and other speakers in this debate have pointed out. I take the chance to remind the House that, even with the third runway at Sydney airport, future demands on capacity at that airport are very pressing.

The Federal Airports Corporation's own projections of future usage of the airport at Sydney envisage a five per cent annual growth of traffic. Authoritative figures that are to hand suggest that in 1993 there were 21,087 landings and there were 4,472 take-offs on the north runway. After the parallel runway is developed the runway will be able to take 15,302 landings and 15,302 take-offs. The important thing to note with that five per cent annual growth is that the landings and take-offs will increase to 21,530 by the year 2000.

Indeed, the worst case scenario—which often, the way the FAC does things, becomes the norm—is that, with particular weather conditions and a heavy load on the day, the north runway, the long runway at Sydney airport, could be in use for over 150 take-offs a day to the north of the airport, which equates to about one take-off every seven minutes. This is take-offs to the north of the airport, when the FAC and all the environmental impact statements and speeches that were made in the discussion over the last 10 years on the use of Sydney airport said that there would be very few take-offs to the north.

When I and some of my colleagues, such as the member for Phillip, as she was at the time, now the member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh), the member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) and Mr Michael Maher, who was the member for Lowe at the time, said that building the third runway and concentrating activities at Sydney airport were going to be a disaster, we were all said to be scaremongering and just saying this for political opportunism. But the FAC's own figures are now showing that, on a day when the weather is bad, we will get one flight every seven minutes taking off over people's homes. That is disgraceful and it puts the lie to all the things that the FAC has said in this debate. Its own worst case scenario is 150 take-offs a day to the north of the airport.

No doubt the residents of my electorate and the other electorates surrounding the airport will be comforted by the government's statement later today, and the work that the Minister for Transport has done on seeing that we do something for western Sydney. What the minister has done is to ensure that we have a regime that will allow us to expand the operations of Badgerys Creek and to put into place the transport infrastructure which will allow Badgerys Creek to operate.

All through the run-up to the choosing of development at Sydney airport, we had the FAC saying, `Oh yes, we are all in favour of doing something at Badgerys Creek.' But what we find now is that it was doing just what those of us who were interested in this project said it would be doing—nothing. There was no planning for the road and rail infrastructure that would link Badgerys Creek airport to the city, there was no planning for the expansion of that airport—there was no planning for Badgerys Creek at all. What the FAC wanted to do was concentrate all its activity at Sydney airport. One would expect that ultimately we would have the only economic case put forward to us that it was interested in, which would be, `Well, Minister, the problem with Sydney airport is that we have got all this infrastructure and investment there and it is only being used 17 hours a day—we really need to get rid of the curfew.'

What Minister Brereton has done now in his proposals to have Badgerys Creek connected to the rail and road infrastructure of Sydney and in his proposals to sell off some of the FAC's operations will ensure that Badgerys Creek is able to compete with Sydney airport. As a non-curfewed airport, Badgerys Creek will be successful, in my view.

The FAC seems to think that Australia should go against the trends of everywhere else in the world. Any member or citizen who has travelled to the other large capitals of the world sees something entirely different from what happens in Sydney. In all the other large capitals there is a smaller 1950s or 1940s airport close to the centre of the city and the large international operator out on the city rim. In London there are two big airports, one at Gatwick and one at Heathrow; Washington has Washington National and Dulles and New York has La Guardia and Kennedy. Any of these large cities has two airports.

The FAC in its manic attempt to ensure that Sydney had only one airport searched the world to come up with an example of a city where there was a big airport planned by the government on the rim of the city that had failed. Such an airport was found in Canada, so the FAC said, `See, this is not a one-off; this is what happens everywhere.' However, the current official of the FAC is the chairman of the World Airports Association, and I am sure he would not be silly enough to say to the government, `Of course, these large airports on city rims have failed all around the world,' because they know it is absolutely not true.

This is a ridiculous attempt to invent something that does not happen anywhere else in the world and concentrate all the activity on one of the smallest airports in the world. That is just not going to work, and the government and particularly Minister Brereton are going to make sure that that little plot is undone. The infrastructure that will be built to link Badgerys Creek with the city by the rail and road networks will ensure that that airport, if it is freed up from the FAC's grasp, will be able to compete with Sydney airport—and compete very well.

The minister has also flagged the idea of selling Tullamarine. The minister really should package Badgerys Creek and Tullamarine together and sell them as a job lot. I think that there would be very great interest from large international operators as well as Australian operators in two airports that can serve the two largest markets in Australia, both of them being non-curfewed airports.

What is going to kill Sydney airport in the end—or kill the residents—is the struggle between the FAC to have the curfew lifted and the residents who want to have some peace and quiet. When you see that its own figures suggest that on bad days there can be a take-off—not a landing—every seven minutes over the suburbs of Sydney, that shows just how stupid the planning proposals were—not just stupid but scandalous.

If Badgerys Creek is opened up as Sydney's western airport, we will see the development of a very significant freight industry. At present some freight operators bring night freight into Sydney with the government licensing, in most instances, quiet aircraft. One operator bought some quiet aircraft—Ansett bought BAe146s—but then Australian Airlines, which is now Qantas, whinged and said, `Of course, we have not got any of those quiet aircraft but we have got some that are not quite so quiet and, in the terms of proper competition, Minister, you should let us fly these aircraft.'

I am sad to say that recently a very stupid decision was made by the government to allow Qantas to fly 737s for night freight operation for a 12-month period. I can say here today that I am going to make sure that, when the 12 months is up, this period will not be extended. It is a disgrace that these people should be allowed to operate such noisy aircraft over the suburbs of Sydney throughout the night.

Badgerys Creek is the perfect place for this. A significant freight operation will be able to operate from Badgerys Creek. International freight operators can come to Badgerys Creek in very large aircraft. It needs to be remembered that Badgerys Creek is at the centre of the growth area of Sydney. To be trying to develop all these aviation operations in a very cramped peninsula, 20 minutes from the CBD, is an absolute nonsense. In fact, figures show that Badgerys Creek catchment area will increase the total Sydney passenger market from 21 per cent to 32 per cent by the year 2020. That catchment area will be larger than any area outside the Sydney and Melbourne CBDs.

The FAC says that we should build an international gateway in Cairns and international airports in Adelaide, Darwin and Perth. But where there is a market that is bigger than all those markets, it wants to put down some little strip that will not even take small jet aircraft. That is a nonsense; it is stupid. It is not going to be sustained.

The changes that Minister Brereton has put forward, and which will come into effect, will ensure that we get a bit of competition in the airport industry in Australia. Surely this other monopoly, the Federal Airports Corporation, should be opened up to competition, if the airlines tell us they are in favour of competition and if the government has told other GBEs that they should be open to competition. It has told Telecom that it should be forced into competition. As part of that forced change, there are some amendments to Telecom's legislation in this bill that are directly related to Telecom having competition.

The opposition is not much better. Its answer is to sell the Federal Airports Corporation; this replaces a public monopoly with a private monopoly. That is just as silly. What we need in this area is proper competition. One of the most competitive regimes that could be put together in Australia would be created if there were one owner for Badgerys Creek and Tullamarine. It could get into competition with this large government business enterprise which has been busy spreading half-truths around the country for so long. We would then see the proper development of Badgerys Creek and the movement of an asset to the people in the industry who can use it.

If it is good enough to have airports in markets that are smaller than that market, it is certainly good enough to have a proper airport that can take international traffic at Badgerys Creek. It will ensure that the airport industry in Australia reacts as it has in the rest of the world, with a smaller, inner city airport, dealing with some international traffic but mostly with domestic traffic, and a bigger international operator out on the city rim.

The people of my electorate and the electorates around the airport have no problem with Sydney airport being involved to a greater extent with domestic traffic. Domestic passengers tend not to want to fly at midnight or at 5.00 a.m., and the curfew can work safely there and not be of detriment to the operators. It can be a positive boon, in fact, to the people who live around the airport. Domestic jets are in the main not as heavy as and are less noisy than those of the international operators that are coming into Sydney airport now.

The FAC needs to comply with what it said it would do originally, which is have take-offs to the south and few or no take-offs to the north. The way to ensure that happens is to move the big operators out to the city rim. Let us have a decent, proper competitive regime and let us see that we get a bit of balanced development in the west of Sydney—and some sanity for the people who live around Sydney airport.

I commend this legislation to the House and congratulate Minister Brereton on his foresight which will ensure our transport and communications industries are given the scope they require to grow and, in particular, to compete in Australia's more and more internationalised marketplace.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—At the conclusion of this debate I thank the honourable members who have contributed during the morning and into the afternoon. Although this Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill contains mainly machinery measures, honourable members have taken the opportunity to express some fairly strongly held views in a range of areas in which they are, in many ways, quite expert. The preceding speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), for example, has a distinct and well-developed interest in the operations at Mascot airport.

PARA.TAB: As I stated in the second reading speech, the bill does not introduce any substantial new policy measures and can be summed up as follows: some amendments to the Air Navigation Act will ensure that Australian airlines that are designated as international carriers under international agreements are substantially controlled and owned by Australian nationals. In fact, they have to continue to be that in order to be the designated national carrier. That comes about through the government's decision to float the ownership of Qantas. It means that Qantas, in fact, must have at least 65 per cent Australian ownership to continue to be described as the national carrier.

The bill also contains some amendments to the Telecommunications Act, which simply change the name to reflect the new trading position of Telecom and Telstra—as it is called in its international operations. There are some amendments to the Navigation Act which tidy up the validity of some exemptions to the act and particularly—and I think this is a very important one—give the maritime authority the power to collect the costs of cleaning up the pollution that is caused particularly by foreign vessels operating in Australian waters. We do not have any difficulty through our various schemes in dealing with Australian shipping in Australian waters, but the ability to collect the costs and force contributions to the fund from foreign vessels is tidied up in this legislation.

There is also a very interesting amendment which enables what we call community service obligations, the requirement of Telecom to make sure that people have access to the phone system and for the payphone system to be extended into the Indian Ocean territories for which Australia has responsibility, in particular, the Cocos and Christmas Islands.

In conclusion, it is worth making one correction to the contribution made by the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) when he was talking about the incident with the Daishowa Maru and referred to the article in the Australian supplement. It is of significance to note that with that incident there was not actually any oil spilt into the sea and so, while the incident itself was significant and highlights the need for our work in this field, in that particular case it was not one that led to actual marine pollution.

I thank the members who have contributed to the debate. I think the legislation takes us all a step further in all of these areas. I appreciate the fact that the opposition has allowed this legislation to pass without dissent on its part, so it is in fact a collaborative arrangement, and that is a good sign for the people who are involved and most particularly the people from the Department of Transport who have put their effort into bringing this legislation together. They too will be pleased to know that the parliament has supported it on both sides of the House. I commend the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr O'Keefe) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill makes amendments to a number of acts within the Human Services and Health portfolio. The amendments are largely of a minor procedural nature and are aimed at rectifying a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen.

PARA.TAB: Part 2 of this bill amends the Disability Services Act 1986 to provide for the recovery of costs incurred by the Commonwealth in the provision of rehabilitation programs. It has been a longstanding practice in the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to serve notices in relation to the recovery of rehabilitation costs on insurers prior to the settlement or conclusion of litigation between the insurer and the insured person. The amendment will provide legislative backing for notices to be served in time for the debt to the Commonwealth to be considered as part of the negotiations prior to the settlement of the compensation claim. Under current legislation there is no requirement for the party deemed liable to pay compensation to discharge the debt to the Commonwealth before paying the person receiving the compensation. This has led to situations where the Commonwealth has had to recover moneys from its rehabilitation client. The amendment will ensure that the insurer pays the debt to the Commonwealth before award moneys are disbursed.
Both amendments to section 23 will serve to strengthen legislative support for the recovery of costs by the Commonwealth for rehabilitation programs provided to clients with compensation claims.

Finally, the bill amends section 26 to require decision makers under part III of the Disability Services Act to notify persons affected by their decisions of the making of the decisions and of their rights of appeal. The Administrative Review Council has recently explored ways of improving a client's appeal rights. The council's advice is implemented through this amendment.

The amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, made by part 3 of this bill, are consequential to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. The Childcare Rebate Act 1993 was another important step to ensure that child care is affordable for all working families. From 1 July 1994, parents using child care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work will be able to claim a cash rebate for part of their child-care expenses. An estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from the scheme.

The Commonwealth child-care cash rebate will be administered by the Health Insurance Commission on behalf of the Department of Human Services and Health. The cash rebate will be payable by mail or in person through Medicare offices of the Health Insurance Commission. To enable the Health Insurance Commission to begin preparations for the child-care rebate, the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Act 1993 was passed during the autumn sittings last year.

Part 3 of this bill makes further amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, to ensure that it makes adequate provision in relation to the child-care cash rebate functions of the commission. Accordingly, the Health Insurance Commission will be required to prepare estimates of receipts and expected expenditure related to the performance of its child-care cash rebate functions, to expend its moneys in relation to those functions only in accordance with approved estimates of expenditure, apportion its assets appropriately, apportion its expenditure appropriately and open bank accounts required to enable it properly to handle its moneys.

The opportunity has also been taken to make technical and drafting amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to facilitate the operation of the financial provisions of the act in relation to functions conferred on the commission.

In part 4, the bill proposes a schedule of amendments to two acts. The schedule makes technical and drafting amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953, substantially to cast certain references in inclusive rather than sexist language. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is largely mechanical and the coalition will not be opposing it. However, there are a few points relating to the family and in particular to the many women whose unpaid `work' is largely ignored, especially the raising, nurturing and education of their children at home, which I shall discuss further in my speech. This comes under part 3 of the bill, or those aspects of the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 which are consequential on the passage of the Childcare Rebate Act 1993.

PARA.TAB: I really am very disappointed that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is not here. This is, of course, her first bill since she has become a minister and I had hoped that we might have seen her in here to discuss this bill, which has some very important implications for women.

The Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 proposes amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953. Part 2 of this bill amends the Disability Services Act 1986 by inserting a new subsection 23(5A) to bring the legislation into line with what has developed as common practice over the years in relation to the issue of early notices of intent to recover moneys to the person potentially liable to pay compensation.

Subsection 23(7) is also to be amended to require the insurer who has been sent a notice under subsection 23(5) advising of the debt due to the Commonwealth relating to the rehabilitation program provided, to pay that debt before any payment is made to the client. Section 26 of the act is also amended by the inclusion of a provision relating to section 27A of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the effect of which is to require decision makers to notify their decisions to the people affected and to inform them of their review rights.

The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service is responsible for the delivery of rehabilitation services to workers compensation authorities. These services account for 32 per cent of CRS service delivery and are revenue raising for the Commonwealth. The Disability Services Act 1986 does not allow for the CRS to claim payment for rehabilitation services prior to service delivery. In the past CRS has encountered problems attempting to recover moneys from workers compensation authorities after services have been rendered. As a result, this has often led to cost recovery from CRS rehabilitation clients rather than from the relevant authority. The amendments before the House today will overcome the past recovery difficulties and administrative delays by allowing CRS to claim funds from workers compensation authorities prior to service delivery for clients.

The coalition supports this concept as the outcome will be a step towards better accountability of government revenue. The question of government accountability has, of course, a familiar ring to it. Already in this first week of a new parliamentary sitting we have heard much about the need for greater accountability in relation to the spending of public moneys. Yesterday's matter of public importance debate about the fraudulent use of funds expended under the Department of Employment, Education and Training programs highlighted the government's accountability problems. It is yet another demonstration of the government's inability to monitor programs and account for disbursement of funds. In the last parliamentary sitting it was its famous sports rorts affair. In the spring sittings it is a question of watch this space for the next example of extravagant waste of taxpayers money by a government which has lost the plot.

As I mentioned earlier in my speech, I would like to make particular reference to part 3 of the bill which proposes amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, consequential to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. From 1 July this year, a $30 allowance will be paid in lieu of the present dependent spouse rebate for those parents who elect to stay home to care for their children. For the 840,000 Australian families where one parent, usually the mother, is caring for children full time in the home, the government's initiative is a case of not all that glitters is gold.

The Keating government's lack of regard for the contribution made by parents caring for their children at home is demonstrated by the yawning gap between the child-care cash rebate—which is worth $61.20 per week for two children—and the home child-care allowance, set at a maximum $60 per fortnight. The 840,000 families across Australia in the latter category have a right to feel cheated. Their caring for their children at home is deemed to have about half the value of child care received by the 230,000 families who will receive the rebate.

Women who elect to stay at home to look after their young children no doubt feel demeaned as a result of this Labor government's action. These women are not being adequately recognised for their significant contribution to the family unit and to our society as a whole.

The coalition has always recognised the need for choice for families when raising their children. Unfortunately, with the cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate, the government has done nothing to extend support to those parents whose family priorities result in one parent staying home to care for their small children. This cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate and turning it into the home child-care allowance will not make a jot of difference to the ability of the average single income family's ability to provide basic necessities and to meet the cost of raising children.

Work by the Social Policy Research Centre has demonstrated that families earning between $20,000 and $40,000 a year have been the big losers under Labor. Research by the Department of Social Security has shown that since 1983 when this Labor government was first elected a single income couple with two children on average weekly earnings is now nearly five per cent worse off in real terms. Other research studies have shown that there is no net assistance from government to families with dependent children. These families enjoy a real standard of living about three-fifths that of the rest of the adult working population.

The non-means-tested child-care cash rebate makes having two parents in the paid work force, getting their two tax free thresholds and their means test free child-care rebate, the logical—perhaps essential—financial option. It may not, however, be the better option for their family's non-financial welfare.

This issue of the right of choice keeps recurring. When parents would prefer to have the opportunity of continuous close personal contact and interaction with their young children, watching over their developmental stages as they grow but are deprived from doing so because government financial policies impact on them, Australia's families are not being well served.

The Keating government discriminates against families with one income compared with those families who have both parents in the work force and who are eligible to receive a child-care rebate of up to $61 per week for their children in external child care. It is a monstrous inequity which demonstrates no regard for those parents who sacrifice their income and financial independence to stay home to nurture their children at a critical time of their children's development.

Further, the home child-care allowance is also income tested. An at-home parent cannot have income of more than $282 a year before losing this new benefit at a rate of $1 for every $4 of income. So a second-income parent who earns $282 a day or $282 an hour is eligible for $61 per week child-care rebate but a full-time parent will start to lose the home child-care allowance with an income of a miserable 78c per day.
I have been in this parliament now just on 20 years and for some time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good on you!
—Yes, really, since 18 May 1974.
—You don't look it.
—Not a minute of it. And for some time before coming into this parliament I was—
—You're getting better every year.

—I am trying harder and it is costing me more. For some time before coming into this parliament I had been very active in politics and particularly in issues relevant to women. This was from the 1960s on, at probably the beginning of the women's movement. I wonder for how many more years its simple message will be misunderstood.

PARA.TAB: The message back in the late 1960s and early 1970s was one of the right of choice for women of not being put into a particular mould, of rejecting the assumption that once they married they must have children and they must stay at home and look after those children full time or else they were unnatural women. The situation now seems to be a 180-degree turn which indicates that the arguments that were being put forward in those days have never been understood in all the intervening years. We have it encapsulated by those child-care financial provisions.

Let me make it absolutely crystal clear that the coalition stands for free choice. It is not opposed to the child-care cash rebate. In fact, it advocated it in the 1984 federal election and has done so in every election since. It would make fascinating reading indeed to go back over the statements of various Labor Party ministers and private members in the intervening years to find out why there could be no rebate where there were two parents in employment. The previous minister for sport rorts and all those other things she was minister for—

TALK.START.PARA: —And whiteboards.

—Yes, that is right. She is on the record time and again, particularly as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, as saying why one could not have a rebate for child-care costs when those child-care costs were related to earning an income. The statements are legion. Those statements are, of course, now flicked aside and not referred to at all by the government. There is no attempt at justification of why it has taken over 10 years for this government to recognise that child-care costs can be a necessary expense of earning an income.

PARA.TAB: I repeat, the coalition has long since recognised that need in its policies and went to the election 10 years ago on policies to that effect. So we are not opposed to the rebate. What we are opposed to is the situation the woman who chooses the other option—which was the so-called traditional option—is now put into, and how she is treated in contrast to the career woman.

One of the things this bill does is fix up some sexist language and makes the language in the acts gender neutral. I thoroughly approve of that, let me make that very clear. I was very careful in the earlier stages of this speech to be gender neutral in my language. I am now not being gender neutral because in most cases the parent staying at home is the mother and I am presently focusing on that fact.

It is highly relevant that we have this debate at the moment, because there is a lot of debate also going on about the subject of women in politics. I have really been itching for the opportunity to say this. The trouble we have with the subject of affirmative action or encouraging women into parliament is that, to this very day, the contribution of the full-time wife and mother is still regarded as zero by this community. That is the problem that women have at preselection councils. One of the government members opposite is nodding her head in agreement; it is the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith).

If we were to look at the profile of the women in this parliament, we would find the following facts. A number of those women are not married and have no children.
