A number are married and have no children. A number of the rest married, had children, and—when their children were of a certain age, an age of independence—came into parliament. That tells you something. I came in comparatively young, and childless. All the women who have come in here at an age on a par with men have come in childless. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Ros Kelly) is the exception: she had children after she became a member. A profile of the women in parliament will also show that very few of them came in here without having subsequently pursued a professional career of some kind.

The thing that irks me, despite my being a non-traditional woman, and irks those women who are, is that the political parties pay absolutely no regard to the abilities that are demonstrated by the woman who is the full-time homemaker, rearing children and keeping house. This is indeed the real struggle. Such women are not regarded as professional people by their political parties. Their backgrounds are considered to be irrelevant in terms of a recommendation for service in the nation's parliament. That is the issue that the parties must address, whether through quotas—in the Labor Party's case—or through the leader's support, in the Liberal Party's case. It is an issue, furthermore, that society must also address.

The really sad thing about this child-care funding change is that it has only taken the step of recognising that caring for children is important in our community. If a decision to work means that children must be put into paid child care, then it certainly should be recognised that that expense is a necessary part of that parent's going to work and it is recognised through the child-care cash rebate. However, what it still has not recognised is that child care by a parent, usually the mother, is as valuable to society. Until that is done, then none of us women, whatever our background—whether professional women, childless, or whatever—has made real pro

SPEECH.PARA: gress. That must be recognised. That is the bottom line.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, what women were reacting against, starting in the 1960s and through into the 1970s, was being shoved into a mould where a woman was not considered normal if she did not marry and have children, and then stay home and look after them full time. We pushed for the right of choice and we said that, in the case of certain families, the option of the second parent—the mother—going to work could be better for a family, and that each family had the right of choice. What I have objected to here today is the financial penalty when the family decides that the better decision is for the second parent—usually the mother—to stay at home and look after the children, but does not then have the equivalent financial support.

This principle was established some time ago. Back in 1977 or 1978, the Fraser government abolished the child endowment payment which went to the mother, and replaced it with the family allowance, a very much upgraded and higher income for the mother. At the same time, it abolished the dependent child rebate. The rationale was perfect: the dependent child rebate had been paid to the parent who did not have prime responsibility for the rearing of the family's children; it went to the taxpayer, the father. Abolishing it, and moving it across to the family's child rearer—cashing it out, as it were—to supersede the child endowment payment meant that the parent who was doing the child caring and rearing got the benefit of that rebate thereafter.

This bill, of course, cashes out the dependent spouse rebate with the same rationale. I have no difficulty with that rationale. The rationale is the same. But in the previous process—of cashing out the dependent child rebate—a couple of important things happened, and they were stated at the time.

Firstly, the big winners were those on low incomes because the actual amount paid to them was not linked to income. It was the same for all families. People were not rebated according to their rate of taxation; they were rebated a set amount. So there was some financial equity there. The benefit paid did not depend on the amount of income earned.

The second point of equity was that the family allowance recognised the economic contribution to this nation of child rearing. In those days, children were looked after much more in the home than through the child care arrangements that we have these days.

These are very important principles. They are principles that were broken by the Hawke government when it means tested the family allowance. I objected to that means testing at the time, as did the opposition. Family allowance thus became the only benefit—other than Austudy—that was means tested according to the income of somebody other than the person receiving the benefit. It was an offensive principle. The wife's payment—the mother's payment—was means tested according to the husband's income. As I said, the only other case where that happens is Austudy, which necessarily incorporates principles of dependency. The Fraser government's family allowance never incorporated principles of dependency. It was a principle of contribution. It acknowledged the principle of doing something worthwhile—child rearing—being recognised through the government revenue system. The Labor government means tested it, however.

I ask all honourable members in this parliament, particularly the female members: how would they feel if their salary was set according to what their husband's salary was? How would the men here feel if their salaries were set according to what their wives' salaries might be outside parliament? It is not a principle any one of us accepts as individuals. We all expect to receive remuneration according to the job we are doing and by an objective measure, and that is what the family allowance used to be.

However, Labor means tested it and decided that, because some women had husbands of an income of a certain level, those women's contribution in the full-time mothering role was to no longer be recognised, or was to receive less recognition. That is utterly obnoxious on principle. Family allowance was never a welfare payment under a Liberal government. I repeat that it was a cashing out of the dependent child rebate, a transfer of child endowment into what was at the time stated, in words of one syllable, as a recognition of the value of the child-rearing role.

Of course, if a parent wanted to then put the children into child care—the family allowance was not paid only to people who were full-time parents—and use that money to pay for child care, that was their choice. And that was the correct principle. All speeches by Liberal, Labor and National party parliamentarians at the time recognised and supported that principle. It was the Hawke government that moved away from it and got us into this real muddle of principles that we have at the moment.

The family allowance has gone. It is now the family assistance supplement, which is means tested, and goes only to families in need. I have no problem with special payments to families in need. The Fraser government brought in the family income support payment, which was additional to family allowances, to assist low income families. That payment was also put into the family assistance supplement. We no longer have the family allowance. We no longer have a recognition that child rearing benefits everyone, and should be supported by this community. That recognition has gone under Labor. Instead we have a child-care rebate, which we support, and the cashing out of yet another rebate—the dependent spouse rebate—for the home child-care allowance, which is not good enough. Whilst I take no objection to government members, men or women, saying nice things about the child-care cash rebate—we support it and it should be supported—it is incumbent on members of the government, particularly women members, to go back to the government and ask, `Are we fair dinkum about the importance of child care? Why is it so much more important when someone other than a parent does it? Why is it that we will give this sort of recognition to someone who is paid to do it as a job, yet we give such puny recognition to a parent who does it? Is child care of value or is it not? If it is of value, why is it financially downgraded when it is done—usually—by the mother?' Let us face it, 90 per cent of the time the value of what we do in our community is measured in money. The contribution we are making for the work we do is measured by the financial return we get.

I repeat: a parent who stays at home to look after the children and who gets an income—not necessarily earns it—from, say, shares or a savings account starts to be financially penalised when that income exceeds 78c per day. Either the job they are doing is of value and is therefore financially recognised, without a means test, or it is of no value. The child-care rebate to parents who work outside the home is not means tested. I would certainly support neither of the payments being means tested.

As I said at the beginning, the coalition supports the bill because it approves of what is happening in the area of rehabilitation in terms of proper financial administration and recoupment of government expenses, and approves of the child-care rebate. However, we differ on some very significant points which go to the principle and the detail of the government's child-care provisions—not least how they reflect on the real status of women in Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate and to support the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I am also pleased to have the opportunity to follow the comments made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), some of which I agreed with, some of which I will disagree with. I will reiterate the main points in this legislation and then turn to some specific parts of it and respond to some of the comments that were made by the honourable member for Moncrieff.

PARA.TAB: The legislation will amend two or three acts. Firstly, it will amend the Disability Services Act 1986 where it talks about recovery of costs of rehabilitation programs provided by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. The amendment to section 23 of the act will cover the capacity of the Commonwealth to recover compensation. The amendment to section 26 of the act relates to a client's right to have a decision reviewed by the secretary and to the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

An amendment to section 23(5) brings this legislation into line with what has been common practice in the government for many years. It has been the practice to serve notices in relation to the recovery of rehabilitation costs on insurers prior to the settlement of the litigation between the insurer and the insured person on the basis that the insurer is the person liable to pay compensation referred to in the act. It is accepted that no payment would be received until the court case has been settled.

Legal advice indicates that, under section 23(5) of the act, notices should not be served until it has been determined by a court or by agreement between the parties that the insurer is liable to pay compensation. The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted in the formulation of this amendment. Its advice supports the need for this legislative amendment. A number of other amendments are outlined in this amendment bill to the Disability Services Act that achieve tidying up changes and bring the legislation into line with the accepted practice.

The other major section of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill relates to administrative changes to the financial provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, which enables the Health Insurance Commission to be involved in the payment of the child-care cash rebate system. These amendments are complementary to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, which introduced this new payment. It is within this context that I would like to make most of my comments this afternoon.

Firstly, I will respond to some of the points made by the honourable member for Moncrieff. Once more, she has been guilty in her comments of only selectively outlining some of the provisions of the Commonwealth in support of families. She has indicated that she feels there is a yawning discrepancy between what we are paying in the home child-care allowance, which is a $30 per week payment, to the spouse remaining at home for the care of children and what we will be paying in the child-care cash rebate system, which is up to a maximum of $61. She claims that this shows a huge discrepancy and discrimination against those families where one spouse remains at home and cares for the family.

However, the honourable member failed to talk about all the other components of the government's comprehensive program of support for families. There is a great discrepancy in her argument because she failed to talk about what we provide to families in recognition of the important role played by the spouses who remain at home and care for children.

The government recognises the important contribution to society and to the economy of the unpaid work undertaken by those people who remain at home caring for children. It is recognised that in the vast majority of cases those people are mothers. The government also acknowledges that the skills of women with work force experience are also extremely valuable in an economy dependent upon the training and flexibility of the work force. So it is a question of getting the correct balance between the two competing needs within our economy.

In properly assessing the impact of Commonwealth assistance for families, it is important to consider all of the allowances that we provide to families. The honourable member for Moncrieff talked about the home child-care allowance. What she has outlined is correct: it replaces and increases the dependent spouse rebate for families where one parent is caring for the children. Instead of the previous tax rebate being a tax concession that goes to the working partner, the taxpayer, we have now changed it to being a weekly payment to the carer of the child or children in the home. It will assist those families whose tax liability was previously too low to get the full value of the dependent spouse rebate.

The home child-care allowance and the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate, which we are ensuring is implemented through this amendment today, will assist families with children, whatever their employment status. They respond to work force participation patterns, which suggest that today most women will spend some time in the paid work force and some time at home caring for their children. The child-care cash rebate will be of great assistance to many women seeking to re-enter the work force through retraining or education. The home child-care allowance will be claimed by women leaving the paid work force to have children.

Since 1983 the government has substantially improved assistance to low income families with children, including single income families. For example, between 1983 and 1993 additional family payments for children in low income families increased in real terms by 75 per cent for a child under 13 years and 147 per cent for a child aged between 13 and 15. Rent assistance has also been extended to low income working families. In particular, these payments go to those families where there is a single income. They are very much a direct cash contribution and cash support to those families where one member of the partnership has remained at home to care for children. This support is paid to families with incomes under $60,000, with greater assistance targeted to lower income families with incomes less than $25,000.

All family payments are now indexed automatically to account for changes in the cost of living. A large number of families receiving the additional family payment are single income couples. Many of these have previously been on higher incomes. They now receive additional assistance when one partner leaves the paid work force to care for a child and, therefore, has a reduction in income.

Let us examine a family earning $35,000, with both partners working—one earning $20,000 and one earning $15,000—renting privately and caring for one child under 13. If that family had another child and the partner earning $15,000 withdrew from the work force, that family would receive nearly $123 per week in tax-free family payments.

It is quite incorrect for the honourable member for Moncrieff to make out that the only payment that this government makes to those families where one partner withdraws from the work force to remain at home caring for children is the $30 a week home child-care allowance. A much larger amount of money is paid through the family payment system. In addition to that $30 a week home child-care allowance, these families would qualify for $123 in family payment, making a total of $153 per week, tax free, in child related assistance.

The home child-care allowance is expected to assist 840,000 families, at a total cost of $1.13 billion, which is $230 million more than we currently pay through the dependent spouse rebate. That is an additional $230 million a year that the Commonwealth will be providing to support those families where one partner remains at home to care for children. About 55,000 families who were not eligible to receive the dependent spouse rebate will now be eligible to receive the $60 per fortnight payment of the home child-care allowance.

The home child-care allowance is also much more responsive to families whose circumstances change during the year, since it is based on current income rather than on income in the previous financial year, which was the way in which the dependent spouse rebate worked. This flexibility is expected to assist up to 120,000 families whose circumstances change within any given year.

When combined with the home child-care allowance, family payments make up a comprehensive package of support for families with children. The government will continue to provide access to child care for parents out of the paid work force for respite and occasional care. In addition, the government has increased child-care assistance, formerly known as fee relief, for occasional care. These forms of care are an essential service for women caring for children, as they allow them time to go shopping, to involve themselves in community organisations, or to attend to important family commitments.

The government will also provide an additional $1.5 million over the next three years to support the establishment of some 3,000 new playgroups, which will benefit an additional 50,000 families—all of those being families where one partner remains at home to care for children. Some single income families will also be eligible to receive this new child-care cash rebate from 1 July in circumstances where dependent spouses are paying for child care to enable them to study, train or look for work.

In her comments this afternoon, the honourable member for Moncrieff claimed that the government is restricting choice for women and that we are discriminating—she used that term and a lot of other emotive language to describe our actions in introducing the home child-care allowance and the child-care cash rebate—in favour of those families where both partners work, and that we are discriminating against those families where one person remains at home to care for children.

She says that, during her formative years in politics when she was actively involved in the women's movement, she sought to assert the right of women to have a choice. That is certainly the position of this government. But we are trying to achieve effective choice where, if people wish to re-enter the work force, we assist them in doing that. We are doing that in a whole range of measures, not just in the support that we provide in our child-care programs.

The honourable member for Moncrieff failed to outline that, all through the 1950s, the 1960s, the 1970s and the early part of the 1980s, it was largely coalition governments that were in power. They had the opportunity to introduce some of these measures and failed to do so. From 1949 to 1983, apart from three years of Labor government, coalition governments were in power. They did not move to introduce any of these alleged new major improvements, as coalition members are now urging the government to do, to support families in the home. That is the direction that we are taking.

The honourable member has some hide coming into this place and attacking the Labor government for the introduction of the programs that we have put in place that support both kinds of families—families where one partner stays at home and those where both partners are at work—when her party, which was in government for 31 out of 34 years, failed to take any such action to support them and has failed to demonstrate any capacity to deliver the types of support for families in the home that she is now urging this government to undertake.

The honourable member for Moncrieff also expressed her strong disagreement with the government's policy of introducing a means test on family payments. She made much of the fact that she believes family payments should go to all families regardless of their income because, by introducing a means test, we are making the carer—the partner who has no formal source of income—answerable to the partner who has a source of income when the carer seeks to get family support payments from the government. She is suggesting that we should not put a means test on family payments.

Family payments are designed to assist families in meeting the additional costs of bearing children and raising them to adulthood. They are designed to bring about some equality between those families which have no children and those that have children, and to assist them with the additional costs of raising children. But, as a government, we have not got an unlimited pool of money and we cannot provide those family payments to every family regardless of their source of income. If we did that, we would have to raise taxation levels, which would impact negatively on low and middle income families and take away a lot of the benefit that we gain from family allowance payments. It is a nonsense to suggest that families that earn $100,000, $200,000 or $300,000 a year in income should be eligible for family allowance payments. Family allowance payments are designed to assist families that do not have sufficient income to meet the needs of raising children.

It is an absolute nonsense for the honourable member for Moncrieff to suggest that we should have no means test whatsoever on family payments. It is a particular nonsense when she has been the one to lead the coalition charge in attacking us because we did not put a means test on the child-care cash rebate. I wish the honourable member would work out exactly what her position is on this matter. When we introduced the child-care cash rebate, she attacked us for not putting a means test on it because it is a much more limited program targeted at a much more restrictive audience. We did not impose a means test on that, but she is now saying that it is wrong for us to impose a means test on family payments. So I do not know what she expects us to do. She attacks a means test in one area and then says that we should have imposed a means test in another area, both concerning family payments and designed to support families in the costs of raising children.

The initiatives outlined by the government in the area of child care have been major. This government has been responsible for significant improvements in offering women a real choice as to whether they wish to remain in the home or enter the work force. I agree with the honourable member for Moncrieff that this community does not give sufficient recognition to the contribution women make in unpaid work in both the home and the community. I believe it is long overdue for us as a community to give much greater recognition to that. The home child-care rebate will go some way towards achieving that.

I certainly support the belief of the honourable member for Moncrieff that, within the preselection processes which parties go through in determining the eligibility of people to stand for election to local, state and federal governments, political parties should give much greater recognition to the unpaid contribution that women make in the home and the community and that unpaid work should be given equal, if not greater, value to that of paid employment when determining the contribution women make in our community and, therefore, determining their eligibility for selection as candidates for the various political parties.

These amendments to the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 that we are discussing today are important. I am pleased that the coalition is supporting the whole of the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—I do not seek to debate anything at this point. I will avail myself of the opportunity later. However, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) attributed an action to me, namely, that I `led the charge' on the means testing of the home child-care allowance. In other words, he said that I was critical of non-means testing of the home child-care allowance. Those words, or words to that effect, have never passed my lips.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to support my colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) today. Any study of Australian families today shows that there has been a significant dramatic difference compared with the families of twenty years ago. Many more women are in the work force. They are either part-time or full-time employees or running their own businesses. Women today are much more orientated towards a career that will take them through their full working lives.

PARA.TAB: Over the past five years, the growth in women's labour force participation has been about 4.5 per cent. Now more than 50 per cent of women with young children are in the work force. More importantly, the future growth of the Australian economy and the living standards of Australians will benefit from women's participation in the labour force. However, most women have different work force patterns from men. They can expect to have periods of their lives where they are out of the paid work force or working part time. Many women also need time to retrain or upgrade their skills because the nature of our work force changes as industrial needs change.

The stress of combining changing patterns of work and family and community responsibility is falling heavily on women. Women are reshaping their lives and the government must respond to their needs. Child care is essential to give women choices as to how they combine work and family responsibilities.

One of the facts to be taken into consideration is that child care is now a common experience for large numbers of Australian children. Some can expect to spend up to 12,000 hours of their early years in paid, formal child care—as much as all the time they spend in primary education. That is why it is absolutely vital that children receive quality care in these important formative years and that parents do not have to worry about how their child is being cared for.

Quality child care is essential for helping parents to remain in or re-enter the work force or to increase their skills through further education. This government believes it has a responsibility to parents to ensure that this quality, affordable child care is available. It is a point of pride that the child-care policy of this government is the most comprehensive and integrated ever adopted in the history of Australia. Its focus is on helping relieve work and family pressures.

In the national child-care strategy we have made a solid commitment to meeting the demand for child-care places by the year 2000. An extra 29,000 new child-care places were funded in 1993-94 and the number of child-care places has quadrupled, from 46,000 in 1983 to almost 200,000 today. A target of 300,000 places has been set, to be reached by 1996-97.

This government's record in building new child-care places is outstanding. It is important that the pace of growth is continued so that women have the confidence that they can find a child-care place when they need it. The government has also introduced a generous fee relief system which now assists two-thirds of families who use Commonwealth child-care centres. It is appropriately targeted to lower income families. We have a needs based planning system to make sure new child-care places go where they are needed most. Over three years $5.3 million dollars is being allocated to support an industry based national accreditation scheme for child-care centres. When this is fully operational, extra funding will be available for training and resource centres participating in the scheme. There are also initiatives which encourage employers to assist with the child-care needs of working families. The government already provides child-care assistance to almost 10,000 employer sponsored child places and existing tax benefits have encouraged the provision of many more.

Research shows that children are likely to be sick as often as nine or 10 times a year, with the period of illness usually ranging from three days to a week or more. This load falls particularly on working mothers. The provision of child care for employers supports demonstrable productivity benefits, including the reduction of absenteeism and the retention of skilled staff. Employers are thus the major beneficiaries of child care.

This government has also expanded services for children with special needs, whether they are from non-English speaking backgrounds or with disabilities or simply live in remote or isolated areas. The family day care system has been expanded with new centres set up and existing establishments expanded. Family day care is a wonderful choice for those parents who want flexibility to arrange hours of care which best suit their individual needs. The secure, home-like environment is ideal for babies and young children.

The children's services program has also identified the need for out of school hours care to meet the growing need for child care among school aged children. Quality outside school care enables parents with school aged children to remain in or re-enter the work force to increase their skills through further education. An innovative new neighbourhood occasional care concept has also been introduced. This will provide parents who look after their children at home with more opportunities to take a break to attend appointments, such as visiting a doctor.

In my own electorate hundreds of working families have benefited from this range of excellent programs. Our government also recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for women earning an income. That is why the child-care cash rebate is a great initiative. It will help families with the cost of child care associated with employment, training, education or job search. A feature of this support is that it is not income tested and will provide up to $61.20 per week for two or more children. Unlike a tax concession, the cash rebate is claimed as the cost is incurred, rather than up to 18 months later. That is why it is a fundamentally fairer system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Paterson will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. How does the minister reconcile the maintenance of Australia's high air safety record with the fact there were no regulations covering the charter flight of the DC3 routed to Norfolk Island and which ditched in Botany Bay on 24 April 1994? Will he acknowledge that the lack of air safety regulations covering this flight contributed to the crash and that it was only the fortunate proximity of private fishing vessels that rescued the 26 passengers and the skill of the pilot which avoided what could have been the worst air disaster in Australia's history? What action has the minister taken to review the regulations relating to air charter flights to ensure that no such event can happen again?

—The honourable member has asked this question of someone who has had to live all his life under the flight paths of the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and in the shadow of air disaster. My most vivid memories are of attending the scene of a DC3 which crashed into the lakes system at the Lakes Golf Club when I was a small boy. I was one of the first people present at the scene of that accident. As a state member of parliament, immediately after the crash of the King Air aircraft in 1980 I stood and witnessed the most horrific carnage that I have ever experienced. I had never seen disaster on such a scale. I have had this job as Minister for Transport now for four months, and I will tell honourable members this: no-one will put more energy into guaranteeing the high standards of aviation safety in this country than I.

PARA.TAB: In terms of major air transport, Australia has an enviable safety record—indeed, it is the envy of the whole of the rest of the world; no-one does better—and the opposition should acknowledge that. But, whilst our performance with major aircraft safety is better than world best, our performance in charter operations and general aviation is no better than the rest of the world. That is something that should concern all of us, and I know it certainly concerns the honourable member for Hume who spoke in this parliament only yesterday on the issue of the Monarch Air disaster.

I was appalled to learn that it is alleged—we have to await the outcome of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report before this is through—that because a plane was 50 years old it could undertake a seven-hour journey across the Tasman Sea which would not have been allowed had that aircraft been built after 1963. If that is the case, then clearly the regulations are defective.

Unlike the opposition, I will not be prejudging that issue. The fact is that we have had a series of accidents. There was one on the weekend which I think anyone watching television would have been horrified by. The scene reminiscent of the great Waldo Pepper involving a couple of people being incinerated in a light aircraft I know shocked and appalled everyone who saw it.

I have spoken to the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority. I put to the House that we in Australia are very fortunate to have had as the leader of the Civil Aviation Authority since last year General Peter Gration. No-one has served Australia better and no-one is more capable of giving leadership in respect of the Civil Aviation Authority and the very important work that it must pursue. I have spoken to General Gration in respect of these incidents and, indeed, in respect of the action that must be taken, and must be taken immediately, after the interim report of BASI into the Monarch Air disaster is available. I expect that report to come to me within the next 24 hours.

It was in anticipation of that and following upon the 25 passengers landing in the water in Botany Bay that I personally contacted General Gration. I have his assurance that he will do everything in these areas necessary to guarantee the highest standards. I trust him and I trust the task that he undoubtedly will complete.

Any recommendations in respect of the Monarch disaster, each and every one of them, will receive every bit of my energy and every bit of my attention. I know that it was a disaster that tore apart a community and destroyed seven lives. Three of those people were school children.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about the regulations?

—I have done a lot about the regulations. I got hold of the chairman only this morning. Only this morning the chairman assured me that this would receive his urgent attention. I repeat: we will pay the closest attention to each and every one of the recommendations from BASI. I will personally not rest until such time as I am assured that each one of them has been properly and comprehensively addressed. We must improve our standards in respect of general aviation and charter aviation and I will certainly be doing everything I can to achieve that outcome.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Has the Attorney-General seen reports of comments by the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, criticising both the federal government and the Australian Securities Commission for failing to effectively police corporate law in Western Australia? Could the Attorney-General advise the House what the government has done to improve the system of corporate regulation in Western Australia and Australia generally?
—They are probably coming around to you with a brown paper bag.
—Order! The member for O'Connor has not been asked to comment.

—I had the good fortune last week to spend a number of days in Western Australia. Indeed, the honourable member for Perth was able to accompany me at a number of functions I was able to attend. I can say that the views expressed to me by the business community of Perth certainly do not coincide with that being expressed by the Western Australian Premier in terms of the acceptance and support of the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that Western Australia joined the national corporations scheme of all the Australian jurisdictions I suppose with most reluctance and with most concern as to how the ASC would operate. I am pleased to be able to say that in the almost three years since the ASC has been an active operation in Western Australia it has built up a great deal of confidence in the local business community. The regional commissioner there, Murray Allen, I think has a good reputation amongst the local business community. That initial point should be made: the ASC is held in high regard among the users of the organisation.

In terms of the allegation that not enough has been done to prosecute outstanding offences flowing from the excesses of the 1980s, again the facts do not coincide with what the Premier's allegations are. Since 1 July 1991, in Western Australia alone there have been 13 successful prosecutions in major criminal matters. Some 19 major civil actions are currently before the court. There have been some 41 prosecutions of major criminal matters and three prosecutions of major civil actions. Obviously, this does not include far more numerous more minor matters.

Clearly, some investigations are still under way involving activities in Western Australia. We await with interest the outcome of those investigations. The reality of the situation in the west indicates that the ASC is operating effectively. It is well respected by the business community there. Premier Court's utterances can be dismissed for what they are—the simple rantings of someone who goes on with state rights rhetoric on any issue. He just pulls out the next page. It does not matter what the heading is; he just goes on with exactly the same line. It is not supported by the users of the organisation in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and follows on from the answer he has just given to the honourable member for Fadden. Why has no action been taken, 11 months after the crash of a Monarch Air aircraft in Young last year, to bring to account those Civil Aviation Authority senior managers who defied the obvious and allowed Monarch to continue to fly so that seven people were killed on 11 June last year on a Monarch aircraft that had had the autopilot removed and several instruments rendered inoperative that were vital to the safe operation of the aircraft, particularly when, on two separate occasions, airworthiness inspectors within the Civil Aviation Authority had recommended that Monarch be grounded and, in particular, after the managing director of the airline had admitted to fraudulently altering the registration of an aircraft to make it suitable for regular public transport?
—Why indeed? Ten months later, and no action.

—It is absolutely untrue to say that there has been no action by the CAA. A great deal of work has been done by the Civil Aviation Authority and the BASI investigators during the months that have elapsed since that accident last year. I know the emotion of the honourable member and I know the relationship that he has with his constituents in that close-knit community. He is not the only person in this House who had personal friendships with people who died on that occasion. My wife lost two friends in the process.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Authority is well advanced in a range of reforms that resulted from the report of the Terrell inquiry into air safety and the CAA's management of air safety which was brought down last year. Of the 58 recommendations of the Terrell inquiry, 38 have now been adopted and put in place. As late as the last 24 hours, I have received an assurance from the Civil Aviation Authority that it is proceeding with absolute haste to guarantee that the remaining 20 recommendations—bringing it to 58, that is the total number of recommendations—are implemented by the end of June this year.

For the honourable member to say that there has been a tardiness on the part of the Civil Aviation Authority, I think is incorrect. To suggest, as he has, or to go further than to suggest, to declare the guilt of officers of the Civil Aviation Authority, as he did in the House last night and as he has repeated today, I think is also premature. For my part, I will await the BASI report that I will receive within the next 24 to 48 hours. Immediately I have it, I will make it available to the honourable member for him to study. I think that is entirely appropriate. I will also await the outcome of the coronial inquiry, which will be conducted later on this year. I have assured him and the House, and I repeat that assurance, that not a stone will be left unturned in pursuing every one of the recommendations necessary to guarantee high standards of aviation safety in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon Mr Jack H. Watson Jr, the personal representative of the President of the United States of America for Australian-American Friendship Week. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It is four weeks since the federal government's new industrial relations laws came into force. Can the minister inform the House of the progress made in workplace bargaining under the federal industrial relations system?

—I thank the honourable member for Reid for his question and for giving me the opportunity of informing the House that more than one million Australians working under federal awards are now covered by workplace agreements under the Federal Industrial Relations Act—one million Australian workers. That represents 2,000 workplace agreements finalised before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and all of them finalised since October 1991. Indeed, this year the rate has picked up and half of those 2,000 agreements have been registered in the last 12 months. All told, federal agreement making now covers 45 per cent of all workers under the federal award system.

PARA.TAB: The spread of enterprise agreement making in the federal system leaves the performance of the state systems absolutely for dead. Let me indicate to the House just how well we have performed in comparison with the states. In New South Wales all they have managed is 579 agreements covering 43,000 workers, that is, 11 per cent of all of the New South Wales workers covered under state awards. This is the much vaunted New South Wales system. We have achieved 45 per cent penetration; they are back at 11 per cent. Indeed, all of the independent studies of the quality of agreement making indicate that, by and large, federal agreements are the higher quality, high productivity outcomes as well. In Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the honourable member will be interested—there are only a miserable 113 agreements covering 20,000 employees.

PARA.TAB: It is even worse in poor old Tasmania, with 47 state agreements covering 744 employees. Yet we continue to hear from the states how well they are going and how poorly they regard the federal system. The fact is that the federal system under the existing legislation saw us run rings around them all. Of course that was before the amendments that have come into effect in the last month.

At the moment, 90 per cent of all businesses with 500 or more employees in the federal system now have workplace agreements. But we are interested in picking up the rest. We are particularly interested in looking at the non-union or lightly unionised sector. That was one of the principal purposes of the Industrial Relations Reform Act. Already in its first four weeks of operation we have seen the first agreements put forward. Indeed, we have seen agreements registered without union involvement in terms of the arrangements that prevailed up until this year.

Until now, workplaces in Australia did not have the opportunities that they should have had to negotiate these flexible agreements. The new act allows that to happen while at the same time reinforcing the award safety net for those people fortunate enough to move into the enterprise bargaining stream. This revolution in the federal workplace—a revolution that will continue as a result of this year's act—has been achieved at a time when the opposition has contributed nothing except a long debate about whether Jobsback should be dumped along with Fightback and the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of a budget speech draft outline being circulated in Parliament House along with a minute paper headed `1994-95 budget speech—draft speech modules', issued under the name of Mick Shadwick, Assistant Secretary budget policy branch? Is the minister aware that the `Budget speech—draft outline (major themes)' deals with the items under the headings `economic context', `budget strategy', `policy settings' and `economic prospects'? In view of the requirement for absolute confidentiality of budget documents, will the minister urgently request the Treasurer to come before the House to explain whether the document is genuine; and, if it is, why it was released?
—I am not actually aware of the document to which the honourable member refers.
—Here is the document, minister.

—If such a document were circulating so far in advance, no doubt she would be very pleased. The last time she commented on bureaucratic matters was to suggest that when the then Treasurer, and now Prime Minister, took decisions on floating the Australian dollar he should have actually gone through a very lengthy process of consultation before he did so, while in the course of that the money markets no doubt went spare. One thing that I will be absolutely certain about in this place is that we will not be taking advice from the honourable member for Mackellar on processing propriety as far as financial matters are concerned.
—I call the honourable member for Moreton.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave—
—The honourable member for Moreton has the call. Resume your seat.
—Minister—
—Resume your seat. The honourable member for Moreton has the call.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have been thoroughly misrepresented by the Minister for Finance.
—There is no point of order.
—Furthermore, I seek leave to table the document.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat. The honourable member for Moreton has the call.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of claims—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!

—Is the minister aware of claims that the government has achieved little in tackling poverty in Australia? What does the government see as the role of the social security system in poverty alleviation?

—I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question. This is an area where misconceptions abound and I have to say that some of the comments that have been made publicly by a number of people have been highly misleading and inaccurate. A recent article by Ross Gittins in this week's Sydney Morning Herald is an honourable exception.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the safety net that we provide through the social security system is the key instrument for poverty avoidance and alleviation in this country. Our system has been reformed and improved over the course of the 1980s and the 1990s. We now have a system which has been carefully studied and found to be highly effective and efficient at its poverty alleviation and avoidance objective, to the point that around 90 per cent in net terms of payments made through the social security system goes to people who would otherwise be in poverty.

This sharpening up of the targeting is a very major achievement of this government and is a crucial element in our efforts to keep fiscal policy in reasonable shape. The United States government, for example, is having to have a very close look at entitlement programs, including a substantial level of payments going to people on middle to high incomes, from the point of view of curtailing its own deficit in the next few years. I think we have achieved something major here.
In the course of doing that, we have been able to significantly improve the situation of those on low incomes, particularly the poorest in our society. Improvements have been made against—
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might just wait for a moment. Those on my right might respect the minister who is on his feet and giving an answer to a question asked by one of their side.

—The evidence is that major improvements have been made over the course of the last decade. For example, very substantial improvements in family payments and rental assistance have meant that payments to an unemployed couple with two dependent children under the age of 13 have doubled in real terms over that period. A sole parent with two dependent children renting privately at the beginning of this government's term of office was nine per cent below the poverty line. That person would now be four per cent above the poverty line. A single pensioner renting privately is now 15 per cent above the poverty line. Pensioners who own their own home are 49 per cent above the poverty line. A pensioner couple who own their own home are 62 per cent above the poverty line. In all these areas, there have been marked and major improvements against the Henderson poverty line, which itself has increased by 16 per cent over that period. So the increase in absolute terms is even more substantial against the increase in the Henderson poverty line.

PARA.TAB: This is an enormous achievement. In addition to those payment improvements, the measures we have taken to extend occupational superannuation and to have a more effective child support scheme have meant that many of our clients are receiving substantial sources of income over and above the social security payments that they receive.

The area we tried to address in the last budget, which is the remaining area of concern, is single people on unemployment payments. At the time we came into office, they were 36 per cent below the poverty line. I regret to say that they are still somewhat below the poverty line, but we have made a huge improvement in that time. In last year's budget, we prioritised them by making a real increase over and above the inflation rate.

So, across the board, I think our achievements in this area are real and substantial. The claims by some that they are not are clearly false. Once again, I refer honourable members to the excellent article by Ross Gittins in this week's Sydney Morning Herald which documents and tabulates them very clearly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice inform the House whether or not the Australian Federal Police is inquiring into allegations of the misappropriation of substantial funds by Palencia Pty Ltd from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and ATSIC under the training for Aboriginals program? If so, can the minister inform the House of the progress of that inquiry? Has the minister informed the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of that inquiry?

—I can advise that I have been told an investigation is proceeding. But, of course, all operational matters are not ever disclosed in this House, and that practice has been universally applied. In relation to those further matters, I can make no further comment.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen reports of statements calling for a huge increase in the amount of Australia's foreign aid? If so, is this consistent with other public statements calling for spending cuts in the present economic situation? What is the government's intention in the matter?

—It is a feature of Australian political debate at the moment, particularly since opposition members junked their Fightback document with a cheerful air—a plethora of them threatened to resign if it was not implemented in detail and to the letter, and another plethora of them said that it represented their profoundest convictions about the future needs of Australia—that all discipline seems to have been lost on the part of the opposition. On the one hand, the opposition spokesman on the Treasury is absolutely demanding massive cuts in public outlays. On the other hand, in just about any conceivable area of government policy one would care to think of, as a problem arises, a suggestion is made that more resources ought to be devoted to it.

PARA.TAB: The most recent example of that is the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong, who called on the Prime Minister to intervene in the budget process to have Australia's overseas aid budget increased. In the last election he ran on a policy of reducing by $200 million over the next two years the amount devoted to Australia's foreign aid. He is one of those who appear to have been liberated so that one side of the opposition can perambulate about the place talking about the need for budget discipline and another section of the opposition can stand up and perorate on the need for more expenditure in particular areas.

As it happens, of course, the public generally, and members of this House, will know what the government intends to devote to the area of foreign aid when the budget is announced, but I think it is worth pointing out these facts. Australia has a better record, in terms of the percentage of our GDP assigned to foreign aid, than the United Kingdom, Portugal, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Austria, Spain, New Zealand, the United States and Ireland. It is in pretty good company, looking through the bulk of those nations. There is a very substantial number of respectable countries among them, including some who are noted for a degree of generosity in the area of foreign aid, such as the United States and Japan; and the United Kingdom has not been regarded over time as niggardly.

I might point out one or two other things about these nations. We have about 38 per cent of our GDP in the public sector. All of those nations which have a better performance in percentage GDP terms in foreign aid than Australia have much higher percentages of their GDP in the public sector. They include the Scandinavian countries. They do come up with very good figures on foreign aid—such as 0.7, 0.8 and one per cent of GDP—but, for example, something like 72 per cent of Sweden's GDP is in the public sector. It is obviously in a position where, devoted to government attention each time its budget is considered, there is a very considerable amount more resources available for disbursement for any particular purpose, including foreign aid.

I do not think there is any country with a public sector the size of ours—and there are only about two with a public sector smaller than ours, including the United States and Japan—that does better on foreign aid. So what consideration there is of foreign aid in the budget needs to be contemplated against that background.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Finance. Is it correct that $816 million was allocated under the One Nation statement of February 1992 over a five-year period for the building better cities program and that $798 million of that has been committed under this program? Is it also correct that the majority of this money—in fact, 80 per cent—has already been committed to capital city areas and that regional cities of the size and population of Bendigo and Ballarat throughout Australia have virtually been ignored by the Keating government? Can the minister advise whether the $150 million for the national regional development strategy to be announced by the Prime Minister today at 4 o'clock is a new allocation of funds or is simply the 20 per cent of the original One Nation money being recycled?

—You really will need to wait to see the Prime Minister's statement before you can make a judgment about that. I am obviously not going to get up in this question time and deal with matters that are contained in the white paper.

PARA.TAB: I will go to the basis of your question on the better cities package that has been put in place to this point. The sorts of figures that you are talking about sound, off the top of my head, roughly of the appropriate dimensions. It has to be said that those propositions in the better cities program are basically aimed at ensuring that we optimise the use of public utilities to ensure that our cities, which have a very substantial tendency to spread expansively, have that process somewhat corrected. It is natural, in those circumstances, that where there are the greatest centres of population there is likely to be a strong tendency in the program to recognise them. I would have thought that the sorts of figures that the honourable member referred to, which were figures related to where the bulk of the Australian population lies, would be the sorts of areas that would be likely to pick up programs.

I might say that all those programs are put in place on the basis of consultation with state governments and most of them reflect the priorities that state governments put forward themselves. If the honourable member has a complaint about that in relation to his area, perhaps he should have a chat with Jeff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the minister whether he can inform the House as to the progress of reform in the Australian construction industry and the extent to which a report released yesterday in Victoria contributes to the reform process.
—Good, and thanks to the honourable member for Corio because—
—Good, and thanks!

—I beg your pardon? I started by saying that I wanted to thank the honourable member for Corio for bringing that report to my attention. It is a report of the Victorian parliament. I understand that he has an interest in the construction industry and has been following that report. We now have a report which contributes nothing to reform in the construction industry.

PARA.TAB: I think that is a sad thing, because the Victorian parliament's own report into the construction industry flies in the face of the Victorian government's cooperation with the Commonwealth government over reform of the construction industry. That is the most disappointing aspect. So under the Commonwealth process—where we have the Construction Industry Development Agency—the Victorian government, along with other conservative governments, has seen the light and the need for cooperation in order to improve the construction industry. But not so the conservative elements of the Victorian parliament. That is the most objectionable part of the report that was handed down yesterday and, as I say, brought to my attention by the honourable member for Corio.

One of the so-called important conclusions of the Victorian report is `the Victorian building and construction industry is critically divided on what the basic productivity objectives are and how to achieve such objectives.' That ignores the fact that there are dozens of enterprise agreements in the construction industry which themselves define productivity and which themselves have produced greater productivity in the construction industry. So the report is outdated and does not understand the sorts of processes that are taking place now between construction agents and the building unions.

It also flies in the face of real live facts like the fact that, as a result of reforms in the construction industry, the Great Southern Stand at the MCG—as I have mentioned here before and which was a $130 million project—was built four months ahead of schedule. So the Victorian parliament, or at least the conservatives in it, are unaware that their own Great Southern Stand was built four months ahead of schedule.

They appear to be unaware that, in the years between 1989 and 1992—for which we have figures—on the aspect of industrial disputes, for instance, an average of 38 days were lost on projects started in 1989 compared with 17.1 days lost for projects commenced in 1992. In a recent survey of 50 projects in the construction industry, 85 per cent of those projects met or bettered their cost targets. So here it is: the conservative elements of the Victorian parliament are at loggerheads with their own Victorian government, which has cooperated in our process in the reform of the construction industry, and have ignored the very practical processes of reform in that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to an article appearing on page 3 of today's Australian newspaper outlining a Queensland CJC investigation into allegations that a `senior ALP identity' is alleged to have been provided thousands of dollars worth of sex from prostitutes, paid for by a man with New South Wales underworld connections, over a two-year period. Having, along with many of my past colleagues, suffered under trial by innuendo and, since the corridors of this place's inside players have been all morning naming a certain person, that person is owed, in my opinion, a speedy and public denial by yourself. If, on the other hand, these allegations constitute, as they appear to do, a prima facie case of corruption at the highest levels, can the Attorney-General advise what were the quid pro quos for such generous, non-taxed fringe benefits? Further, if such is the case, can the Attorney-General assure the House that Mr X will be brought to judgment and given a fair trial—I might add, a courtesy he never extended to thousands of ordinary, working-class north Queenslanders? Will the Attorney-General confirm or deny that the senior ALP person referred to in the Australian article was the ALP's most powerful figure for over a decade, ex-Senator Graham Frederick Richardson?
—The Attorney-General might take some care in responding to the particular question that has been outlined so that it conforms to our standing orders.

—Thank you for that guidance, Mr Speaker. I have seen the article in the Australian today. It refers to an investigation by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission. The activities and investigations of the Queensland CJC are not referred to me, the Minister for Justice or the Commonwealth government. They are obviously matters for that particular body.

PARA.TAB: I can give no advice whatsoever as to whether there is an investigation of this type or whether the allegations contained in the article are true or otherwise. I am simply not in such a position. I would, however, express my extreme disappointment in the honourable member and the action that he has now taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not much is honourable about him.

—Yes, I think `honourable' is probably an undeserved term in this situation. In your preamble you announce that people are entitled to certain protections. Such protections, as I understand it, would be provided by the legislation which governs investigations by the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland. If the honourable member were to make a similar statement outside this chamber, I imagine there may be some action there. For the honourable member to come into this chamber and perform in the way he has does no credit to this House and particularly no credit to him.

—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Lilley, I remind honourable members that when the honourable member for Kennedy asked his question, I made some comment to the Attorney-General before he responded. I draw the attention of honourable members to the standing order to which I referred, which is 153, and ask them all to look at that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the minister aware of recent media reports suggesting that veterans entitlements are likely to be adversely affected as a result of recommendations contained in a report on veterans compensation soon to be released? In particular, is the minister aware of assertions by the honourable member for Wide Bay on ABC radio in Queensland to the effect that thousands of service pensioners are about to lose their pensions as a result of this report? Can the minister assure veterans in my electorate, the electorate of Richmond and many other electorates that such statements are irresponsible and untrue? Can the minister advise the House as to when the report of the compensation review committee, chaired by Professor Peter Baume, will be released and when the government's response will be provided?

—I thank the honourable member for Lilley for his question. I am sure that everybody, including honourable members on the other side, will want to listen to this answer because we all have veterans in our electorates. It is true that there have been a number of media reports. It is also true that, as a result of a 1992 Auditor-General's report which was critical of the veterans compensation system, my predecessor, John Faulkner, commissioned an independent review by a committee chaired by Professor Peter Baume and assisted by Air Vice Marshal Richard Bomball AO and Ms Robyn Layton, an Adelaide QC. The committee was asked to consider the Auditor-General's report and the High Court case of Bushell. The committee reported to my predecessor on 18 March 1994.

PARA.TAB: The government has examined the report and will respond in the budget context.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to release the report, to answer the question of the Leader of the National Party, on Monday, 9 May, just prior to the presentation of the budget. Naturally, I cannot disclose the government's response until budget night. But in general terms, I can say that under this government the principle will always remain that the ex-service community is a unique and highly respected section of our society and deserves to be treated in a special way. All Australians owe veterans from all campaigns a huge debt of gratitude—a debt which will be very difficult to repay in the future. Accordingly, this principle has been at the forefront of the government's thinking during budget deliberations and it will be well maintained next Tuesday.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the assertions made on ABC radio in Queensland by the honourable member for Wide Bay, as mentioned by the honourable member for Lilley, and also to an article in his local newspaper headed, `Veterans' pensions may face government threat—Truss'. The honourable member for Wide Bay is not a bad fellow; he is quite a good fellow. But on this occasion he has been a very naughty boy. He is out there scaring an older section of our community by making people think they are going to lose entitlements which they will not lose. I would ask him to be the good fellow that he is and stop doing that. I reject absolutely his prophecies.

Further, irrespective of any recommendations of the Baume committee, I can assure the House that all legitimate claims will continue to be recognised and that no significant changes will be made without consultation with our ex-service community. That has occurred in the past and will occur in the future. In conclusion, I inform the House that any new initiatives arising from the government's response to the Baume report will not result in the reduction of any existing pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the regrettable though now regular absence of the Prime Minister, my question is directed to the Minister for Finance, who I understand is standing in for the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, who usually represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the plight of a young woman, Miss Kellie Wilkinson, from Caloundra in my electorate, and her companions, who were kidnapped at gunpoint about three weeks ago by the Khmer Rouge guerillas in Cambodia, and also to my representations to the Prime Minister on behalf of the Wilkinson family seeking his intervention to secure the immediate release of Miss Wilkinson. Can the minister outline to the House what steps, if any, the Prime Minister and the government have taken or are prepared to take to secure Miss Wilkinson's freedom from this terrorist group at the earliest opportunity?

—I do not have a brief on the material which the honourable member has asked his question on. I will check with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and provide the honourable member with a note on the matter to answer his question.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Does the minister agree that there is a need to reform existing bankruptcy laws and, if so, what are the government's intentions in this area?

—I thank the honourable member for the question. The government is committed to modernising many aspects of the law. Recently three discussion papers proposing reforms to the Bankruptcy Act were published. They were circulated to all interests in the community concerned with bankruptcy matters. A large number of submissions were received from registered trustees, consumer organisations, banks, credit unions and other interested individuals and organisations.

PARA.TAB: The government has analysed all the submissions and proposes to bring forward legislation which will do three things. It will overhaul part X of the act, which provides for negotiation of voluntary insolvency administrations and, in keeping with the government's commitment to improve access to the law, there will be a new form of administration to be known as consumer compositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister is clearly announcing policy. He says that they have had an inquiry. He now wishes to announce the government's intention as regards the legislation.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister has been asked to respond to a specific question, and he is doing so.

—If honourable members had any knowledge whatsoever of this field, they would realise that cabinet made this decision some little while ago and public releases were issued. I am simply responding to a question from a member who is interested—as, clearly, the opposition is not—in making sure we do provide the most efficient and effective means of providing fair processes for those unfortunate enough in our community to find themselves in the position of facing financial difficulty.

PARA.TAB: The new form of consumer composition that we will be introducing in legislation to this House will, for the first time, mean that we have a convenient and more appropriate process for smaller debtors to negotiate alternatives to bankruptcy. The package will also allow trustees to quickly and cheaply recover property disposed of by bankrupts in an attempt to defeat creditors. We have also asked the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia to continue its process of making sure it develops a convenient one-stop service for those who seek its assistance so that they can be facilitated in getting appropriate advice without difficulty or delay.

The elements of that reform package will go a very substantial way to improving the administration of the bankruptcy system. Whilst we occasionally hear crocodile tears from the other side relating to numbers of bankruptcies, we hear very little noise now, given that the numbers are going down. I wish that those opposite would have some concern for getting systems in place which will be of benefit to those who are unfortunate enough to face those difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that the former manager of the Adelaide airport, Mr Lou MacKrall, was dismissed from that position by the Federal Airports Corporation because of his support for the extension of the runway at the Adelaide airport? In light of this, will the minister conduct an inquiry and report to the House on aviation industry claims that the current manager, Mr Mike Lennon, was appointed specifically because of his opposition to the extension of that runway?

—I must admit that I know of no such claims or allegations. If anyone has any evidence of substance to support those allegations, I will most certainly ensure that they are properly and fully investigated. The Adelaide airport issue is one that I have discussed with the Premier of South Australia as late as the last two weeks. I have indicated to him the federal government's support for his plans to see that airport developed at a much earlier than might have been anticipated date.

PARA.TAB: So let the House be under no doubts that the government is not in any way opposed to the aspirations of the Adelaide community, the government of South Australia and any individuals who would seek to see a better, bigger and more effective airport servicing the needs of that state. I can only say to the honourable member for Sturt that, if he has any evidence—but it had better be evidence of substance—he ought to put it forward. But I certainly have not heard any suggestion at all along the lines that he has raised this afternoon until this very moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—I was asked a question earlier on, and a note from the Minister for Foreign Affairs has been handed to me. He says that the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh, together with the British Embassy, has been working closely on this issue with the Cambodian government, which has primary responsibility for achieving the release of Miss Wilkinson and her British companions. The trio has been held by the Khmer Rouge since 11 April 1994. He is satisfied that the Cambodian government is fully committed to gaining the group's safe release. The minister is similarly satisfied that every possible effort has been made by Australian officials in Cambodia to assist both local authorities and members of Miss Wilkinson's family. Both my colleague Senator Bolkus and the secretary to the department of the Minister for Foreign Affairs were recently in Cambodia and discussed with Cambodian ministers and officials our concerns for the safety of the group.

PARA.TAB: It was as a result of representations by the Australian and British ambassadors that King Sihanouk wrote an open letter to the abductors requesting the release of the captives. Cambodian authorities have received a number of unconfirmed reports of sightings of the captives, who have been moved around the Kampot region. These reports indicate that Miss Wilkinson and her companions are unharmed.

Consular officials have been in Sihanoukville, in southern Cambodia, since the abduction and are in close contact with local police and military officials. Two Australian Federal Police officers with previous Cambodian experience are on hand to provide advice to embassy officials.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the member did not even wait for the answer.
—He didn't know he was going to get it. Fair go; that is bloody stupid.
—Order! I did not hear the remark.
—It was bloody stupid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement relating to the white paper on employment, industry and regional development.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This white paper reflects the collective concern of Australians and their collective ambition. Their concern for their fellow Australians, their ambition to make this a good society and a great and successful country. It is a statement about the two imperatives of a decent society—compassion and strength. About the bonds which exist between all Australians—and the premium this country places on the talent and energy of every individual. It is about the desire to extend the safety net and basic services which expand equality of opportunity and go to make a truly civilised society—and the ability to pay for them.

PARA.TAB: This is a white paper for the times we live in: an era of unprecedented change and equally unprecedented national opportunity. It is also an era in which hundreds of thousands of Australians, through no fault of their own, are bearing the burden of that change and are denied their share of opportunity.

Unemployment is without question the greatest problem we face. Unemployment saps the confidence and self-esteem of our fellow Australians—which in turn saps the nation's. It damages the social fabric. It has profound consequences for our social cohesion. As we have seen in other countries, ignored and neglected as a social problem, left to a fate to be decided solely by `market forces', unemployment threatens to create a permanent underclass. It threatens to create the conditions for social decay. We are not alone among nations in this—it is endemic to the Western developed countries. This government for one is determined to deal with the problem.

I said on election night last year that we will not leave the unemployed behind. And I said on Australia Day this year that this recovery must be shared by all of us. The white paper I present to the House today, entitled Working Nation, delivers on those two commitments. But success will not come easily: with this white paper we cannot say that the battle has been won, but we can say that it has been joined, and we sincerely hope not just by the Commonwealth government.

It has to be understood that success here depends upon all Australians joining the effort. That means business and trade unions and communities. It means all tiers of government.
