If we do want to reach the point where we can say that every Australian who wants a job can have one, it will require a conscious and concerted national effort. So we do not say that this white paper will wipe away the problem at a stroke, but we do say that Australia will not leave people neglected and forgotten.

Through this document, Australia says to those who are out of work: we believe you are entitled to the benefits of recovery and a chance to contribute to it. If you do not have the appropriate skills, we will help you get them. If you are young, we will see that you are trained. If you have been a long time out of work, we will offer you employment and training, if that is what you need. It says we will do all we can to help make you ready for a job.

The means of giving concrete expression to our intentions constitute the most profound reform of Australia's labour market and social security provisions since World War II. The new provisions are tailored to meet the needs of the unemployed in the modern Australian economy. They will serve Australia for many years.

The white paper is a statement of policy on employment and growth. It takes the view—the incontestable view—that economic growth is the key to employment growth. The evidence is very plainly there in this recovery—we have already seen 230,000 new jobs created in the past 12 months. That is why a substantial part of the white paper addresses itself to the means by which Australia can achieve higher levels of competitiveness. One of our great goals in these last years of the century must be economic efficiency, and the micro-economic reform and other measures described in this paper are no less important than the training, labour market and social security reforms.

The government believes that Australia can sustain or improve upon the present rate of low inflation growth through to the end of the decade. The period will be characterised by a continuation of the trend towards successful small and medium size enterprises producing sophisticated manufactures for export. It will also see continued growth in sophisticated services.

Australian business and industry will need to be increasingly flexible, innovative and responsive to customer needs. It will need these qualities to succeed in the increasingly competitive markets of the world. As these companies grow, jobs will grow with them. But we know from the experience of the 1980s that very largely these new jobs will go to new entrants to the labour market and not to the long-term unemployed.

As the green paper indicated, even with strong economic growth, without intervention of the kind we have decided to undertake in this white paper, by mid-1998 there would still be some 290,000 people in the pool of long-term unemployed. This is not only profoundly unfair, it is profoundly inefficient. It is a waste of our greatest resource—the talent and energy of our people. Returning the long-term unemployed to the productive process of the nation not only returns them to the income, social interaction and creativity which work provides, it taps their potential for the good of Australia. As the white paper says, when we employ these otherwise wasted human resources we are made stronger.

Large numbers of long-term unemployed people demand large outlays on social security and other assistance. Furthermore, having so many people effectively disqualified from the work force reduces the efficiency of the labour market. In this recovery the complement to skill formation in the labour market is not going to come from migration. This time it has to come from training our own people, including those who are presently unemployed.

The details of the government's policy reforms are spelt out in the second volume of the white paper. The measures I am announcing today will cost $1.7 billion in their first full year. Those who may question the cost of these measures should ask themselves what are the costs of doing nothing. The cost of failing to introduce the major efficiency and equity benefits to the labour market, industry and the regions that this package describes.

It is important to note that we have been able to accomplish these fundamental reforms consistent with our target of a deficit of around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. For the information of honourable members, I will concentrate on only the most substantial of the new measures.

Central to the government's strategy for getting the long-term unemployed back into work is the job compact. The job compact puts new obligations on both the government and those receiving unemployment benefits. The government will provide to those who have been on unemployment benefits for 18 months or more individual case management, training and support and the offer of a job for six to 12 months. Individuals will be expected to take the job or lose their benefits.

We will also introduce measures to identify people at risk of becoming long-term unemployed. Together with those who have been continuously unemployed for 12 months, these people will be given individual case management, including remedial action in such areas as literacy, numeracy, language and vocational training and access to relevant labour market programs. It is expected that over half a million people will receive individual case management each year.

This is a radical program, a qualitative change in the way we approach labour market problems. The objective is to make long-term unemployed people ready for a job, and break forever the pattern in which the long-term unemployed become steadily more dispirited and unqualified for employment, while employers become steadily less inclined to consider them employable. In other words, the purpose of the job compact is principally to see that a substantial proportion of the new jobs in the recovery go to long-term unemployed Australians.

A new training wage will be introduced to provide employers with extra incentives to hire long-term unemployed workers and invest in their training. The training wage encourages employers to provide training places in two ways. The award wage will be discounted for accredited training and the employer will receive a wage subsidy from the government at a level above what it would be if no training were involved. This represents a substantial incentive for employers to play their part in the national effort.

An in-principle agreement on the training wage has been reached with a high level ACTU committee which will be recommending its adoption to the ACTU executive. The government will also be consulting with employers on the details of the training wage. To deliver case management and job placement services, the government will radically change the labour market by engaging community and private sector agencies. Job seekers will have a choice between these and the CES, with the competition between them regulated and encouraged by a new authority—the Employment Service Regulatory Agency, ESRA.

The CES will be revitalised to meet the greater responsibilities placed upon it by the job compact and other initiatives. Additional resources, extra training of staff, external recruitment and improved information technology will be brought to the operations of the service. The emphasis will be on closer relations with employers, greater skills and efficient delivery through more sophisticated technology and coordination. For instance, job boards and job cards in CES offices will be replaced with computerised vacancy systems featuring user-friendly technology to encourage self-help job searches.

As the white paper says, we are never going to return to a world where large numbers of full-time jobs are available for unskilled young workers. As the keys to a successful modern economy are skills, ideas and innovation, the keys to employment are education and training. It cannot be stressed too much—in the modern economy skills are our greatest competitive advantage. Whether it is in global enterprises or local small businesses, it is on the ability of our people to add value that our standard of living depends. It is on skills that every individual's standard of living increasingly depends.

In the past decade, the number of young people completing year 12 or an initial post-school qualification has dramatically increased. However we are still below the average for the OECD and well short of the goal that all Australian governments have set—namely, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds by 2001. The white paper describes the government's program for building the skills of young Australians.

The three principal elements of new government policy are: first, the government aims to encourage young people to stay in education and training by giving them appropriate financial support and more relevant courses run jointly by schools and industry. Second, we will be increasing the number and range of entry level training places for young people—by an estimated 50,000 by 1995-96. And thirdly, we will be introducing as a major policy change a youth training initiative for unemployed young people. The key to success is to provide help at an early stage in the unemployment cycle, which means with the least possible delay after leaving school. The principal features of the youth training initiative are:
intensive case management, with an initial assessment of skills and knowledge, for all unemployed people under the age of eighteen

SPEECH.PARA: a doubling of the number of labour market and vocational training places for young people
assistance in finding a job, and
reformed income support arrangements to help keep young people in education or training.

Under the youth training initiative—in the clearest possible signal that every young Australian should be in education, training or employment—unemployment benefits—or the jobsearch allowance will be replaced by a youth training allowance.

PARA.TAB: Investing in skills of Australians, particularly young Australians, is the best investment we can make. This is recognised well beyond the realms of government. Industry is increasingly recognising it and increasingly indicating its desire to play a part. We are very well aware of industry's concerns about the relevance of current training and for this reason we are anxious to engage industry in both the design and delivery of courses. In future, Australian vocational training will be available through traineeships based in schools, TAFE, industry and labour market programs and will be available to adults as well. A training wage which offers a much simpler alternative to the multiple industry-specific rates currently applying will be available to employers who provide entry-level training.

The social safety net was a term first used in the 1940s by Ben Chifley. He thought of it as the net under a trapeze artist, `to break the fall towards destitution and sustain a man and his family while they help him climb the ladder of opportunity again'. The basic principle of the safety net remains the same—and so does the basic necessity in a decent society to maintain it. But circumstances have changed and so must the way we design the net. The most fundamental difference is that no longer do families depend on the man alone to bring in the income.

In general, the present social security system continues to assume that only one member of a couple, in most cases the husband, will be actively looking for work while the other will be a dependant. This ignores the increase in employment for women. It means that unemployed couples have not been encouraged to take advantage of the opportunities in the labour market. Over the last 10 years, the gap between income support for a married couple and income from lower paid jobs has also narrowed and the incentive to find work has been greatly diminished.

In another basic structural reform of our income support system, young unemployed couples without children will need to qualify for unemployment payments in their own right and the joint income test for unemployed couples will be abolished. The effect of this will be to encourage both partners to seek work. It also means that many low income working families will gain extra income support.

Under the current social security income test, after a modest level of income, for every dollar of income earned, a dollar of income support is lost. From July next year the dollar-for-dollar taper will be replaced with a 70c in the dollar taper which will mean that people will always be better off from working because work will always increase their total income.

In another radical initiative, a parenting allowance will be introduced to provide an independent source of income for parents in low income families who care for dependent children under 16 years of age. The parenting allowance will effectively provide a payment for one parent free of any obligation to seek work.

There will also be a more generous income test for those who wish to combine parenting with paid work. By any measure, this is a major reform. The simplest measure is this—it will mean an extra $59 per week on average for nearly 120,000 low income families. The parenting allowance signals a new approach to income support based on the right of people to be paid as individuals, rather than as dependent partners. In this, and in the fact that it constitutes greater recognition of women's role in the work force and the growth in part-time and casual employment, the parenting allowance is consistent with the changes to income testing.

If we do not take remedial action, the long-term unemployed and many young Australians at risk of joining their ranks will be relegated to the margins of our national life and miss out on the opportunities offered by the present recovery. The same can be said of many of the regions of Australia. The white paper presents a new Commonwealth approach to regional development.

If we are to make the most of all our national resources, including the skills and energy of our people, we need to ensure that the regions of Australia are given the opportunity to flourish—that they become partners in Australia's growth. As the white paper says, to neglect the regions is to neglect not only a great many Australians and all that they have to give this country, but to pass up the opportunity to build a stronger and more diverse economy.

Three reports on regional development have been received by the government in recent times—the Kelty task force report, the McKinsey report and the report of the Industry Commission. The principal lessons to be learned are that the regions, though presently enjoying very different degrees of success, have in common an abundance of energy and commitment.

The government takes the view, with Kelty and McKinsey, that the most effective approach for the Commonwealth is to provide strategic assistance of a kind that will help the regions to make the most of their human and physical resources. More often than not, this will require them to integrate their local economies with the national and international economy.

The white paper instances some remarkable achievements and some other places where major obstacles have yet to be overcome. The uneven performance of our regions in large part flows from an uneven quality of organisation and leadership. The white paper details the way in which the Commonwealth government will support the formation and functioning of regional groupings and provide assistance to regions so that they can develop and implement effective strategic plans, with an emphasis on international best practice.

We will also be significantly modifying the tax treatment of infrastructure bonds and taking other steps to encourage private sector investment in regional Australia. We will also provide funds for capital works where it can be demonstrated that their completion is vital to local economic performance.

The white paper nominates two regional development projects the government will support which may be taken as models for other regions in Australia. The Goulburn Valley and the Sunraysia have developed plans for ecologically sustainable, highly productive, self-funding, irrigated agriculture which will repair the environment and greatly increase the contribution to GDP. The Sunraysia is expected to double output in the next two decades.

The government will provide funding for essential capital works projects and support for restructuring through the rural adjustment scheme. I will be going to the Sunraysia on Friday to see first hand the proposed projects and meet with some of the region's leaders. It should be noted also that reforms to the labour market, education and training and social security contain provisions for programs which will be specifically tailored to regional needs.

In addition, some 60 DEET area consultative committees will be created and they will seek to establish direct links with successful regional development organisations. The consultative committees will include employers, local and state government representatives and education and training providers.

Just as it is essential that we do not allow the long-term unemployed to become cut off from the mainstream of society, it is equally important that we take steps to see that regions of Australia are not left to drift out of the nation's economic and social life. These reforms and initiatives necessarily depend on continuing economic growth. They depend on the ability of Australian enterprise to flourish and carve out a future in the world economy and especially the Asia-Pacific. For that reason the white paper contains a statement of the government's industry policy.

In summary, the thrust of government policy is towards globalisation, competitiveness and productivity. We are seeing major success from measures already taken: a dramatic increase in exports, the rise of dynamic small and medium sized businesses which have been born of the export culture developed in the last decade—`born global' in other words—the growth of manufactured exports to rank now with agriculture and mining as a proportion of GDP and the rapid growth in exports of sophisticated manufactures.

There is no question that our policies, including our tariff policy, are enabling Australia to be a competitive player in the regional and world economy. There is equally no question that we have no choice but to continue the process of reform which alone will keep us in the race.

The white paper contains a broad statement of the principles governing our industry policy and a number of specific measures consistent with those principles. The process of micro-economic reform will continue. A consistent goal of the next few years must be economic efficiency. The principles of best practice, which many Australian companies have adopted, must be adopted by the nation itself. In this, as in all the measures described in this white paper, much depends on other tiers of government, on trade unions, business, communities, the people of Australia themselves. It demands a continuation of the great cultural shift which has occurred in the past decade.

The government sees its proper role as creating a competitive environment for industry and, by strategic intervention, helping to create competitive companies. As the paper says, our policy must be to harness the power of markets, while recognising that, left to themselves, markets will not always give us the best possible results.

There are measures described in this white paper to remove impediments to business efficiency, to facilitate exports, to encourage research and development, to make access to finance for small and medium sized business easier, to remove regulation and lower business costs and, among the latter, the white paper announces the suspension of the training guarantee.

One significant initiative will be the establishment of a body to improve coordination and delivery of government programs for business. The body, to be called Ausindustry, will be within the portfolio of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and will be guided by a board comprising people with experience in all aspects of business, from research and development to international trade. The establishment of Ausindustry is a direct response to two recent studies by McKinsey which found that business was often confused about the range of services available under government programs.

Our success will also depend on the capacity and willingness of Australians to strike productivity bargains in the nation's workplaces. The Industrial Relations Reform Act introduced last year provides the framework for this process to rapidly proceed. Much now depends on the willingness of employers and employees to strike the kinds of bargains which will be mutually rewarding to them, and rewarding also to Australia's economic future.

We have seen in a very short time a sea change, not just in the shape of the Australian economy, not just in its orientation and in the way we do business, but in the way we think about our business practice. We understand both the need for, and the principles of, competitiveness. We understand the need for cooperation in the workplace. We understand the need for skills and creativity. We know that we must be a nation which makes things and sells things in the international markets of the world. We know these things principally because we know that not to do them will mean to fail as a nation. It will mean a lower standard of living for this and for future generations.

The major reforms announced in this white paper should be seen in this context. We do not accept that we can raise the standard of living of Australians by allowing a large number of people to drift permanently out of the system. We do not accept that we can afford to waste their potential. Nor do we accept that the only way to maintain our standard of living is to lower the wages of Australian workers. The white paper is underpinned by the belief that Australia must and can be a high wage and a high productivity country.

A hundred years ago, the Australian colonies federated into a nation which numbered among its watchwords `the social laboratory of the world'. The Australia of a hundred years ago prided itself on advanced social policy. Just 50 years ago, with the white paper on full employment, another Australian Labor government codified and consolidated social policies which together formed the basis of the Australian social welfare system. That was a document of its times—in some essential ways, a much more modest document than this one. This white paper is a document for these times.

These social programs, together with those introduced in recent years, mean that in this decade we should take pride in the fact that, faithful to previous generations of Australians, we have made this one of the most sophisticated social democracies in the world. It would be no bad thing if, in this decade, we also developed pride in the great changes we have made to our economy. We should be proud that we now compete in areas we once thought beyond our capacity. It would be a very good thing if, at the end of the century, we defined ourselves as one of the very fair societies in the world and one of the most creative. That is the philosophy which underlies this white paper. It is a program for employment and growth. It underlies all the policies of this government. I present the following papers:
Working nation—
White Paper on Employment, Industry and Regional Development.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Motion by (Mr Beazley)—by leave—agreed to:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 30 minutes when the debate is resumed.
Debate (on motion by Dr Hewson) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the routine of business for Thursday, 5 May 1994, being as follows, unless otherwise ordered:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1.Notices and orders of the day, government business (to be interrupted at 1.30 p.m. in order that the grievance debate can be called on):

PARA.TAB: (a)if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced, and
(b)the Speaker shall fix the time for the resumption of the debate on any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of the interruption.

PROCTEXT.PARA: 7.Notices and orders of the day, government business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not having been privy to the discussions with the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), in his absence, I rise to say that we accept the proposal put by the government. I know that on other occasions my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong has referred to what we still see as some of the fundamental difficulties in the change of standing orders. Whilst I know that we had a brief debate on this subject yesterday, as one who has experienced different times for questions, I think it is unfortunate that we have chosen to preserve this system of having rostered ministers and having questions without notice at 3 o'clock. I regard it as being too late in the afternoon.

PARA.TAB: The general approach of the government towards the operations of this place, even with the standing orders which it has implemented, was quite apparent today when the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) did not even bother to be present on time. While the opposition accepts this notice and will not oppose it, it is about time the government considered the extent to which it is denigrating this institution, the House of the people, by its procedures and practices. It detracts from democracy and the efficacy of members being able to fulfil their responsibilities. I accept the motion only because there have been discussions with my colleague. It would seem that the government is intent on preserving what I see as a ridiculous modification to the sessional orders to the disadvantage of this institution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the Senate acquainting the House of the appointment of Senator Gibson to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities in place of Senator Campbell, discharged.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Government to properly administer civil aviation.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia was horrified on 24 April to learn of the crash landing of a DC3 aircraft in Botany Bay. Thank goodness, 25 people escaped from that particular disaster with their lives. I am sure that the people of Australia were even more horrified when they learned that absolutely no regulations governed the operation of a DC3 charter aircraft for a seven-hour trip over an ocean to Norfolk Island. I am sure that they were absolutely horrified on the weekend when they saw yet another disaster near Maitland in New South Wales, where a vintage Tiger Moth aircraft crashed, killing two occupants.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that they have been horrified by the exposes undertaken by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) into the crash of the Monarch aircraft. I am sure that they have been horrified by the crash of the Dove aeroplane a few months ago at Essendon. I am sure that they were horrified to hear the answers that were given by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in this House today.

The reality is that over the last five or six years the administration of aviation in Australia has become an absolute disaster zone. To give the House an indication of just how bad things are becoming, not only in the operations but in the administration, I will quote from the minister himself. He was asked a question in the Senate a few weeks ago and gave this answer on 14 March. The question concerned how many accidents and incidents had been reported in Australia in the three-year period to the end of November 1993. The minister answered that 10,000 accidents and incidents were reported in Australia for the three-year period to the end of November 1993.

While it is true that some of them would not be regarded as major issues, the facts of the matter are that the second and third tiers of aircraft operation in Australia are areas of very great concern. In the 12 months from November 1990 to November 1991, 24 accidents were classified in category 2—namely, regional airline operations—and 22 incidents. From November 1991 to November 1992, there were 20 accidents and 10 incidents. From November 1992 to November 1993, there were seven accidents and one incident. Thank goodness that there have been no category 1 disasters and that our major carriers at least have a very safe level of operation.

The plain facts are that Australia's skies are not as safe as they once were or how people think they may be. Much of this has come about because of the government's failure to control the development of safe aviation in Australia.

I remind the House of some things that have happened in recent years. There was an absolute debacle concerning the radar contracts. We remember the tremendous efforts of Senator MacGibbon in the other place and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) here in making sure that that was all exposed. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were wasted by the Civil Aviation Authority because it had to go back and redo the whole radar contract system.

Remember the debacle, which is still going on, over the new provisions for airspace management around Australia. We were supposed to go into this new system last November, but there were such objections, concerns and fears raised in the aviation industry that the implementation date has been put back. Perhaps we will see it happening a little later this year. There was utter confusion within the aviation industry as to what many of those changes were all about.

I suppose that nothing better exemplifies this than the report that appeared in the Australian on Friday, 29 April 1994. The headline read `Row erupts over air safety'. Two different departments—the Civil Aviation Authority and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation—had a go at each other because they disagreed with the violations of controlled airspace over a five-year period. BASI brought to everyone's attention the real dangers that were starting to exist in air space management. As usual, the CAA said, `Everything will probably be all right.'

We have been through another situation. The department has insisted—probably rightly so—that beacons be installed in all operating aircraft. A row then developed as to what sort of beacon it should be. They should have been in place by now, but, once again, because of the dithering of this government, that project has been delayed. We will not see the introduction of those beacons until the middle of this year. It does not matter where you look in all the rows about safety, people are concerned at the obvious decline in safety standards in Australian aviation.

On 28 April, a report from Australian Associated Press indicated that a Worksafe report had found that proposed changes to work hours for pilots might compromise pilot and passenger safety. The Australian International Pilots Association, one of the most responsible unions in the aviation industry, released a summary of the report which it will use to argue against a Civil Aviation Authority proposal to increase the maximum duty period for flight crews from 16 to 22 hours per day.

The association is concerned that there is no other country that has those particular provisions. For some reason the Civil Aviation Authority has decided that they should be examined as a real proposition. The government is yet to make a determination on what is going to happen there. I think one of the great tragedies is that, while we can still proudly boast one of the safest aviation systems in the world, the plain fact is that it has been more and more challenged. It is being challenged because we have seen a decline in the capacity of governments and departments to administer safety standards in Australia.

In question time today I was interested to hear the minister say that, as a result of the issues that were raised yesterday by the honourable member for Hume and me, he actually rang the chairman of the CAA this morning. He has only been the minister for four months; we cannot expect him to get onto these things too soon—especially when it comes to aviation safety. What an absolute disaster!

One of the great criticisms of this minister that I get from all sections of the aviation industry is that they can never get in to see him. The General Aviation Association and the airports people are all saying that it is physically impossible to make an appointment to discuss these matters of great moment with this particular minister. In the meantime we have a Civil Aviation Authority that has been charged with raising so much revenue that it would almost seem that that is its prime responsibility rather than determining the safety standards and regulations of Australia. We do have some very dedicated and very good people in those departments, but they are frustrated now to the point where the morale in the Civil Aviation Authority is at an absolute low.

I am surprised that, when the minister rang this morning and suggested that something should be done, he did not say, `Why hasn't something been done over the past several years by the CAA board to bring this whole administration into shape?' Obviously, at the end of the day, even with independent statutory bodies of the government, the minister has the ultimate responsibility to make sure that it has that capacity and, in fact, delivers on producing the best aviation safety standards so that all Australians have the capacity to fly around Australia knowing that they will arrive at their destinations.

If we look at the administration of civil aviation in Australia and all its facets over the last several years, we see that it is a disaster. Let us look at the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation. I was fascinated in the white paper from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to see that we got a one line mention. The one line mention is the allocation of $73 million for some work to be done on the Badgerys Creek airport west of Sydney in the financial years 1995-96 and 1996-97. It is hoped that it might all be finished by then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Additional.

—Yes, additional money, but two hours before that we had the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the chief government whip in this House giving long tirades on the necessity for the development of Badgerys Creek airport. Of course, they were absolutely right. But does the minister honestly believe that the present allocations plus these additional allocations that have come in on this white paper have the capacity to present a full international facility for the people of western Sydney? The answer is obviously no. If I were the honourable member for Werriwa, after my commitment to making sure we were going to get the development of Badgerys Creek airport, I probably would have to go outside this place and either resign my seat or slash my wrists as a result of those statements in the government white paper.

PARA.TAB: Badgerys Creek is essential for the proper development of airport infrastructure in Australia. We need only look around Australia to see this. We had a question today about the state of Adelaide airport. We know the confinement that the length of that runway is having on the international operations there and the requirement for its extension for the development of proper freight facilities in that part of the world.

We know the absolute disaster of the construction of the new terminal at the Brisbane international airport. It was promised for years and years. Finally it decided to build it. Already, according to the Courier-Mail reports, industry representatives are saying that it is too small and that already it is going to have to start looking towards some more extensions on that edifice that is being built. Brisbane international airport is going to be the second busiest airport in Australia by 1998.

To go a little bit further, we can go around the regional areas of Australia and see the difficulties that are being experienced in many of the remote areas of Australia in terms of being able to maintain airstrips as a result of the government's decision under the airport local ownership plan to willy-nilly hand over the airports to those operations and expect them to operate them profitably. With the regional disasters that we have around Australia, and the recession, and the droughts, it is virtually impossible for people to provide that infrastructure.

This is a little bit like a Demtel television commercial: `If you want more, we've got more.' Let us look at the International Air Services Commission. There is some magnificent stuff going on there. At the moment we have a fight going on between Qantas and Ansett. The government, in its wisdom, decided to introduce a second carrier on international rights. Quite properly, the IASC awarded Ansett a number of international services. It is picking up the Osaka service and the Hong Kong service, and it is operating the Bali service. But it has rights to Malaysia—a huge source of tourism to Australia—that it is not going to pick up, and it is not going to pick up its rights over the New Zealand route. Qantas has rights that it has not used. On many of these services we have been asked to provide more capacity because the full development of Australian tourism is being wound down because of the lack of availability of seats on those routes at certain times of the year.

Let us look at the great initiative that the government had about the common aviation market between Australia and New Zealand. That was supposed to all be in place at the end of last year. We have got no further on that. We have put question after question on the Notice Paper. We never get a response from the minister. Who knows what is going to happen there.

We have a situation where an air carrier has been given rights to China, but it does not look as though it has the capacity to raise the money to buy an aircraft to operate the services. In the meantime, Qantas is terribly concerned about that, and we have the Chinese wondering what the devil is happening. The potential in and out of China is absolutely enormous.

Late last year we had bilateral brawls between Australia and the United States in terms of the North West Airlines services over Osaka and the absolute debacle that happened there. In the end Australia won absolutely nothing, North West Airlines walked away, and we looked like absolute fools. I guess we will have another fight pretty soon, when United Airlines decides that it is going to try to claim those rights. What will the government do then? Back down as usual—no problems at all.We have just had a situation where Qantas applied for extra capacity over Thailand. What happened? The Thais said, `The deal is not good enough for us. You cannot come in.' Qantas has said, very reluctantly, that now it is going to switch its services to Singapore because the government has not had the capacity to negotiate those air rights.

We have problems; it does not matter whether we look into the administration of the safety aspects of Australian aviation or at the independent statutory corporations such as the Federal Airports Corporation. After all, the FAC is supposed to be a commercial entity. It could pay $1 1/2 million for a share in a fresh food service at Sydney and Brisbane airports, and in the first year of operation it managed to lose about $277,000. One has to question some of its commercial capacity. It does not matter whether we look into that whole area of air rights; we have problems there as well. The plain fact is that the decade of the 1990s has ended up an absolute disaster in terms of the administration of Australian aviation.

My good advice to the minister, seeing as he has only been in the chair for four months, is to start to kick a few heads; look at the composition of the board of the CAA and see what he can do to improve it; look at the composition of the Federal Airports Corporation; and look at the composition of his department. Australia's public will not accept second-rate standards in any of these areas. He owes it to the Australian population to provide a safe, secure and viable aviation industry. The way this government is going, it is not going to get it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things I would absolutely agree with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) about: firstly, his comment that we in Australia can still proudly boast one of the safest systems in the world—I was very pleased that he made that admission—and, secondly, his comment that the Chinese would be wondering what is really happening. I agree with that because, if the Chinese had heard his speech this afternoon, they would not have any idea what is really happening in this House or in the opposition's view of aviation in this country.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member gave us a diatribe starting with air safety, which is, of course, the matter of the moment, but then he ranged off in one direction or another to deal with the Federal Airports Corporation, its alleged shortcomings, the question of airport expansion the length and breadth of Australia—from Adelaide to God only knows where—and the development of Badgerys Creek. He commented upon debates earlier in the House today, he dealt with the International Air Services Commission and the question of Ansett flights to Bali and non-flights to Malaysia, and the fact that it is not taking up all the rights awarded to it. He mentioned the common aviation market as well as air rights to China itself, not to mention the North West Airlines flights via Osaka.

But the real question before the House is none of these things; it is the question of what do we need to do additional to what is already being done to guarantee the highest standards of air safety in this country, to guarantee that we can continue to proudly boast, in the words of the honourable member, `the safest system in the world.' I am reasonably well qualified to speak in this debate because for 24 1/2 years I have represented, at both the state and federal level, constituents who live directly under the flight paths to the biggest and busiest airport in this nation. We have lived with aircraft every minute of every day, except when the curfew was in place, and even then we have lived with those curfew flights, whether propeller-driven or jet, that have been allowed into Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

As I indicated in the House today, as someone who has personally witnessed crashes and seen the carnage involved, who, as a boy, marvelled at the ability of a DC3 to float for some time before it sank into the Lakes golf course pond in the mid-1950s and who later witnessed what I said was the worst carnage and the most horrific accident that I ever thought could occur, being the crash of the Advance Airlines King Air in 1980, I feel a particular responsibility to pursue with all my vigour the question of air safety and to ensure that we do everything in our power in that regard.

The honourable member for Fadden misrepresented me today when he suggested that I have only just—in the last 24 hours—contacted General Gration and the CAA in regard to air traffic safety. The honourable member should be aware that I have been in regular contact with the CAA from the moment I took up my duties as Minister for Transport. I have met with representatives of the CAA several times, I have spoken with them on the phone on numerous occasions and, as I confirmed to the House, I spoke again with General Gration this morning to make sure that he and I are on exactly the one wavelength in terms of pursuing these issues of great concern. I am pleased to report to the House today that we are. He indicated to me that he agreed with me completely that we should put all our energy into doing everything possible to see a complete response to the matters of concern regarding air safety.

I indicated to the House earlier today that, of the 58 identified recommendations of the Terrell report into air safety last year, 38 have already been put into place by the Civil Aviation Authority. General Gration was able to guarantee that the remaining 20 recommendations—bringing it up to the full quota of 58—will be in place by the end of June this year. I was pleased to obtain that assurance. We were able to talk further and to discuss this very question raised in the last few weeks about the circumstances in which a DC3 aircraft was allowed to take off—it did not get very far—and fly for seven hours across the Tasman Sea carrying no fewer than 25 people, the majority being the children who comprise the Scots College school band.

If it is true, as has been suggested in press reports, that had that aircraft been built after 1963 it would not have been allowed to undertake that flight, I think there is something seriously wrong with the regulations. I have asked General Gration to make sure that that is addressed as a matter of absolute urgency. Let us not wait for any BASI inquiries into that crash; let us get on and tackle it now.

In respect of the matters that have been of great concern to the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), there is one big issue that I think requires attention over and above what we know of the circumstances of the accident to date—that is, the question of companies which might be in some financial difficulties, and whether there should not be a system of credit watch adopted by the Civil Aviation Authority where it is on a sort of red alert, as it were, to pay particular attention to companies that are fairly close to that viability line. I am not sure how we would go about that, but it is one of the things that I have asked General Gration to pay particular attention to, and I am hopeful that we can devise a system that will allow a lot more attention to be paid to airlines that fly in the future whose financial circumstances are similar to those sad days leading to the awful disaster of Monarch's aeroplane in June last year.

I am able to assure the House that we are concerned about this issue and we are intent on doing everything within our power to pursue a series of regulations and recommendations that will leave Australia absolutely confident in the quality of our air safety. But I will not go out and pre-judge these issues. I know that, in the emotion of the moment when a member is representing an electorate where people have been touched by a great tragedy; where a community has been enormously affected by an accident such as the King Air, there is a tendency to race out and say, `This one is to blame and that one is to blame.' I will not be in on that. What I will do is pursue recommendations as they come from the appropriate authorities to make sure it cannot happen again and to make sure that, if those recommendations suggest that actions of a criminal or disciplinary nature should be taken against particular officers, that is pursued and pursued with all vigour. But I will not come out and act as judge, jury and executioner in this process. That will be for the proper authorities. But I will be—and this government will be—the facilitator of making sure that attention is paid by those authorities to all these issues.

The fact is that the opposition has been at sixes and sevens about the question of the powers of the Civil Aviation Authority. There is no better way of illustrating that than to look at the various quotations of the honourable member for Fadden or, alternatively, the honourable member for Hume or, going to the other place, none other than our friend Senator MacGibbon. If honourable members read the things they have said—and I have had a chance to do so—they will see that they take a very different attitude as to how the Civil Aviation Authority should pursue its role.

There is no ambiguity about the position of the honourable member for Hume. He is on the record as saying that the Civil Aviation Authority's role is to be the policeman for all air services in Australia. He is quite clear in his mind as to how the Civil Aviation Authority should function and how it should pursue its duties. On the other hand, the honourable member for Fadden has been a

SPEECH.PARA: touch more circumspect, or he certainly was on 27 October when he said:

PARA.TAB: I have no problems with deregulation of the airline industry at all. In fact, deregulation does not mean, and it should not mean, the lowering of safety standards. I hope we can find that this—

SPEECH.PARA: he was talking about an accident—
was an isolated incident rather than one of laxity by the department in allowing some of those standards to slip. I am sure that the latter was not the case.
The honourable member believed that the standards could not slip. On the basis of these comments, he has a great deal of confidence in the Civil Aviation Authority. He went on to say:

Therefore, I would hope that we would not be going into a frenzy regarding the reintroduction of a fully regulated airline industry when there are obviously so many savings that can be made in a deregulated environment. Perhaps I should not say any more than that until such time as the full report from the Civil Aviation Authority is released regarding this particular accident in Young.

That is the Monarch airline accident. I agree with the honourable member that we should wait until we have that report. I have indicated that it will be available very shortly. I will then share it with the honourable member for Hume and we will pursue its recommendations. But the opposition's position does not run from that point to the other. It goes a long way further in the utterances of Senator MacGibbon, who is on the record as saying:

PARA.TAB: We certainly need a cooperative approach from the Civil Aviation Authority . . . We have to get a civil aviation authority that wants to work with, not against, the aviation industry. The nonsense that is going on today has to stop and it has to stop rapidly, otherwise a lot of people will die needlessly in the VFR field in Australia.
Once upon a time the department of civil aviation worked in cooperation with the industry. It led by example, it counselled people and it advised them.

SPEECH.PARA: So there are a diversity of views in the opposition. Some believe that the CAA should be the policeman. Others believe that we should wait and see. Others believe that the CAA should take a hands-off approach with a full commitment to self-regulation. We have to get the balance right. We have to make sure that there are appropriate rules and regulations.

PARA.TAB: When I see an old aircraft carrying a lot of kids crash into Botany Bay, I am enormously thankful that not a life was lost. But I ask myself: what steps should we be taking to make sure that this cannot happen again? When I see tragically a couple of people burnt to death as a result of a wing-walking stunt exercise on the weekend, which I know horrified every television viewer who unfortunately saw it, I say, `Why are we still doing this? Didn't this cease with Robert Redford and The Great Waldo Pepper all those years ago?' That is one area, along with the question of old aeroplanes operating over the ocean for long distances, which I have asked General Gration to address as a matter of urgency.

I repeat to the House that I have the greatest of confidence in General Gration. I consider him to be one of the finest Australians that this nation has ever produced. I think we are enormously fortunate to have such an outstanding Australian available in the leadership role of the Civil Aviation Authority. He has told me that 38 of the 58 recommendations of Terrell have been implemented, and I know that is the case. He has told me that he is pursuing the remainder. He has told me that these other issues, such as wing-walking and old aircraft, will be pursued by him with all his vigour and that he will do everything possible to tighten up the internal affairs of the Civil Aviation Authority as a result of the Monarch accident and the lessons learnt from the Monarch accident.

It may take some months before we have the final recommendations of BASI. We will certainly have an interim report either today, tomorrow or before the end of this week. I hope it contains some things which we can proceed to implement immediately. But we will not be able to attribute blame until such time as we have final recommendations and the results of the coronial inquiry. I implore the honourable member for Hume, in spite of the high emotion he feels on behalf of his constituents who have been so dramatically and tragically affected, to wait and see before we act as judge and jury against the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority, the pilots, the owners of Monarch Air or any other party.

When the recommendations are available and the determination of the coronial inquiry is before me, he and the House may rest assured that we will do everything possible—indeed, everything necessary—to guarantee that we can proudly say that we still boast the highest record of safety anywhere in the world. So, with those words and assurances, I am pleased to have had this opportunity to contribute to the matter of public importance submitted by the honourable member for Fadden.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the remarks of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) both in this matter of public importance and in question time earlier today. His response was interesting. For example, he mentioned the viability or credit watch of the airlines around Australia that provide a service to the travelling public. I think this is a critical issue. Had it been in place in Australia, as it is in the UK or the US, Monarch simply would not have been operating much beyond 1991, for the simple reason that Monarch was technically bankrupt at the time. The importance of this, which is learnt from investigating incidents such as the Monarch crash, is that, if an airline is not operating profitably, the first thing it does is cut corners. The corners that it cuts involve things such as maintenance and flying operation procedures. In my view, that ultimately helped contribute to the tragic loss of those seven lives at Young on 11 June last year.

PARA.TAB: I was also interested to hear that the minister will pursue this matter as far as he possibly can. I was very pleased to hear that. But I will give the minister a little bit of an idea of the tiger that he will have to wrestle with. Over the years the CAA has run quite out of control. I have many examples of this, and I will talk about a couple of them today. The Monarch accident is one. This airline was technically bankrupt. The aircraft were not being properly maintained. Indeed, the aircraft that crashed had had the autopilot removed and several vital instruments had been made inoperable.

I can highlight other instances. I draw to the attention of the House the incident involving Western Airlines that operated out of Wagga. That airline was a standing joke, particularly in Canberra. The joke was that, when a Western Airlines aircraft pulled up, drip trays had to be put under the aircraft to stop the oil spilling all over the apron. In Wagga the airworthiness inspector proposed to his senior managers in the CAA that that airline have its AOC, air operator's certificate, withdrawn and that the aircraft be grounded. Do honourable members know what ended up happening? The senior managers did investigate the claims made by the airworthiness inspector. They were all found to be correct. But, instead of punishing Western Airlines, they punished the airworthiness inspector. He was sidelined. His career is now doomed. But Western Airlines continues to fly. That is the sort of attitude that prevails within the Civil Aviation Authority.

Let me give another example. Seaview Lord Howe Island Pty Ltd operates a Navaho that flies between Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Island. The Navaho can take nine passengers but, because of the length of the strip at Lord Howe Island and the 480-odd nautical miles that has to be flown between the two places, this Navaho is licensed to carry only six passengers because it has to carry a full load of fuel, taking off on a short runway.

The chief pilot of Seaview Aviation reported to the Civil Aviation Authority that he was being forced by his employer to carry nine passengers, against the licensed regulations imposed on that aircraft operating that service. The end result was that the chief pilot was sacked by the airline. The airworthiness inspector recommended that the aircraft and the airline be grounded. What happened? The airline continued to fly. The guy who blew the whistle was punished by being sacked and the airline that was breaking the law continued to fly.

That was not the only thing it was doing. The airline was operating a scheduled service and yet it was not licensed to provide regular public transport. It was breaking the law because it was carrying more people than it was licensed to carry. It was breaking the law because it was providing an RPT service when it was not licensed to do so. It was also breaking the law because life vests and life rafts were not carried when aircraft were flying over water. Yet this airline which was operating so dangerously and which was putting people's lives at risk continued to fly.

I have many other examples. I have a list as long as your arm that I could have given yesterday in my speech, but I am afraid that time did not permit me to do so. There are other examples of things going on in the Civil Aviation Authority that should concern the minister. Yesterday I mentioned the possibility of corruption. I cited the instance of flying operations inspectors, who are pilots, who are able to finesse a problem that air operators have on the basis and the understanding that, if they do it, there is plenty of free flying time for them in that airline company's aircraft. This has been suggested. I cited a particular example of it yesterday. But there are more problems than that.

There is another activity that occurs with flying operations inspectors and it is called line flying: the CAA's flying operations inspectors fly with airlines. This is designed to give those pilots who work for the CAA flying experience to keep their licences up to scratch, and it also saves the CAA money. But many of those flying operations inspectors are abusing that system. One inspector in particular dons the uniform of one particular airline and flies every fortnight. As a result of this the people who are supposed to be administering, regulating or policing the law—whichever way we want to describe it—are working with and alongside the people that they are supposed to be regulating, resulting in a club-like matey arrangement. That is part of the problem because it is the flying operations inspectors who are overriding the recommendations of the airworthiness inspectors.

Let me give another example. A CAA district officer recommended to the Director of Public Prosecutions that a particular airline operator be charged. The Director of Public Prosecutions looked into the matter and found that a prima facie case existed, so charges were laid. A flying operations officer based here in Canberra, who was at the time acting in what is described as a very senior position, intervened in this matter, spoke to the officer in charge of that district office where the original complaints had come from and demanded that those complaints be withdrawn. However, the DPP had taken those complaints to the point where they could not be withdrawn. But had that flying operations officer been successful, that case would never have gone forward. As it was the case did go forward and the air operator was found guilty of the charge. That would never have happened if that flying operations officer based here in Canberra had had his way. There is something awfully wrong with the way the Civil Aviation Authority is operating. If the minister is going to do what he says he is going to do, he has a big task ahead of him.

There is another critical aspect to all of this which the Monarch Air crash and another crash that took place in Victoria down near Seymour two years ago highlight—that is, the matter of insurance. People are staggered when they realise that insurance for these types of airlines is not compulsory; it is an optional extra. That is absolutely wrong. I guarantee that all passengers who get in commercial airline aircraft in Australia would believe they are properly insured, but it is not the case. Many of the third level airlines do insure even though it is not required. But even if they do, as was the case in Victoria and has now proven to be the case with Monarch Air, the insurance company claims immediately there was a breach of the Air Navigation Act therefore the policy is voided, therefore there is no liability, and therefore there is no insurance for the victims' families. That is usually what happens.

But if the insurance companies do not do that and they do pay out, there is a maximum payout of up to $180,000. If the Minister for Transport were driving his car, had a crash and was made a quadriplegic, he would expect to get $3 million or $4 million in compensation. But if the minister were flying in one of these aircraft, it crashed and he was made a quadriplegic, he could expect to get only up to $180,000—that is, if the insurance company ever paid up. That is downright unfair. It is inequitable and it has to be addressed. What the minister also has to do in the months ahead of him, as he fulfils the promise that he has given this House today, is to fix the problems of the Civil Aviation Authority and the aviation industry here in Australia.

I hope he does live up to what he says. It is terribly important that he does because the lives of many Australians swing on his ability to turn the rhetoric that he has expressed here in this House today into action. If he does not then there will be many more Australians go to their graves as those 25 boys from Scots College nearly did the other day and as some of my constituents did on 11 June last year at Young in an accident that really should never have happened.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a debate like this and with a topic as significant as aviation administration there ought to be a both reasoned and considered form of debate that takes place between us. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) was what I would call very measured in his discussion of this topic, and I think that the contributions made by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) were in the same vein. I am not sure that it is the kind of topic that ought to be brought on in an MPI, but here it is.

PARA.TAB: The starting point in this debate has to be the issue of general air safety in Australia. At the top level is the question of world envy of the fact that Australia has such an excellent air safety record, particularly with regard to the major commercial airlines and the major passenger traffic. There are lots of reasons for that, not the least being the very heavy and intense effort put in over many years by the Civil Aviation Authority and its predecessors requiring those standards, and the requirements instituted under the old two-airline agreement.

Following the opening up of aviation to competition, and in this current climate of user pays and more and more intense pressure on the dollar in all industries, there are many more planes flying than was the case in the past. They are flying on much tighter margins and governments are under pressure from the industry, from taxpayers, from everyone, to minimise the bureaucratic costs involved with regulation and supervision. At the same time operators are under cost pressures that can lead to short cuts. Those short cuts can often be in the field of safety.

There is nothing in the performance of the airlines or the statistics to date that gives us any reason to believe that this situation is any worse than it has been in the past. But that is not to say that we should not be seriously cognisant of it. I have to say to the honourable members for Hume and Fadden that in the kinds of policies they were coming forward with at the last election there was one little policy complication they got themselves into and have not yet, at this point anyway, jettisoned. In their Fightback proposals they were proposing that this industry bear the full cost of air safety charges: in other words, total user pays.

The government maintains a regime whereby we finance the operations of the CAA in the field, and there is a subsidy involved because we believe in our commitment. Had that policy come into effect not only would the opposition have been adding a GST to the airline prices but it would also have been removing some of the assistance that is given in a financial way to the supervision of safety; in other words, there would have been a further direct squeeze on this issue of air safety. It is a little puzzling that too much is made of this issue in that context.

I heard the honourable member for Hume on radio this morning. People often ask me, `What's he like?' and all that sort of stuff and I say, `I've known him for a few years. We came into this place together. He's very articulate and he delivers his views, but he is prone to stretch the point a bit and in fact is not always absolutely accurate.' That is a nice way to put it. On the radio this morning in respect of the Monarch incident—and I fully understand his close interest in and concern about this matter—I heard him say, `Here it is. It happened all this time ago and nothing has happened.' I do not believe that he really thought that nothing had been done. I hope that he is reassured by the answer given in question time today by the minister, who indicated that there has been extensive investigation undertaken in respect of that accident and there are a number of recommendations being brought forward right now. It is not true to publicly paint a picture that it happened and has been ignored or forgotten.

It is also fair to say that the government shares some of the concerns about the capacity of the CAA, in the form that it was in, to deal with this air safety issue. That is why significant action has been taken to provide some restructuring and some separation of issues, such as the airworthiness section and the licensing section. It is my understanding that the structural changes that bring about those separations are already in place. If that is so, the honourable member for Hume was giving examples on radio this morning and again in this parliament about practices that no longer exist. They are colourful illustrations of the point, but the point needs to be made that they are no longer in existence. So, to the extent that that is the case, it is worth my making that point.

I share the minister's acknowledgment of the regard in which everybody holds Peter Gration, who has been appointed to the position of chairman of the CAA. He has a track record of getting things done, and he has put this matter at the top of his priority list. I think we can expect some very prompt implementation of changes or assurances that a number of these matters that may cause concern are being and will be addressed.

Having said those things, let me flag in this discussion something about which I think we all have to do some thinking. While we may have had these wonderful safety procedures and records, the fact of the matter is that flying around Australia is not all that difficult by world standards. It is basically a flat country and most of the major airports are on flat land near the seaboard. Whether it is by good management, good luck, good geography or whatever, we have enjoyed an enviable safety record, and the world acknowledges that. But the number of aircraft flying around in the skies over Australia is increasing. With population shifts and increasing wealth, lots of changes are taking place in commuter patterns and the pressure on airports is increasing. It is incumbent upon government and the industry to ensure that the infrastructure and the standards are in place, be they improvements in airports, in air traffic control, in training of the people involved or a higher degree of safety and responsibility on the part of the operators.

I happened to be in south-west Tasmania last week and I flew back from a remote airfield to Hobart airport. As we approached the airfield, I had headphones on and was listening to the air traffic discussion between my pilot and air traffic controllers. As we were flying over Hobart, there were several aircraft in the sky. The pilot was told where they were and to keep his eye out for them. He was looking around everywhere, and so was I.

However, the point is that maybe that is not satisfactory over time. Perhaps relying on pilots doing visuals under 3,000 feet will not be satisfactory in time, particularly if the equipment in the aircraft is not up to that. I think a lot of work needs to be done, as there are more and more of these aircraft flying around, to ensure that these standards are developed and maintained. I do not think the MPI is of substance, but I am happy to make that contribution.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The discussion is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the second and third reports of the committee for 1994 relating to the refurbishment of the Australian Federal Police College, Barton, Australian Capital Territory, and the relocation of the Salisbury explosive ordnance testing facilities to Port Wakefield, South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the House. The first report which I have tabled deals with the refurbishment of the Australian Federal Police College, Barton, Australian Capital Territory. The report recommends that the refurbishment should proceed, although there is a condition attached to this recommendation which I will explain later. The estimated cost of the proposed refurbishment is $10.5 million at July 1993 prices.

PARA.TAB: The report mentions that the existing college building, although partially extended and later renovated, is nearly 50 years old and the standard of living-in accommodation and training facilities reflects this. If the Australian Federal Police is to have adequate facilities for the training of police officers and officers from other agencies, there is a definite requirement for better facilities.

The AFP examined a number of options, including the use of a surplus school and the integration of the college with a new AFP headquarters. Neither option proved practicable or financially realistic. Accordingly, the AFP proposes to upgrade the building to comply with current regulations, fire safety and occupational health and safety; establish clearly defined functional zones and refine circulation and access routes within the complex; utilise existing courtyards more imaginatively; and upgrade the quality of work and residential areas.

The committee's report concludes that the extent of the proposed refurbishment is necessary due to the age and condition of the building and a requirement to provide a modern, integrated training establishment offering facilities consistent with contemporary standards and expectations. Therefore, the standard of accommodation proposed is consistent with a need to cater for the diversity of personnel attending training courses. Similarly, the extent of the proposed upgrading of building services reflects the requirement to repair and maintain deficiencies in existing systems and to modernise them, where necessary.

The committee has made recommendations concerning a number of design and consultative matters. On the question of fire safety, the committee recommends that the involvement of the ACT Fire Brigade should continue throughout the design and delivery of the completed project. The committee also recommends that an energy audit of the college should be carried out 12 months after completion of the project. The committee recommends that the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled should be involved in the design of refurbishment work relating to access and other facilities for the disabled. The committee recommends that the AFP should formalise arrangements with child-care centres aimed at providing certainty about the availability of child-care places.

I said at the outset that the committee's recommendation that the work should proceed is conditional. This conditional approval stems from the impact of the law enforcement review, now completed, on the structure and functions of Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. The review had not been finalised at the time of the committee's consideration of the proposed work. We were very conscious of a case where a completed work previously examined by the committee was not required as a consequence of organisational changes occurring during construction. I am sure that the parliament would not wish to see a repeat of this type of debacle. The committee therefore recommends that the project should proceed, subject to impacts associated with the law enforcement review having no significant bearing on the scope of the proposal.

The second report which I have tabled deals with the partial relocation of the environmental test facility from its current location in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation complex at Salisbury to Port Wakefield, north of Adelaide.In this place we all understand stress; indeed, it is an occupational hazard for us. But, for the benefit of honourable members, I will try to explain what environmental stress testing is all about. It involves subjecting items of ordnance to a variety of tests which simulate their handling, transport and storage. At present, this testing is carried out at Salisbury. The transportation of environmentally stressed ordnance from Salisbury to the proof and experimental establishment at Port Wakefield poses risks to the public and Defence personnel which could be avoided.

The scope of the proposed work examined by the committee involves the construction of 12 test laboratory buildings, control and administrative buildings, four storage magazines and associated infrastructure. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $8 million. The committee has recommended that the proposal proceed. In arriving at this recommendation, the committee considered that environmental stress testing of explosive ordnance is essential to ensure the safety of defence personnel required to transport it and to ultimately operate the weapons system.

The committee also concluded that there is a need for the stress testing to be undertaken at a safer location, preferably in close proximity to a proofing range. Defence examined a number of possible locations and concluded that Port Wakefield is the best one. I must say that, having inspected the proof and experimental establishment there, the committee agreed with this assessment. The committee concluded that the extent of the proposed work could be justified on the basis of the specialised functions which need to be carried out by or in the various buildings proposed.

The committee sought assurances from Defence on a number of safety and environmental issues. The committee was assured that the location and size of the proposed site provides adequate clearance and room for expansion. Preliminary engineering investigations have indicated that the site is suitable for constructing the buildings proposed. There will be no significant deleterious environmental impacts from the proposed facility. There will be no additional firing and associated noise from the proof and experimental establishment as a consequence of the relocation of the ordnance environmental stress facility to Port Wakefield.

Again, the committee sought assurances about the long-term viability of the proposed facility in the light of possible future policy changes. Based on the evidence presented to it, the committee concluded that, in the event of policy changes occurring in the future which may place the responsibility for all or some environmental stress testing of ordnance on Australian manufacturers, need for and the use of the proposed facility will remain. In terms of revenue from testing ordnance, the committee concluded that provision of a new purpose-built facility will provide considerable scope for Defence to undertake additional commercial work without the need for additional staff.

A feature of the construction of the new facility will be the involvement of army engineers as the primary construction agency. The decision to use army engineers was made on the basis of the relatively remote site, the benefits to be gained from training and value for money. Army engineers are presently involved in the construction of RAAF base Scherger, near Weipa in Queensland. From all reports that I have received, it is proving to be a very successful exercise.

Finally, I mention that the proposal has considerable local government support and, indeed, strong support from the local federal member. The proof and experimental establishment has been at Port Wakefield since 1928 and considerable goodwill exists between civilian and military authorities there. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As the member for Wakefield, I welcome this particular work. I should, however, indicate to the House that I am also a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works. As such, it could be said that I have a vested interest in this work proceeding.

PARA.TAB: The chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), has, in his usual generous manner, indicated my enthusiasm for the project, but I should point out to the House that, following the public works committee hearing into the relocation of the proof and experimental testing facility from Salisbury to Port Wakefield, something of a local controversy has erupted. It is for that reason that I would like to participate in the submission to the House and indicate to the House just what the work will do and why I welcome it.

There are two issues currently before the House on the question of testing ordnance. The first is that there exists at Port Wakefield, which is at the top of the Gulf of St Vincent, a proof and experimental establishment. It has been there since 1928.
