The proof and experimental establishment is there simply so that all of the service arms of the Australian Defence Force can test ordnances by firing them down the gulf. It may seem a little odd that anyone should choose to fire from Port Wakefield down the gulf towards the city of Adelaide, but Port Wakefield is in fact located at least 90 kilometres from the city of Adelaide. Even though the proofing range takes up about 30 kilometres of that stretch, the simple reality is that the firing occurs there because the Gulf of St Vincent is unique in world terms.

The gulf is unique in world terms in that it has lengthy and wide, sandy beaches and a huge tidal movement so it is possible for the proof and experimental establishment to fire from its location just south of Port Wakefield down the east coast of the Gulf of St Vincent and to have the projectiles land in what will be about two metres of water. They will then safely and without sustaining damage sink to the bottom. The tide goes out and the proof and experimental people retrieve the projectile.

The whole object of the proof and experimental range is to be able to take that projectile and, having tested it with radars and having tested its trajectory, determine whether or not, since it has not been damaged in the landing process, it is distorted in any way as a result of the firing. This procedure has gone on since 1928. Since 1928 it has been possible for Defence to test its barrels, its shells, the shell casings and the projectiles in this manner. So successful has this testing been that we have now attracted work from around the globe.

Naturally, the firing process in itself causes a good deal of noise and some angst to the local community. Many members of the community are accustomed to it as it has gone on since 1928. During World War II the range was extensively used and the extensive use of the range in wartime conditions, when there was an urgency for all types of tests to occur, meant that there were occasions when ordnances that ought to have exploded failed to explode on impact and so sat on the bottom of the beach.

As a South Australian I must confess that the beaches now occupied by some unexploded ordnances resulting from World War II testing are beaches that South Australians would like to use for crayfishing. Just to the south of the range, in fact, there is quite a vigorous little crayfishing port called Parham. It simply will not be possible, I regret, for South Australians to occupy this east coast of the Gulf of St Vincent because since World War II there has been all of this extensive testing.

The controversy that has erupted over the relocation of the Salisbury facility to Port Wakefield is that there are people who believe it will result in additional firings from Port Wakefield. I want to pick up the point made by the chairman when he said that the committee was assured that `there will be no additional firing and associated noise from the Proof and Experimental Establishment as a consequence of the relocation of the ordnance environmental stress test facility to Port Wakefield.'

The ordnance environmental stress test facility—it may seem a little odd to have an environmental testing facility involved with munitions—is a facility that exists at Salisbury and will be relocated to Port Wakefield. Prior to its relocation, all of the testing done on ordnances in Salisbury were nothing more than environmental testing, hence the name. That is, the ordnances were either frozen or heated as the case may be. As the chairman and members of the committee and I witnessed, they are dropped off pallets to simulate what would happen if in the loading of a vessel, for example, the forklift or the pallet slipped and these munitions then fell onto the deck of the ship. Clearly it is in the interests of the Australian Defence Force and of all personnel that they explode in the barrel of a gun and not on the deck of a ship.

This sort of test goes on and it goes on at Salisbury in what is now a metropolitan area. Having been tested at Salisbury, the ordnances are then carted to Port Wakefield for firing. The public works committee has endorsed the proposal to transfer the testing that happens at Salisbury to Port Wakefield and then fire the ordnances. So there is no additional firing involved.

As the chairman has indicated, the committee has endorsed a proposal that says we are prepared to spend a total of $6 million in building the necessary laboratories so that conditions can be simulated in which the munitions can be either frozen, heated or exposed to abrasive circumstances, vibrated—as they would be on road or rail transport—and generally treated to ensure that they are stable. I just want to put on record in the parliament the simple reassurance that I offer those few people who have since become apprehensive about this work: there is no proposal, nor is there any need for additional firing from Port Wakefield.

In addition, I point out to any South Australians who might perchance pick up the Hansard that the facility that now exists at Port Wakefield is generating export income for Australia and for South Australia. I regret that some people have been inconvenienced by it. I restate that the area is already, as it were, polluted by World War II firings. No pollution occurs now, since the projectile and the trajectory are always monitored when it is fired. Defence knows precisely where the projectile has landed. It can be marked on the map so it is easy to locate or at least Defence knows the general area where it is if it cannot be located. Currently, because we have guns that now fire over a much larger distance, some firing occurs from the west coast of the Gulf of St Vincent across to the east coast. I know that has caused some dislocation, some concern to Defence and some concern to my constituents over the past two weeks.

It is regrettable that this extended firing to do a particular job for Defence occurred with the announcement of this proposed change to the Port Wakefield range. As a result of that, some of my constituents are certain that their federal member deceived them in his comments to the public inquiry into the location of the proof and experimental station. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure them, as I assure you, that there will be no additional firing and there will be an opportunity for additional export income as a result of this work. As a South Australian, I welcome it.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that it gives me a great deal of pleasure to resume the debate on this matter. I am sure that no-one in the House enjoys having a debate disturbed, particularly over a three-hour period. However, I suppose when we consider that the debate is all about something that we on this side of the House are extremely proud of, it is fortuitous or symbolic that it was delayed to allow the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to advise us of the nature of the white paper and its issues, which we on this side of the House will be proud of for a long time to come.

PARA.TAB: At the time the debate was suspended I was in the middle of explaining why the child-care cash rebate is such a great initiative. This initiative will help families with the cost of child care associated with employment, training, education or job search. A feature of this support is that it will not be income tested. It will provide up to $61.20 per week for two or more children. Unlike a tax concession, the cash rebate is claimed as the cost is incurred rather than up to 18 months later. That is why it is fundamentally fairer than a tax concession. It does not favour high income earners.

The cash rebate will make sure that women with low incomes also benefit, including women in part-time work or studying who have no taxable income. It will not force low income women unnecessarily into the work force. An estimated 230,000 families will benefit at a cost of $149 million a year over the next four years. The child-care rebate legislation which establishes the child-care cash rebate was not opposed by the opposition. I thank the opposition for that. I urge honourable members to support this current legislation, which will implement changes to the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill so that the child-care cash rebate scheme can be administered by the Health Insurance Commission.

I am proud that this government has elevated child care to a central role in our nation's economic and community life. With 1994 being the International Year of the Family, such an initiative is indeed timely, giving added financial support to families. It is not only timely—it is indeed appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure also to speak to the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. In doing so I support my colleagues the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne). I was also very pleased to hear the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) say that some very good points are contained in this legislation. I commend her for those comments. But as is often the case, the honourable member for Moncrieff was rather selective in some of her comments. At one point the honourable member for Moncrieff actually claimed that she had been misrepresented by the honourable member for Moreton. I would like to take up that issue. The honourable member for Moreton—I take it from the Hansard green today—stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a particular nonsense when she—
that being the honourable member for Moncrieff—
has been the one to lead the coalition charge in attacking us because we did not put a means test on the child-care cash rebate.

The honourable member for Moncrieff said that she had been misrepresented in that she supposedly led the charge. In my book, if you lead the charge you are obviously the one in front. Back in 1993, on 20 October, the honourable member was the first person to speak for the coalition—therefore leading the coalition discussion—in demanding that a means test be imposed on the child-care cash rebate. She was, I reiterate, the first speaker from the coalition on this bill and therefore in the lead. I would like to quote a couple of passages from that speech on 20 October 1993. The honourable member for Moncrieff stated:

The coalition will not oppose the bill but will move to amend it, to cap the payment of child-care rebate, to remove the child-care for millionaires element. Furthermore, under the coalition's proposed scheme, a rebate would not have been payable beyond a combined income of $60,000, with payment of a rebate tapering out between $50,000 and $60,000.
The speech goes on to say:
I—
being the honourable member for Moncrieff—

point out that the coalition supports capping the level of income able to be earned in order to be eligible. For many years there has been increasing community recognition of the expense and the inequity of open-ended government assistance and the desirability of targeting those in most need. The coalition believes that this approach would be an appalling misuse of scarce public resources and unnecessarily limits the capacity of government to provide adequate assistance to those in genuine need.

We are talking about assisting those in genuine need. The amendments here that we are discussing today are largely, as we have heard, of a minor procedural nature. They provide for the recovery of costs incurred by the Commonwealth in the provision of rehabilitation programs. The amendments in section 23, as we have heard, will serve to strengthen legislative support for the recovery of costs by the Commonwealth for rehabilitation programs provided to clients with compensation. The bill further goes on to require decision makers under part 3 of the Disability Services Act to notify persons affected by their decisions of the making of those decisions and of the right of appeal.

PARA.TAB: Part 3 of the bill relating to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 is consequential on the passage of the Child Care Rebate Act of 1993. The amendments will provide that, consistent with the existing scheme of operation of part 5 of the HIC Act 1973, part 5 makes adequate provision in relation to the child-care cash rebate functions of the commission. Part 5 of the Health Insurance Commission Act deals with financial matters. So accordingly the HIC will be required to prepare estimates of receipts and expected expenditures related to the performance of its child-care cash rebate functions; to expend its moneys in relation to those functions only in accordance with approved estimates of expenditure; to apportion its assets and expenditure appropriately and to open bank accounts required to enable it to properly handle its moneys.

What is most noteworthy about this bill is that the Labor government has recognised that it is difficult for women to participate on an active basis in the workplace. We have had that come to our attention on many occasions. Women are often constrained by access to affordable child care. I reiterate here something that has been often stated by the women members of this parliament: women are over 50 per cent of the population and have a diversity of skills and abilities to offer which are extremely valuable to the economy. Yet, in many instances we are unable to make use of that incredible pool of knowledge. The limited access in the past to affordable child care has been part of the problem. The cash rebate will substantially increase the ability and the affordable opportunities of women who wish to work or undertake further education and/or participate in training programs.

Let us be realistic. This legislation now allows many more women to contribute their great talents and capabilities to our national growth and future prosperity. We have to forget tagging child care as a welfare issue. It is not a welfare issue any more. It is a vital part of this government's approach to building and rebuilding a well skilled and capable work force in Australia.

The child-care rebate forms part of the Labor government's child-care policy, which is an extremely comprehensive package that recognises that most parents, at some stage of their working lives, will require affordable access to quality child care. In 1983, when this government was elected, there were approximately 46,000 child-care places available. By the end of the 1993-94 financial year—10 years later—that will have increased to approximately 237,000 places. This government promised to meet all demand for work related child care by the year 2001. From the results to date, and with the implementation of the child-care rebate scheme on 1 July 1994, this promise is well on target.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in Investing in the nation that the child-care rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income. As with other expenses incurred when earning an income, it will not be means tested. The introduction of this scheme recognises at long last the costs that are borne by parents—I reiterate `parents'—and particularly mothers in earning an income. This bill recognises that all working families are entitled to some form of recompense for the cost of work related child care. However, to ensure that this recompense was equitable and that benefits flowed to lower income families, a decision was made to introduce a cash rebate so that families could claim as the expense was incurred.

I will outline the main features of the child-care rebate scheme. The rebate will be payable by mail or in person through Medicare offices of the Health Insurance Commission with effect from 1 July 1994. The rebate will be available to parents who are employed, studying, training or looking for work. It will be paid for any work related child-care expenses for children under 13 years of age. After the first $16 of weekly child-care costs, families can claim 30 per cent of their costs up to a ceiling of $110 per week for one child in care and $220 per week for two or more. The maximum weekly rebate will be $28 per week for one child in care and $61.20 per week for two or more children in care. The rebate will be payable over and above child-care assistance and it will not be income tested. All work related child care in the formal child-care sector will be eligible—long-day care and occasional care centres, family day care, outside school hours care and vacation care.

Informal child care is defined as child care that is not currently eligible for Commonwealth and/or state funding. It can be either in the child's home or in another person's home. In the informal child-care sector, carers have to be 18 years old or over. Parents are excluded from claiming for the cost of caring for their own children. Carers can be a child's stepbrother or stepsister or other relative. Informal carers must meet state or territory regulations relating to informal care where they apply. Eligible child-care expenses must be directly associated with the provision of work related care.

To participate in the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme, families will need to register with the Health Insurance Commission, and it is expected that that is now well under way. To be eligible to claim the rebate families will have to satisfy some criteria. The cash rebate will be available for child-care expenses for the care of children under 13 years of age incurred by families where both parents are engaged in one or more of the following: full-time or part-time work, study, training, or looking for work. In the case of sole parent families, only the custodial parent needs to meet one of these criteria.

Families will be required to substantiate their work force status and the birth dates of the children they wish to register. Families will have the option of allowing the Health Insurance Commission to use Medicare enrolment details to verify birth dates of children. In order to be eligible for the cash rebate, families must be Australian residents as defined under the Social Security Act; that is, they must be Australian citizens, or have a valid entry permit, or a return endorsement, or a resident's return visa. Some categories of non-residents will also be eligible: Australian government sponsored overseas students and hardship cases. Registered families who meet these criteria will be able to claim the child-care cash rebate by presenting receipts for work related child-care expenses incurred with a registered child-care provider from 1 July 1994.

The bill is to be commended. It has opened great, positive initiatives, not only for the working women of Australia, those who wish to become working women and those who are training, but for families, no matter how they are made up. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. This bill proposes amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953.

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986 relate to the recovery of costs of rehabilitation programs provided by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to persons eligible to receive compensation from other sources, such as insurers, for their injuries. Section 26 of the act relates to a client's right to have a decision reviewed by the secretary and to the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. An amendment to section 23(5) brings the legislation into line with what has been common practice for many years. It has been the practice to serve notices in relation to the recovery of rehabilitation costs on insurers prior to the settlement of litigation between the insurer and the insured person, on the basis that the insurer is `the person liable to pay compensation' referred to in the act. It is accepted that no payment would be received until a court case had been settled.

Legal advice indicates that, under section 23(5) of the act, notices should not be served until it has been determined by a court, or by agreement between the parties, that the insurer is liable to pay compensation. The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted and its advice supports the need for legislative amendment. If notices were not sent early it would have a serious effect on the recovery of costs of programs provided and consequently on the revenue targets set for the CRS.

An amendment to section 23(5) of the act will enable notices to be sent to insurers who are potentially liable to pay compensation well before the matter comes before a court or is settled between the parties. The second amendment to section 23 is to subsection (7) which presently requires an insurer not to pay any moneys awarded to the client until the amount owing for the rehabilitation program has been specified by the Commonwealth. It does not require the insurer to discharge the debt to the Commonwealth before paying the client.

Difficulties are often created for the CRS when the insurer pays the client without regard to the sum owing to the Commonwealth and the CRS is obliged to seek to recover the amount owing from the client. It should be noted that even when the payment is received from the insurer, the client has the right to seek to be released from any liability and could, in special circumstances, have all or part of the moneys paid to the Commonwealth refunded. Advice from the department's legal branch supports the need for a change, and the amendment requires payment of the debt to the Commonwealth before paying the remaining award moneys to the client.

The third and final amendment is to section 26(5) of the act where a note has been appended to the subsection to ensure that all clients are advised in writing of their right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the review decision made under section 26 affirms the original decision with which the client was dissatisfied. This would bring the act into line with the requirement in a recent amendment to section 27A of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 which requires advice of appeal rights against reviewable decisions to be given in writing, and defines reviewable decisions to include decisions reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and those taken in an internal review procedure.

The administrative changes to the financial provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 also form part of this bill. The amendments in part 3 of this bill are consequential to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. These amendments aim to ensure that the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 makes adequate provision in relation to the child-care cash rebate functions of the commission. They follow previous amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Act of May 1993.

The new cash rebate system is a major part of this bill. For the people of Gilmore, the people who I represent, I would like to put it in these terms: the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate will cut child-care costs for working families. Around 230,000 families with about 350,000 children in informal and formal child care are expected to benefit from this new non-means tested payment. From 1 July this year, parents using child care while working, training, studying or looking for a job will be eligible for a 30 per cent rebate on the cost of child care. The rebate will be paid for all work related child-care expenses for children under 13.

The cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents. Unlike other concessions for expenses incurred in earning an income, the new child-care cash rebate will not be means tested. The introduction of this scheme marks an enormous change in our attitude towards child care. It recognises that child care is an important economic issue and not just a welfare issue. I will go further to suggest that it is not a women's issue; it is a family issue which relates to our whole population.

The maximum weekly rebate will be $28.20 per week, or around $1,466 each year, for one child in care. An amount of $61.20 per week, or around $3,182 each year, will be paid for two or more children. Families will pay the first $16 of weekly child-care costs and then be able to claim 30 per cent of their costs up to the fee ceiling of $110 per week for one child in care or $220 per week for two or more children. To ensure the payment of the rebate from 1 July, families and child-care providers are urged to register with Medicare by person or by mail as soon as possible.

Because it will be paid for both formal and informal care, the new scheme will also make child care more accessible and affordable. For example, it will be paid for expenses incurred by parents using long day care centres, preschools, family day care, outside school hours care, vacation care, private child care and arrangements including paid care provided in the child's home, although parents may not claim for looking after their own children.

The improvements in child care that have been made by this government in its 10 years of office, the recognition that has been given to child care as a major issue in the employment and social spheres of Australian society and the reorganisation of society that has been taking place are truly amazing. The ability of a person of my age and generation to see my male and female contemporaries having more equal opportunities than perhaps my parents did is an indication of the changes that have taken place in Australian society. Those changes have allowed more egalitarianism and a more efficient and progressive use of the human resources in this country.

A woman going out to work was once thought to be an abomination. However, fortune and intelligence have finally broken through to the point where 51 per cent of Australia's population—that is, the female section of our population—has equal, if not more, opportunities to expand their intellectual ability than comparative males. The sickly thing is that in the past women have been suppressed. They have been prevented from reaching their economic, employment and academic goals and their intellectual capacity. They have not had the basic right of being able to reach their potential.

Fortunately, this is changing. I would not suggest, particularly to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) and the shadow minister at the table, that at any point we have reached equality, because quite clearly we have not. The membership of this chamber is an indication of that. In order to understand the reasons why we have essential division on this issue, one should look at what has happened in the area of child care.

I hope that our moves in the area of child care and the freeing of half the population in order to enable it to play a more pro-active role in our community will change women's desire to be in this place. Quite frankly, many of them look at this place, but they do not have a great desire to come here because, in the view of many people, this place is held in low esteem.

However, I support the suggestion of Jim Carlton, the former member for Mackellar, that we should have 50 per cent female representation by legislation. Each seat should have two representatives—a male and a female. But in order to do that we first have to realise that males and females are human beings that have responsibilities. It is of particular interest for us to realise that we are members of families.

This is the Year of the Family. `Families' is not just a word that can be pulled out every time that, for example, the National Party wants to say something in order to get a warm, glowing feeling. Families are units of individuals. They are an active and dynamic group of relationships.

What has tended to happen in traditional society, both in the developed and undeveloped world, is that an undue part of the physical work has been taken on by one sex in that relationship, predominantly the female sex. In order to even that up, we need to have a realistic approach to the division of labour within the family and the home. No-one can expect an individual to go out and work a 40-hour week or longer and then come back and do the same thing in the home.

Unfortunately, that is exactly what is happening. To the extent that I can possibly do it, I will attempt to alleviate that in my home, because I know that I am also guilty of it. In the last 20 to 25 years, the women in our families have been in the workplace and done their fair share of bringing home the bacon via a pay packet, supplementing the family income or even being the sole income earner. They have also been expected to look after the children.

Child care liberates women and enables them to reach their potential in the employment market if they so desire. Their being liberated and not tied to those targets requires financial backing, which comes from the provisions of the new child-care cash rebate scheme in the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Its set-up through the use of the existing infrastructure—that is, Medicare, et cetera—is most appropriate. It avoids the duplication of infrastructure, which all too often happens, and bureaucracies, which may not be beneficial for the long-term economic efficiency of our community.

I highlight the fact that this government has really delivered in the areas in which we have promised to deliver. I take a great deal of pride in standing up here as a member of the government. In the March election, I was one person who put our record on child care as one of the reasons why I should be elected. Our promises of continued action in the area of child care is one reason why we should be returned to office again and again.

This government has delivered and continues to deliver on one of the most important issues that faces working families. We have delivered in a way that is fair and equitable. We have delivered in a way so that there is social justice. We have delivered in a way so that the people who need access will obtain access. I suggest that those people who are responsible—and I see one of them in the chamber, the parliamentary secretary at the table—are owed a great debt of gratitude by the people of Australia because of the way that they have come forward and put this to the Australian people in such a good and wholesome fashion.

I can give an indication of the child-care costs that confront the average family. The arrangements that are made in this case are a little peculiar; nonetheless, this example is relevant. A certain woman I know wished to have significant time with her children, so instead of working five days a week she chose to work three days a week. Her remuneration was such that, after she had paid child care for the three days that she did work, she ended up with $150 a fortnight. These arrangements will substantially change that. I know about that example because that woman happens to be my wife.

I suggest that to a woman with intelligence and career objectives there is more to life than just her children. It is not a case of fleeing from those children; it is a case of having conversations with people over the age of three and having interests broader than just the marital home, the garden and the shops. Employment allows these women to have a broader perspective on life. It allows them to have broader interests. It allows them to relieve some of the strain that comes from being a parent.

I love my children very much. I hope that the relationship is reciprocal and that it is very loving and close. But I can assure honourable members that 24 hours straight with the little beggars and one starts to climb the walls. There is need for people to have forms of escape. Employment is one of those forms of escape. It is a form of escape which allows people to develop their own interests and further their own intellectual capacities.

I believe that these arrangements will enable more people to be involved in our work force and enable us to have a very compassionate attitude towards the new family that is evolving in the Australian social scene. The new family in the Australian social scene involves two people working, whether it be full time or part time, and having broader relationships outside. Hopefully we will be able to tie in with the broader concept of what previously enriched our lives—that is, the broader family context of grandparents and other family members.

I thank the government for its action in this regard. The responsibility has been heavy. There are a lot of competing needs in the community. For this government to recognise that child care is one of the major issues in the last decade of this century puts us in good stead to allow all members of our community and all members of our society to participate at a level commensurate with their ability.

If this enables women to advance to the higher ranks in business, if this enables women to go forward and take their rightful place in our community, I think that in the longer term, when in the future the history of this nation in this century is told by honest players—people such as Manning Clark—we will find that this Labor government will be held up in high esteem as a government that cared about its people, both male and female. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do, yet again.
—Please proceed.

—I will explain very briefly. I am not going to debate the issues, but a certain matter has to be put straight on the record. Earlier today in debate on the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) made certain statements in relation to me and my expressed views on subjects covered by this bill. PARA.TAB: Earlier this evening the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) referred to the speech by the honourable member for Moreton and quoted from a speech that I made here in October last year on the subject of child-care rebates. Although I had requested a copy of the green of the speech from the honourable member for Moreton, I did not have it at the time, so it was not possible for me to reply immediately. Obviously it was important that I had the actual words in front of me. I will quote what the honourable member for Moreton said in relation to views I expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is this the honourable member for Moreton or the honourable member for Bass?

—I just wanted to say what I was making a personal explanation about. Effectively the honourable member for Bass said that my personal explanation was not correct.
