DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) is apologising for some of the rather extreme positions she has taken in here in the past. The Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is an omnibus bill that covers a number of amendments to various pieces of health and human services legislation. In particular, the amendments made by part III of the bill are consequential to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. That act was another important step to ensure that child care is affordable for all working families. From 1 July this year parents using child care while in employment or while training, studying or looking for work will be able to claim a cash rebate for part of their child-care expenses.

PARA.TAB: An estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from that scheme. It would be good if the honourable member for Moncrieff could take note of these particular statistics. This piece of legislation will help 230,000 families with 358,000 children. That is something that she ought to be a bit interested in rather than nattering about on the side.

The Commonwealth cash rebate will be administered by the Health Insurance Commission on behalf of the Department of Human Services and Health, and the cash rebate will be payable by mail or in person through Medicare offices of the Health Insurance Commission. I think that that is a very worthwhile social reform. In fact, I believe that in years to come this government will be remembered for its initiatives focusing on supporting the family unit.

In my years as a member of the federal parliament, it is hard to remember a more popular initiative than the child-care cash rebate. This fulfils another promise that the government made during the election campaign. I have received hundreds of phone calls from constituents commending the government on this initiative. I think the opposition would be hard put to find one parent who did not believe that he or she needed this assistance. Even among the opposition, only one honourable member has stood in this House today to oppose the legislation, and I think that, in a sense, that might be voting with the constituents.

It is unfortunate that opposition members are carping that this initiative should be income tested when in the same breath they are telling taxpayers that they want to introduce income splitting so that well-to-do people earning over $100,000 a year can pay less tax. I do not know where they think there is any equity in that but, then again, faulty thinking is something that in recent years we have come to expect from the opposition on matters such as this. I think that opposition members know that few households with young children earn more than $100,000. In fact, according to the 1991 census, in my electorate parents earning more than $100,000 represented just 0.1 per cent—about 80 people.

I have to say that, if the government can look after the rest of those people and provide some assistance, I think that is pretty fair. In fact, I believe all members of this House, be they in government or opposition, would be hard pressed to find, in my electorate or anyone else's, a great number of families in the $100,000 income bracket with children young enough to require child care. Maybe the honourable member for Moncrieff, who represents a very affluent part of the Gold Coast, has a lot of these very high income families in her electorate, but I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, representing an electorate in Victoria, and I, from Sydney, do not have a lot of families in our electorates that earn such incomes.

To give some examples of the circumstances in my electorate, recently the Rockdale Council, which covers part of my electorate and part of the electorate of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), completed a demographic survey of the municipality. Some very interesting results came out of that, and I would like to share them with the House this evening. Of the 30,400 households, families make up 70 per cent, and 70 per cent of the families have dependent children. Of those households with dependent children, 6.9 per cent are lone parents and, of those working parents with dependent children, 73 per cent employ the full-time use of child care in one form or another.

However, it should be noted that Rockdale is a rather settled area, and the figures would be relatively low compared with other parts of my electorate. Nearly one quarter of the people who live in Rockdale live alone or are elderly. In the adjacent Hurstville and Canterbury local government areas, for which I have not got any figures available at present, I will hazard a guess that the number of young families with dependent children would be twice the number of Rockdale. There is no doubt in my mind that working families with children are a very significant proportion of our society. I believe, and the government believes, that they deserve the very best we can provide in this, the International Year of the Family. That is what they are receiving from this government—assistance where they need it and when they need it. It is a pity that the opposition cannot join with us in totally supporting this very worthwhile initiative.

Another important aspect of this initiative is the recognition of the informal child care sector. In the past, things such as fee relief—which I will go into shortly—were available for people in the formal child care area. But for the first time this legislation takes account of the fact that a large number of people have their children cared for by family members or friends. The government is taking account of that and providing assistance in that area. I think that the overwhelmingly larger part of the provision of child care is in that informal area.

The government's record on the provision of child care is unequalled, with record growth in the number of places—increasing from 46,000 when we came to office to 257,000 by June this year—and our interim target will be 300,000 places by 1996-97. Nevertheless, that still does not provide enough assistance in the informal child care area. As I said earlier, for the first time—and only under a Labor government—the child-care cash rebate acknowledges the work of neighbourhood baby-sitters and of grandparents. This aspect alone is a very big leap forward in assisting working parents and ensuring the provision of child care for them.

It is very interesting to note what one might say is the malappropriation of child-care services in Australia; that those parents who come from middle class areas tend to have far greater access to the formal child-care system of preschools, nurseries, family day care, et cetera. For people in working class electorates, who by dint of economic circumstances in many cases have to make a decision for both parents to work, there is far less access to a variety of child-care provisions.

It used to gall me in the past to see those middle class areas in my city of Sydney having a disproportionate amount of child-care centres and people in working class electorates such as mine—particularly the very working class areas of my electorate such as Campsie and Lakemba—having access to mostly family day care, neighbourhood friends or relations. With family day care, people got some assistance but, if people had their children being minded in the informal area, there was no assistance at all. I think one of the great provisions of this piece of legislation is a mechanism to allow us to pay people in the informal sector.

The government has never been content to rest on its laurels. In addition to the child-care cash rebate, which we are dealing with in this legislation, we have already introduced a home child-care allowance. Today, as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the white paper on employment and growth, we will be introducing a new parenting allowance. The parenting allowance will provide payment to one parent free of any obligation to seek work. There will be a more generous income test if the person chooses to combine parenting with paid work. It will mean an extra $59 a week for over 120,000 parents. I think that is something that members of the government and the Prime Minister himself, who has taken a very close interest in this area, can be very proud of. I hope that the opposition, in its response to the white paper later on in the week, will show some decency and embrace at least this portion of the white paper.

This allowance will be paid at the maximum of $132.65 per week when the recipient's income is less than $231 per week, reducing to $30 per week when the partner's income exceeds $378 per week. The home child-care allowance, scheduled for introduction in September this year, will be incorporated into the parenting allowance from July 1995. This will mean that the person receiving the parenting allowance will retain a $30 per week non-taxable payment irrespective of his or her partner's income. This allowance, along with other changes to the payment of social security benefits, including the partner allowance, recognises the right of individuals to be paid.

In introducing these initiatives which focus on families, the government is recognising that Australia's most valuable resource for the future development of both our economy and our society is our children. Ensuring that our children receive quality care at the beginning of their lives is one of the major priorities of the government. When that is coupled with the government's support for schooling and training after schooling, it shows that the government believes that we should be giving particularly low income families the best chance we can.

These are things that we can look back on in the future and say that, if we did nothing else in our lives, being part of a government that brought forward proposals such as these was a very important thing to do. These initiatives will be described as an apt response by the government in the International Year of the Family. But I think they represent much more than that. They represent an historic shift in the way we view our society working and rightly recognise the importance of the family unit to the social fabric of our nation.

As I said earlier, we can look back with pride on a number of very worthwhile initiatives that the government has introduced. It is worth reconsidering those. In 1983, when we came to office, there were 46,000 operational child-care places. There are now more than 220,000 child-care places, which is an increase of 478 per cent. We reached the figure of 220,000 in December last year. The 1993-94 budget provided for the provision of 31,000 new places, bringing the total number of places that we hope to provide by the end of this financial year to just under 240,000.

We have also provided over 26,000 places to the children of clients on JET, the jobs, employment and training scheme. This scheme assists sole parents entering or returning to the work force. The overall success rate of JET clients being assisted to find a child-care place is currently running at approximately 96 per cent.

The Commonwealth outlays on child care have grown from $65 million in 1983, when we came into power, to over $680 million this financial year. That is an incredible increase which shows the commitment the government has to this area. But we are still some way from meeting all the work related demand for child care. Our 1993 election commitment was to meet all work related child-care demand by the year 2000. The government has set an interim target of 300,000 places by 1996-97, and we are well on track to meet that target.

I refer to a number of other schemes that have been outlined tonight. One of them which I mentioned earlier is child-care assistance, which was formerly called fee relief. That is provided to assist families on low and middle incomes with the cost of child care. It is provided to approximately 175,000 families. The Commonwealth outlays on child-care assistance are approximately $500 million. I think that is also something that we can be very proud of.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, there are 344,000 children from 275,000 families using Commonwealth funded child-care services. That is a proud record which the opposition, with all its fuzzy thinking, is unable, unwilling or just too plain mean to appreciate. This government has made child care affordable for ordinary working people. That was our aim and we have met that aim.

My wife has worked on and off for most of our married life. I know how hard it has been from time to time for her to have access to child care. I know that the access that young married couples or other people with young families have now is far better than it was when my children were young. In the main, that is because of the activities of this federal Labor government.

I commend this bill to the House. It has been another milestone in the road we have taken to provide equity in our society. I congratulate the minister. I congratulate the Prime Minister, in particular, for the interest he has taken in this very worthwhile program. I think it shows that the government, unlike the opposition, is meeting the goal of the International Year of the Family. I think we can modestly say that we can hold our heads high in this particular regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) on his contribution to the debate relating to child care. I am very pleased to be speaking on the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Since joining this House I have spoken on several occasions on matters to do with health and human services.

PARA.TAB: The health of Australia is a matter that must be very greatly at the forefront of concern of any government of our nation. We are a society and not primarily an economy. Health is not a product; it is a human right. I have always thought that it is a very unfortunate situation that health in Australia is a matter of such contention and that such diametrical hostility exists between the government and opposition on this issue.

The support for Medicare and the full range of public medical health is extremely widespread in Australia. The opposition parties do themselves and Australia no good by refusing to commit themselves genuinely and irrevocably to the concept of a public medical system financed by a levy on wages and salaries.

Honourable members will be aware that I am here because I defeated the opposition spokesman on health in the seat of Lowe. Health was a major issue. I can assure the House that the fear of the health provisions of Fightback was very real and very widespread. Women especially were concerned that the opposition would in fact have a worse system than it was actually promoting in Fightback. Why does the opposition still cling to this view that health is a product like Coca-Cola or jeans, a product to be sold to those who can buy and be denied to those who cannot? I know that the opposition said that this was not its policy, but I can tell honourable members that people, especially women, were convinced that this would be the real outcome of the opposition's health policies.

The result: major distrust of the opposition on this matter of health. This distrust continues and again, especially amongst women voters, it is a major communication problem for the opposition. Now one may ask why should I be worried if the opposition insists on clinging to a health policy outlook that is poison at the ballot box. I am concerned because I see the genuine fear and worry of many men and women on low income levels at every election. They fear the result which would see Medicare dismantled and they fear the decline in their families' health from such an act. To remove such fear I would suggest that the opposition parties actually have a change of heart and embrace the public health system as exemplified by Medicare.

Realistically, I am not too confident that the opposition will take such excellent advice. In urging this I am not saying that there is no place for private health; there is. I am not opposed to private health insurance or private hospitals; they have their place. Australia is a success because we can fit together public and private facilities into one society. By taking this cooperative approach, we include everyone in our vision of Australia.

Australians want to be included and they want to belong. They want security. They want a decent standard of living where they do not have to worry that illness will crush them either financially or socially. We Australians are actually different people from others in the world who speak English. Our society is a serious success because of our peculiar avoidance of the pitfalls of class, race and religious bigotries. How this came about is a good question for historians. I will not pretend to know, but what I do know is that we are different because we look upon each other not as competitors for scarce resources but as cooperators in building a decent place to live. This smooth plain of cooperation is not perfectly smooth. Some Australians still see health and human services as a great field for profit and enrichment.

I am insistent that highly trained and dedicated medical staff must be properly paid and work in proper conditions. However, I would remind the House that health and human services do not always lend themselves to the achievement of a profit. Can the Flying Doctor Service turn a profit? Can major children's hospitals turn a profit? Can medical research always turn a profit? The ideas of the opposition lead many of us to think that a coalition government—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am very reluctant to do this because the honourable member is making an interesting speech. But I think she is misled as to the content of the bill that we are debating. We are getting a speech on health. In fact this bill is not about health at all. The Health Insurance Commission is only involved because it is being used as the means to pay the child-care cash rebate. The issue is one of child care, it is not one of health provisions, insurance or anything like that.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—As is the custom in speeches on the second reading, the debate usually involves public policy. An honourable member's speech can range across public policy being affected by the bill. While not acceding to the point of order, I just point that out and leave it to the honourable member for Lowe to ensure that her remarks are addressed towards public policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is a general bill on human services and health. Although there are specific clauses, all previous deputy speakers have allowed in relation to this bill a wide-ranging debate on a whole range of issues, including the speech made by the honourable member for Moncrieff.
—I thank the parliamentary secretary for his assistance. But I have ruled on the matter.

—On the point of order raised by the parliamentary secretary, which is a separate point of order from the one you have ruled on: I would remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, what was said in the minister's second reading speech. He said that the amendments are largely of a minor procedural nature and are aimed at rectifying a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen. Quite frankly, listening to the honourable member's speech, she must have picked up the wrong copy, thinking it was a different bill. I really ask you to call her back to the subject matter of the bill before this chamber.
—I am sure she will do that.
—I take the interpretation that even though the issue of child care relates directly to this bill there can be a wider definition in terms of health issues as well. So I think it is quite in order—
—That is not what the Deputy Speaker just said, so you better just rail it in.
—You really are very rude.
—The honourable member will address her remarks through the chair.

—I apologise. In my electorate of Lowe, 14.5 per cent of people have shown a need for child care for children from 0-5 years of age. It has one of the highest demands for child care. This government has seen the need for child care by these people. We know, as we have heard in the speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) this afternoon, that this need has been further catered for in the white paper on employment.

PARA.TAB: But clearly we have a situation where child care has gone to two different categories: people who have been needing more facilities and people who have been needing child care not only for employment but for the seeking of employment. Clearly there has been a great need to see a financial commitment by the government to those who pay for child care. Of course, there was the previous situation where people were able to get child care allowances that were means tested. For people who had been using other means of child care, be they private arrangements, nannies, grandparents, et cetera, there was a difference that had to be met. Clearly we now have a situation where the government has met this need by bringing in the new child-care arrangements.

I would also like to make some reference to AIDS, if I may. I hope this will be in order, Mr Deputy Speaker, with regards to the fullness of this bill. As many members are aware, the AIDS epidemic is spreading across the world. Scientists are losing hope that an effective vaccine will be developed in the foreseeable future. In some African cities one in three of the population is HIV positive. Blood can only be accepted from primary school children. The World Health Organisation estimates that 45 million people will be HIV positive within six years. In Europe and America there are signs that the disease is spreading, especially among the poor. Around the world there are about 15 vaccines under development. However, it may not be possible to find one that protects against all of the strains of the virus.

At the end of 1993, nearly one million AIDS cases had been formally notified by the World Health Organisation. However, the real figure is likely to be more than three times this, with two-thirds of the total in sub-Saharan Africa. The AIDS catastrophe is expected to dramatically slow population growth, lower life expectancy and raise child mortality rates in every one of the world's poorest countries.

For example, in Uganda, a member of the Commonwealth, life expectancy by 2010 will be 32 years, down from 59 years in 1990. In the same period, Thailand, with whom we expect to trade profitably, will see its life expectancy fall from 75 years in 1980 to 45 by 2010. To take the Thailand example further, child mortality rates are expected to rise more than fivefold over the current—

TALK.START.PARA: —How is this related to child-care rebates?

—Because this issue is very relevant to issues of health as well. In Thailand, child mortality rates are expected to rise more than fivefold from the current 20 deaths per thousand born to 110 deaths per thousand born in the year 2010. Unfortunately, all the various international agencies agree on these shocking statistics. This is a matter of the gravest concern for Australia and the world. We would be well advised to take this epidemic very seriously and not delude ourselves that this is a matter that only affects a certain group of people and, therefore, the rest of us need not worry.

PARA.TAB: This House has a serious moral duty to the nation to look at this problem in a totally scientific way and not to wrap itself up in smug self-righteous attitudes. Even if we limit ourselves to the most basic level of our economic ties to the rest of the world, I would remind the House that half the world's population in 1994 was to be found in just five countries: China, India, the United States of America, Brazil and Russia. These countries have a major problem with AIDS and not one of these countries is handling the epidemic very well at all. The capacity for destruction by AIDS is unparalleled in modern history. For example, in Brazil, Haiti, Thailand and 13 African countries, the AIDS epidemic will slow growth rates so dramatically that, by 2010, these countries will have 101 million fewer people than had been estimated in 1990.

For those who smugly suggest that AIDS is just an epidemic amongst homosexual men, the Asian Development Bank has recently written that the AIDS epidemic in Asia will be a higher threat to women than to men. The epidemic is certain to have major socioeconomic implications for Asia and the Pacific. At present, more Asian men than women are infected with HIV. But there is strong evidence that social conditions in Asia, particularly south Asia, may lead to a trend where many more women become infected. The reasons for expected rising infections among women are biological factors: frequent births, which may require blood transfusions; and the low status of women, which inhibits them from acquiring the means to protect themselves from AIDS.

In Australia the situation is a lot better than in any other country. Proper scientific approaches to the problem have existed from the beginning. Adequate education, funding and community concern have resulted in a serious assault on this epidemic. Many people are to be thanked for this timely and, so far, successful campaign. The typical, sensible, bipartisan Australian approach has paid off and I, for one, am most anxious to see that this continues.

In the weeks ahead, I will be visiting the AIDS ward of St Vincents Hospital in Sydney to see and hear for myself at first-hand the current situation with AIDS in Australia. I would urge all members to take such an opportunity to acquaint themselves with the most up-to-date intelligence on this medical and social catastrophe. Australians have a proud record in medical matters. Our predecessor parliaments have always been supporters of medical research, be it for polio, diphtheria or any other communicable disease. I am confident that this 37th parliament can be worthy of its forebears and stay up to the mark on this epidemic of AIDS for as long as necessary. I commend the bill to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable members who have spoken on the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. We have certainly had a very wide ranging and interesting debate. We have heard from the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne), the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith), the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson). So we have had a very significant debate on and contributions to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We have also had the occurrence of a very unique event, in that in the middle of the debate—we started the debate in the early afternoon—we had the presentation before this parliament of one of the most revolutionary pieces of policy by any government for many years. I am referring to the white paper on employment, Working Nation. Elements of that paper affect the issues that have been discussed and, indeed, some of the questions raised by some of the speakers. I will refer to that later.

Let me begin on one point made by the honourable member for Moncrieff. She made a number of points and she would be very disappointed if I did not respond to them. The first important point was, `Why isn't Dr Lawrence here to handle the legislation?' Obviously the honourable member for Moncrieff knows that I have responsibility within the government for legislation in the Department of Human Services and Health, and I have held that responsibility on behalf of a number of ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the minister has the responsibility too.

—The honourable member for Moncrieff obviously does not understand the way things operate. Perhaps she ought to go and study the system as it is operated. But the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has approved the policies and the legislation, and the department has been involved scrupulously, with the very hard work of our officers, in putting forward the legislation. That point made by the honourable member for Moncrieff was a furphy. She was trying to raise the point as though the minister were not concerned with the issues involved here. The minister is very much concerned with the issues raised here in this bill and with issues that honourable members have raised, including those raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff. I refer to the issues of child care and the home child-care allowance.
—She has to take your word for that.

—I am telling her. Of course, the honourable member for Moncrieff, if she can get the call from her leader, might ask the minister a question at some appropriate time and she will get a further explanation of whatever she wants to know.

PARA.TAB: Some of my colleagues tried to reply to the issues raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff. She took a number of points of order and made a personal explanation because she did not consider that they had properly dealt with her arguments. She accused them of not referring to the right policy. But, of course, one of the problems we have with the opposition is that it appears to consider it is okay to means test some things but not others, without any rationale on its part whatever. I could not follow why she objected last year to the means testing of certain things and then objected when certain other things were not means tested. We seem to have some confusion on the part of the opposition as to this whole issue of what is to be means tested and what is not.

Obviously, it would be good to have a general philosophical position on this, but that is a vain hope, given that the opposition as a whole has very little philosophical position on social issues. It needs to think through some issues. Maybe it could learn some things by talking to some of the conservative parties in other countries that have moved beyond the New Right Thatcherist ideas in economics and have tried to do something on social policy. The opposition might actually develop some social policy and we might be able to have a debate in this chamber.

As the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) mentioned during question time today, it is no good the opposition simply picking one little piece and saying, `You should spend more money on that or you should spend more money on another little policy' when its key economic spokespersons are saying, `Cut out billions of dollars, $5 billion, $6 billion or $7 billion, from the budget,' which essentially means the social budget. That is what it means and meant in the last election: the social budget. If the opposition were going to cut that money out of the social budget, it cannot come in here and demand all sorts of extra spending. That basically was the argument from the honourable member for Moncrieff. Her argument was that we should spend more money on the parent who is at home, whether the wife or the husband, and looking after the children.

The government, unlike the Liberal Party, is actually concerned with this issue and has brought forward the home child-care allowance. What is more, the government has funded it, notwithstanding the fact that the opposition keeps saying, `Cut the budget.' At the same time, we have funded it.

TALK.START.PARA: —By borrowing overseas.

—The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney, says `By borrowing'. What is he going to fund it with? Money from trees? The reality is that we have to face real economic and social decisions. There is always a balance judgment between economic and social decisions. What differentiates the Labor Party from the opposition is that we have always been involved in balancing social justice and economic development.

PARA.TAB: The balance between social justice and economic development is the key issue. That is what government is all about in the modern world: finding the right balance, not ignoring social priorities, drastically cutting things and creating an underclass as Mrs Thatcher did in Britain. The British people are still suffering years afterwards and will probably continue to suffer for many years into the future because of the lack of concern for social justice and social policy.

The honourable member for Moncrieff talked about recognising the role of women or men at home. The government has issued a number of papers talking about the recognition of their role and has actually put into place the home child-care allowance. We had another interesting development today with the presentation of the white paper. What do we see in the white paper? We see a further development of this matter by the government with the introduction of the new parenting allowance, which will further support parents at home. What is most interesting is that this is a clear social justice measure. In particular, 120,000 low income families in Australia will receive an extra $59 a week on average.

We are talking about social justice in action. We are not getting up and saying, `This ought to be done,' and then turning around without the money to pay for it because the economic spokespeople are trying to please certain right wing think-tanks around the place by talking about massive cuts to the budget. Those opposite cannot have it both ways. The opposition might have dropped Fightback and it might have dropped all of its policies, but it will not be allowed to get away with the idea that it can talk about big cuts to the budget on the one hand and about social concern and social policies on the other.

Why did the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) issue a statement attacking the central concept of the jobs compact the other day? He attacked that idea. In attacking that idea what was he talking about? He was talking about the central social justice idea to assist unemployed people. He did that because he recognised that if his party were in government it could not afford it. If one looks at the Fightback package, one will see that the coalition was going to significantly reduce spending in these areas. How then would the unemployed, especially the long-term unemployed, have been able to benefit?

When talking about people's choices, as the honourable member for Moncrieff did, especially choices for women, the basic standard of living which we are able to supply is of crucial importance. The choices people face are not abstract; they have to be real. They have to be based in real, concrete, economic and social circumstances. It is no good saying to a person facing abject poverty, `You've got some choices.' That person has to actually be offered concrete assistance to make those choices real. This is what this government is doing in relation to child care and in relation to assistance for women, and in certain cases men, staying at home looking after children.

We do believe in the right of choice, contrary to what the honourable member for Moncrieff said. But unlike the opposition, which talks about the need for there to be a right of choice while not providing any substance or any money to support social programs, we actually find the money by a difficult balance between economic and social requirements. That is what is most important with respect to those choices.

I totally reject the allegations made by the honourable member for Moncrieff. We are doing more all the time to offer those choices. Choices are becoming increasingly available to women who stay at home, who seek opportunities in the work force or who participate in society in other respects. They are becoming increasingly available to them because of the policies of the government in relation to child care on the one hand and to support for those who choose to stay at home on the other. It is not a question of not offering equal choices. Equal choices are being offered and people will be increasingly taking them up.

I come back to the point I made a moment ago. There is no point talking about choices in the abstract. There has to be a firm, serious commitment to funding. There has to be a firm, serious commitment to working out the bureaucratic arrangements that will deliver these things. That is what government is about. It is not just a question of making pronouncements. These things are never easy. It is difficult to administer these things properly and to make sure that the people who deserve them get them. Of course, we are open to suggestions from the opposition in relation to these matters, but what we have had from most of the spokespeople from the opposition is a refusal to even concentrate on these issues.

The honourable member for Moncrieff talked in her speech about the participation of women in parliament. That is a very distant topic from this bill. However, she managed to talk for five minutes on the participation of women in parliament. We will assume that the debate was wide ranging at that time. She protested about the honourable member for Lowe talking about health on the health bill, yet she talked for about five minutes on the participation of women in parliament.

I think it is a very important matter. The honourable member for Moncrieff made the interesting point that there are few women in parliament who were here at the time when they were actually rearing children. I think that is a matter that needs some attention. With respect to the participation of women in parliament, obviously the provision of significant child care and the provision of allowances and support will be very important in assisting them to participate more fully in society, including in the political process, and therefore be able to take up opportunities when they arise.

We do not disagree on that point. I do not think the honourable member should try to make some political point against the government by claiming that it is not interested in supporting women who wish to stay at home. As I have mentioned, the allowances announced today further support that, especially for low income earners.

I also want to refer to some other important matters which are quite relevant to the child-care allowance. It is very important for people to recognise that they can apply for this allowance now, and they should be applying for it. It is clear that the benefit from that allowance will further strengthen families and the participation of women and their role in society. I strongly urge people to become aware that they can apply for the allowance now. We need to do more to encourage people to do so.

I conclude by congratulating the government and the ministers involved for putting forward the white paper, especially for what it does for the general issues of social justice that we are discussing here. The white paper makes a tremendous contribution in the area of social justice. It gives a massive $6.5 billion injection to a whole range of programs: programs to assist women, young people in trouble and a whole range of disadvantaged people—those from non-English speaking backgrounds, Aboriginal people, those with disabilities and the homeless—and, most importantly, programs to assist the long-term unemployed to get back to work.

In this the International Year of the Family it is very important to realise when we are talking about helping people—especially women—that most of us participate in society because of our family circumstances. For example, if in a two person family both people are long-term unemployed, desperation occurs—a certain sense of inability to participate in and be part of society. The formation of an underclass of people who feel rejected by society is a very serious matter. The white paper has addressed that, which is a very good thing. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be appropriate at this point to put a couple of points straight that have arisen in the course of debate. Early in my speech on the second reading I made reference to the fact that I was disappointed that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was not here, given that the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill is her first bill.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), in his reply said that I was in error. Did I not know that, as parliamentary secretary, he did legislation? He said that the minister approves policy and legislation and then he handles it here. I am well used to the honourable member for Calwell handling legislation for the Minister for Health, but the previous Minister for Health was a senator, and I really did not expect former Senator Richardson to appear in this chamber and handle this legislation.

I was disappointed that, now that we have a minister who is a member of the House of Representatives, she is not here. This is not meant in any way to denigrate the parliamentary secretary; he knows I would not do that. But I just remind the parliamentary secretary that this arrangement can lead to an unsatisfactory situation. There have been times in debate in the committee stage in this House when certain matters have been raised—amendments and explanations and so on—and the parliamentary secretary was not in the best position to reply for the government. Instead, we were given an indication that the government could well consider favourably the amendment but was not capable of doing it here because the minister was in the Senate. So the House had to pass legislation which, it was acknowledged, could be deficient and send it to the Senate to be fixed up. I do not think that is something that any member of this House would like.

I want to knock on the head the idea that, because a minister has a parliamentary secretary, that minister has absolutely no obligation to this House and that the parliamentary secretary has the obligation to be here for legislation. I recommend to the parliamentary secretary at the table that he take a look at the record of, for example, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean). That minister also has a parliamentary secretary, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). Nevertheless, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training makes a point of reading his own second reading speeches, of being present for his own debates, of moving his own replies to second readings, and carrying any debate that there may be in the detailed consideration of the bill. I lament the idea that ministers no longer have any sort of obligation to the parliament when it comes to the handling of their own legislation. That is enough on that subject.

Coming to the subject of the debate, the parliamentary secretary seemed to be very proud of the fact that the home child-care allowance is funded. I remind the parliamentary secretary that rebates for child-care costs, where they are costs of employment, and equivalent payments for home child-care allowance were part of Fightback. Those very generous measures were part of the opposition's policy before the last election. It was after we had announced the details of our policy that the government came up with policies that it certainly had never mentioned before but which appeared to be equivalent to the coalition's policies.

What the government did not mention at any stage, of course, was that it was going to fund the home child-care allowance by cashing out the dependent spouse rebate. I have already indicated that there is no problem with that. There have been many reports over the years that show that the dependent spouse rebate was a very poorly targeted benefit and that this is a better way of targeting it.

However, those who might have been tempted to vote Labor, believing that there was going to be increased support for the family where a parent was full time at home playing the parenting role, have been disappointed because there is a cashing out of the benefit. There is no increased benefit.

I wish I could share the parliamentary secretary's enthusiasm for the announcement of the parenting allowance today. I am going to wait until I see the fine print, as indeed the voters of Australia should have done. They did not wait for the fine print on the government's election promises last time. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! No honourable member having risen, I call the honourable member for Moncrieff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must hark back to the matter of family payments and certain statements that have been made here today. For example, I made reference in my speech—a reference which has been ignored by government members since—to the family allowance which was introduced by the Fraser government. This was achieved partly through a cashing out of the dependent child rebate. The major part of the cost of the introduction of the family allowance was achieved by means of very vastly increased family payments derived from the increase in the then fuel excise.
—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1 April 1994 amendments to the fringe benefits tax have been implemented which have caused considerable concern throughout the community. Small businessmen and women have been placed in a position where company owned assets previously exempt from the fringe benefits tax now qualify. The concern which has been raised with me has been initiated by an elector within the Cowan electorate, Mr Brian Aitken of Kingsley. He has asked ask me to present his case to the parliament. Needless to say, this is only one example of the many businesses within the electorate of Cowan and throughout Australia that are concerned about these amendments. Mr Aitken writes:

SPEECH.PARA: I am an insurance broker contracted to a major insurance broking organisation, and my wife and I operate through a proprietary limited company servicing insurance needs for some 500 clients, utilising the facilities, systems and backup of a major insurance broking house. I have an office at home, however by necessity, and convenience, travel to the inner city office where I utilise the computer systems and clerical backup which is provided.

It is necessary for me to use my car regularly in carrying out my business and to be available on demand to visit any such clients as may require my services from time to time. In addition I need to be mobile to respond to any new business opportunities that may arise. I have chosen to purchase a regular parking spot close to the office (approximately 200 metres). For that I pay $225 per calendar month. Up until 1 April 1994 that cost was a tax deduction as a business expense reasonably incurred in earning my income. From 1 April 1994, with the cynical wave of a pen, the federal government has determined that such an expense is deemed to be a fringe benefit in that the parking paid for my company (as indeed the vehicle is owned by my company) and the company must pay fringe benefits tax on the cost of the parking.
Mr Aitken continues by pointing out the bureaucracy which he is now facing to resolve the issue. He says:

I am told that if I can establish that I am absent from my office in town for more than four hours per day I may be exempt from this impost, but as I maintain a regular parking spot this will be difficult to establish. In addition, because of the nature of business, such activity, whilst it may be the case for several days, may not be the case on every day and therefore I will need to prove such absence from the office and apportion a comparative cost accordingly. The clerical and accounting costs involved in such an exercise will be horrendous.

Whilst it may be that some people could obtain a fringe benefit by having an employer pay for parking in an area close to an office, I am not completely convinced of this. I fail to see how it could be deemed that I am obtaining a fringe benefit whatsoever by my company paying for a parking spot which is necessarily required to enable me to carry out my duties as a director of that company and consequently earn my income. I see the cost as merely another cost in running a motor vehicle which is a necessary tool of my trade and of my business. My wife and I own a family car which we use for such family occasions, and rarely is the business car used for such private activities.

While the amendment to the fringe benefits tax that Mr Aitken is alluding to may have seemed a good idea in theory, it is obvious that it is yet another example of the ineffectiveness in practice. Like the Family Law Act and the Child Support Agency, it seemed like a good idea at the time. It is typical of this Labor government. It has clearly stated the myth again this week that it is supporting small business. I would cite Mr Aitken of Kingsley as an example of the way the Labor government ignores the needs of small business and the business community as a whole in Australia and continues to run rampant through the ever decreasing stock it has with small businesses. I ask that the government, if it is sincere about looking after small business, consider the needs of small business in the fringe benefits tax area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Royalauto of April 1994 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Fourteen times a day the brand new $5 million, 750-tonne Queenscliff-Sorrento ferry links the Mornington and Bellarine Peninsulas on a picturesque and calm 35-minute voyage.

PARA.TAB: Ferry fares? They vary slightly according to the make of vehicle and time of year but a guide is for a family sedan, $35 for one way, plus $3 for each adult and $2 for children aged five to 15.
The Queenscliff can carry as many as 60 vehicles and 500 passengers on each crossing of Port Phillip Bay.
John Mackeddie, general manager of Peninsula Searoad Transport, says it has rarely missed its scheduled quota of 14 crossings each day.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the same Mr John Mackeddie that started a hovercraft business with money from the VEDC and left a concrete ramp down at Frankston. I believe that the Frankston people are paying for that to be cleaned up and taken away as a result of the hovercraft service going broke. I received a letter about this ferry from one of my constituents, who wrote to the ferry company. The letter states:
I travelled last week on your new Queenscliff to Sorrento ferry accompanied by my family, a member of which is in a wheelchair, a young woman paralysed from waist down with Multiple Sclerosis.
To my horror I found no facilities whatsoever for such people. From the car level there is no lift to the loungeroom and all facilities are upstairs.

On talking to one of the officers of this vessel, I was told of the rush to make this boat available for the Christmas period and was advised she could either remain in the car or in her wheelchair on the car level.

I must state that as a ferry it is very comfortable for the normal homeo sapien. Was it not made mandatory that all tourist and recreation facilities must include at least one facility for wheelchair victims.
Thank God she did not require the use of a toilet or become seasick. Can you imagine this dilemma?
I would strongly recommend that you give this deplorable situation your urgent attention especially as it was awarded a Tourism Award for Transportation 1993.

I contacted the federal Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) to ascertain for which areas the federal government has responsibility in this matter. The car ferry operates only within Victoria and as such falls under the jurisdiction of the Marine Board of Victoria. The Commonwealth's marine safety authority, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, has no jurisdiction over vessels operating intrastate.

PARA.TAB: I contacted the Marine Board of Victoria and it is still having discussions with the Disability Advisory Council of Australia. I also spoke to the minister's office which has asked the Department of Transport to investigate what steps can be taken to guarantee access. This ship has no specific facilities for disabled travellers. A disabled person has the option of staying in his or her vehicle or sitting next to the vehicle in the wheelchair travelling as cargo. Although it is a multistorey vessel, there is no lift so that these people may use the same viewing, eating and toilet facilities offered to able-bodied travellers.

There is a clear case of discrimination, as disabled people are not offered a concession rate for travelling. Therefore, disabled people are forced to travel steerage class as cargo but pay the same rate as able-bodied travellers who are able to enjoy and use the full facilities of this vessel. The company does acknowledge, however, that there are toilet facilities for the disabled at each of the three ports—not much help when one is aboard this ship at sea!

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to applaud yet another significant milestone for Central Queensland and for Gladstone, which is rapidly becoming the new age industrial capital of Australia. On 8 March I attended the official opening of Queensland Cement Ltd's $33 million expansion at Fishermans Landing just north of Gladstone in my electorate of Hinkler. QCL, which is owned by the Swiss based Holderbank Group, is Queensland's largest manufacturer and distributor of cement and is one of Australia's major marketers of cement products.

PARA.TAB: The expansion at Fishermans Landing involves the addition of state-of-the-art cement milling, storage, bagging and palletising facilities. The new installations complement the established limestone mine at nearby Mount Larcom, also in my electorate, with its unique slurry transport system and existing clinker production plant at the Fishermans Landing site.

For those not familiar with cement processing, I will give a quick sketch of what is involved. The first stage of cement manufacture is the production of clinker. The main raw materials in clinker are limestone, silica, iron oxide and alumina. These materials are obtained from QCL's East End mine near Mount Larcom and from sandmining leases near Gladstone. The raw materials are crushed and mixed with water to form a slurry and pumped at the rate of 250 tonnes per hour, 24 kilometres via an underground pipeline to Fishermans Landing. At Fishermans Landing the slurry is dried and then fired in a special kiln to form clinker.

To complete the process, the clinker is combined with special amounts of gypsum and limestone and fed into a ball mill that grinds it into a very fine, light grey powder which we commonly know as cement. The cement is conveyed to a 20,000-tonne silo and is ready for dispatch either in bulk or bag form for distribution to Central and North Queensland or for export. The expanded facility has meant that QCL Gladstone can produce and dispatch approximately 600,000 tonnes of cement a year, or approximately 10 per cent of Australia's current consumption. The new additions ensure that QCL Gladstone is an internationally cost competitive cement manufacturing plant, giving the company a competitive edge in marketing cement in Australia, Oceania and South-East Asia.

I turn briefly to the human face of the company. QCL Gladstone employs around 100 skilled and dedicated people. Recent workplace changes have resulted in the adoption of many innovative work practices, ensuring an effective workplace. The company also has its own environmental policy which provides for the efficient use of natural resources, minimising the creation of wastes and, where possible, the recycling of those wastes.

In summary, I see QCL Gladstone as significant for three reasons: firstly, it sources nearly all its raw materials locally; secondly, it is a classic example of value adding, with the company now upgrading its operations to produce both clinker and cement; and, thirdly, the QCL facility at Gladstone is a prime example of regional development at its best. Would to heaven there were more QCL type initiatives in today's lacklustre white paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—It is bad; is it not? QCL's establishment of a clinker plant back in the early 1980s saw the company contribute $12 million to the infrastructure of Gladstone, including the first bridge across the Calliope River in the near-Gladstone area. At the northern end of Gladstone Harbour, where it established Fishermans Landing wharf, it has improved the harbour access and has pioneered the Yarwun industrial estate just north of the city, which is now home to several major chemical plants, including ICI and Minproc.

PARA.TAB: In other words, QCL acted as a catalyst for further development in the region as well as literally cementing—excuse the pun—Gladstone's reputation as an industrial centre. I regret I was not able to raise this matter during our sittings in March, but belatedly I wish to congratulate the company, its executives, its staff and the wider Gladstone community, for what really is a landmark in regional development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to inform the House tonight of a recent visit to my electorate by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), and a visit to a local company which is an example of how successful some of the government programs have been in relation to encouraging exports. Champion Compressors Ltd is a small company established in 1970, specialising in the manufacture of industrial electric screw compressors. The company has a turnover of approximately $20 million per annum.

PARA.TAB: We were met at the factory by Mr Gerry Mussen, the Managing Director; Mr Wayne St Baker; and also a representative of the export access program. The company now exports some 25 per cent of its products, and the company's turnover has increased by approximately $5 million from $15 million to $20 million. A lot of that has had to do with the export access program. An article in a local newspaper states:

Champion's marketing and export director Mr Wayne St. Baker said the company's success had already paved the way for extra jobs and more could follow depending on the movement of the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: The article further states:

PARA.TAB: Mr St. Baker, told `The Journal' his company "got its foot in the door" at the 1993 Beijing International Fair where it secured four orders for product and received 15 inquiries from potential distributors.
"It is almost impossible for a small company to make it in the export market because you just don't have the capital," he said.
"Without the program we would never have had a chance and without adequate research and expertise there's always the question of `where do we go'—we may have tried a dozen markets without a strike.
"Frankly, we would never have considered China as a market and now we're well down the track in developing very positive business throughout the Asian Pacific region.
"Already we've had to increase our staff to 125 people, an increase of 15 per cent, and as business comes in, more local jobs will be created."

SPEECH.PARA: This program, export access, is something that we then advertised through the local papers and already we have had in the last two weeks four inquiries from local businesses which we passed on to the program to ensure that they were able to access this assistance.

PARA.TAB: Professional help is readily available for small and medium size firms seeking to enter international markets. Although many small and medium size enterprises, SMEs, have realised that they had to be internationally focused if they wanted to be around in the 21st century, access to export assistance was often difficult to find.

When export access started two years ago, it created a lot of interest with SMEs as they recognised that much of the assistance which they were seeking would be provided by the program. Export access has also been seen to be a fast track into export markets for many businesses as well as being a well structured program for firms which are about to enter international markets for the first time. Funded and administered by the Commonwealth government, export access is delivered by the private sector and participants do not pay any fees or charges.

A team of project managers is located throughout Australia in leading industry associations providing intensive hands-on assistance to help SMEs develop new business in selected overseas markets. However, applicants are not required to be members of an industry association to participate in export access.

Export access is not a grant scheme. The program offers a comprehensive package of training and practical assistance to SMEs looking to develop offshore activities. Participating firms appreciate the program's simplicity, flexibility and having their business appointment schedules arranged for them by the project managers. These business appointments are set up through a strong international network of private sector industry associations and other appropriate programs and networks.

Export access is also unique in its concept as all applicants receive a visit from a project manager to evaluate their potential and suitability for the program. It is a government funded program which goes out to the potential clients. Strong bonds are often formed between the project managers and their clients through the hands-on assistance provided by the account manager concept.

A fundamental aim of export access is to prepare and train smaller firms to survive and prosper in the international marketplace. Launched in October 1991 as a pilot program to handle 250 firms over three years, export access has received significant funding boosts, initially after its first 12 months in the One Nation statement in 1992, and more recently with a further commitment of $8 million in the 1993-94 Commonwealth budget.

The $20 million funding allocated to export access will enable 1,400 SMEs to be processed by the end of 1995. The funding supports the operations of 25 project managers located in major industry associations throughout Australia and overseas Australian business offices in St Louis, Osaka and Amsterdam. Four hundred and eighty-five firms have been accepted into the program as at 11 March 1994 and approvals are proceeding at a rate of approximately 50 to 60 a month.

Export access has already gained an enviable performance record from the 485 clients who have entered the program. Over 170 firms have now finished the export access program and are completing formal exit questionnaires and evaluation surveys. The first 107 surveyed have shown spectacular results, with 84 per cent of the companies successfully arranging long-term business relationships.

Whilst lead times for doing export business can be quite protracted, the 100 firms surveyed have already achieved sales of $7.6 million, a figure which they expect to reach $78 million in the next three years. These firms have demonstrated a commitment to export by appointing new business arrangements through the export access program. It is a great success and it will continue from there. I thank the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) for his assistance during tonight's debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about superannuation and its limited benefits for casual or itinerant workers. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) I trust will not assist me as well.

PARA.TAB: Mr Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of my colleagues have noted this before. However, I would like to highlight the absurdity again. Simply put, superannuation for many casual employees is a farce. On 17 August 1993 the former Treasurer acknowledged the problem which superannuation poses for casual employees. Mr Dawkins noted then that relatively small amounts of money which had to be contributed on behalf of many casual and itinerant employees could be eroded by the fees and charges applied by their superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: This concern was echoed by Susan Ryan, the executive director of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia—she is well known to this place, particularly to the Senate—on 21 April 1994 in an article in the Australian Financial Review. Ms Ryan said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are genuine shortcomings in the (superannuation) scheme, particularly as it applies to low-income and casual workers or people not in the paid workforce.

Our superannuation scheme is geared towards a person who works continuously for many years. Thus, it discriminates against people who are forced to work on a casual basis. It discriminates against many women whose working pattern is often interrupted by childbirth and some years in the home looking after children. It discriminates against rural and itinerant workers, who are forced by the nature of their work to move around the country and to work as the weather permits. It also discriminates against people who only pick up work from time to time, who form a growing group in today's economic climate.

PARA.TAB: I had some experience of the problem of superannuation for casual employees after recently employing a person for only a few weeks. Because the employee earned more than $1,000, I was required by law to pay three per cent of her income towards superannuation. As we all know, this money has to be paid into a complying superannuation fund.

Unfortunately, the employee did not already have a superannuation fund. She had to open one specifically for the superannuation. By the time she reaches her retirement years—in fact, well before—the superannuation she earned while working in my office will have been eaten up in administration fees.

This is not news to the many groups which have lobbied the government to amend our superannuation rules. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is examining the problem of casual employee superannuation being consumed by administration fees, taxes and other charges. My colleague Senator Watson from Tasmania is the chairman of that committee. He understands the chaos of superannuation as it relates to casual employees. Committee members have already received many representations from casual workers, who are concerned about their superannuation being consumed by fees and charges.

I note that the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations has made a submission to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to combat the problem. The federation proposes to establish a central fund to collect superannuation contributions for part-time and casual workers. This central fund would apply to people who have a number of part-time or casual jobs throughout the years and would enable them to pay their superannuation into one account, giving them a greater chance of accumulating something for their retirement.

The number of part-time and casual employees is growing each year as the structure of our work force changes to combat our high unemployment. Clearly, something needs to be done about the superannuation scheme as it applies to this growing section of the work force. Superannuation is meant to be a reward and a security net for all workers. At the moment, it is simply absurd.
In conclusion, the New South Wales Farmers Federation said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the superannuation system at the moment looks as though it was designed by a committee of misdirected people locked away in an air conditioned room in Canberra and totally detached from the real world. It was!

Until our superannuation system is changed, many workers, particularly women and rural workers, will be at risk of receiving absolutely no benefit from the superannuation scheme which purports to help them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, I have just recently come back from a delegation assigned from this House which went to Bougainville. I do not wish to speak on the contents of the report, which will be placed before this House in four or five weeks. However, I wish to make some comments about some observations that were made there.

PARA.TAB: The delegation was led by Senator Loosley. The deputy chairman was the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It was also attended by Senator Vicki Bourne, Senator Paul Calvert and me. The time of the delegation was just prior to Anzac Day. We felt it would be very good for us, particularly as we were going there, to visit the war graves in Rabaul.

One of the most moving things that have happened to me for a long time was going through and looking at a place where Australian soldiers from the First World War and the Second World War are lying at rest. To see the graves that contain messages from the families of those people who had fallen was indeed a remarkably moving thing.

One of the recurring themes was the ages on those Second World War graves. Most, many, a lot—whatever word or percentage we would like to put on it—listed people who were 18 or 19 years of age. I think I saw three or four graves of people who were older than I am today. One particular grave had an inscription on it which referred to a wife left and a small boy who would now probably be in his 60s.

It seems to me, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I could not come back into this House without making some comment on those people who have been before us and whether war is right or wrong. I think you know that I am a peace activist; I am not a pacifist.

There are moves by others in this House to have Anzac Day recognised as a national day of remembrance. My family always chose 11 November as that day. I have no objection; in fact, I would support greatly Anzac Day being marked in a permanent way on our calendar. But I think one of the things that motivate me in this House, and will always motivate me in this House, in terms of what I do and in terms of conflicts abroad and at home, will be what I saw in Rabaul.

I believe that what the others were all significantly touched by was that, irrespective of the cause of war, the results are pulled out of the community itself. I would like to state in this House that whatever I can do to make sure that this country has a peaceful existence in the future, I will do. I honour those people who have passed before us and who have given their all, and I hope that all parts of this nation will forever honour the service that they have given, the sacrifice that they have made, and the fact that they cannot be back with us in this country.

The fact that maybe some of their people will never see the graves where they lie scattered all around the world is a tragedy. But probably the biggest tragedy is the holes that they have left. I assure honourable members that there are still many people, many women and many families, who still have holes in them from our previous engagements. I was against the Vietnam War, but I am all for those people who participated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In tonight's adjournment debate I want to raise an issue which is significant to the Greek Cypriot community within Australia. I have had considerable contact with constituents of mine with Grecian heritage over the past few weeks, but it is not my intention to canvass the Macedonian issue tonight. I want to use this time to draw the attention of the House to another issue which is important to Australians of Greek Cypriot heritage. It concerns the fact that Australian citizens of Greek Cypriot heritage are being denied their property ownership rights in the Turkish occupied part of Cyprus. Just over a third of the country of Cyprus has been occupied by the Turks since they invaded in July and August 1974, and it is estimated that some 200,000 people have been displaced as a result of the invasion.

PARA.TAB: Many of those people who were displaced following the Turkish invasion have migrated to Australia, and the latest census figures confirm that there are something like 22,000 people in Australia who were born in Cyprus. It must be remembered that many Cypriots migrated to Australia prior to the Turkish invasion. One estimate I have seen is that 10,000 Cypriots own land in the Turkish occupied part of Cyprus. These people are Australian citizens who have maintained land ownership since migrating from Cyprus or have inherited the property from their parents or grandparents. It is not unreasonable to estimate the value of this property at something between $300 million and $400 million.

My cause and problem tonight is that I am concerned that Australian citizens who are owners of this property are being denied their fundamental right of ownership by the Turkish government. This is clearly an unpalatable situation and one which must be rectified. I will finish my comments on a further occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 17 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: Will the Government impose a tariff on imported billiard table cloth; if so, (a) at what level, (b) is cloth of this particular quality manufactured in Australia; if not, why is the tariff being imposed and (c) is the imposition of the tariff in line with the recent conclusion of the GATT negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) The Government does not intend to amend the tariff rate of customs duty on imported billiard table cloth. The present customs duty rate is General 29%; Developing Countries 24%; Hong Kong, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan Province 27%; New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Forum Island Countries Free.

(b)(i) Cloth which can be used on billiard tables is manufactured in Australia by Macquarie Textiles Pty Ltd. Macquarie Textiles do not manufacture high quality cloth, known as "competition quality" cloth, and a Tariff Concession (providing duty free importation) for such cloth was granted in 1991 but revoked on request from Macquarie on 21 September 1993. The concession legislation operating at that time required that the Comptroller-General should not allow a concession if "goods serving similar functions" were produced or were capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business. Locally produced goods did not need to be identical to the imported goods, it was sufficient under the system existing at that time that goods served a similar function.

That revocation decision would have meant that competition billiard cloth was subject to duty but the Government introduced a new concession system on 1 November 1992 with broader requirements than the old system.

An application under the new system was lodged on 1 October 1993 and the narrower wording of this concession was accepted by Macquarie Textiles. The net effect of this action is that a concession for "competition quality" cloth has been granted, effective from 1 October 1993.

(ii) No tariff rate has been "imposed" on billiard cloth. Billiard cloth is classified to a heading which has the rates previously mentioned applied to it. A tariff concession now exists which allows duty free importation of "competition quality" billiard cloth. This quality billiard cloth has received the benefit of duty free admission since 1991.
(c) As mentioned, the tariff rate for textile products of this nature has been in place for some time and is not effected by the recent GATT negotiations.

The current concession allows duty free importation of "competition quality" cloth and that concession will remain in place unless an Australian local manufacturer should commence manufacture of substitutable goods.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister's Department employ proper accounting procedures to record departmental purchases; if so,

(a) what system is used, (b) are all purchases recorded and (c) to what extent are records accessible by auditors, departmental officers and other officials; if not, (i) why not and (ii) what procedures are used for appropriate financial management and reconciliation of purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes, the Department utilises various accounting systems to ensure proper accounting procedures are in place to record Departmental purchases.

(a) The Department uses four separate accounting systems across the areas of the Department indicated below. The systems are all proprietary accounting systems with a full range of accounting functions.

Core Department: (FISCLE) which stands for Financial Information System Clerical Legal Executive and is a product of Management Solutions Pty Ltd. It has operated in the Department for 5 years. AUSTRAC: Open System Accounting (OSAS). This is a product of INTECH Software Pty Ltd, NSW and has been operating in AUSTRAC since 1 July 1992.
AUSCRIPT: Rainbow Accounting System. The Rainbow system is owned by PARKLANE Computing Pty Ltd, Victoria. This system has been operating since 1 July 1991.
Australian Protective Service: NOMAD FINANCIALS. This system is owned by the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian Protective Service has been using this system since 1 July 1990.

(b) All purchases are recorded on the various Departmental accounting systems. These systems all operate integrated purchasing modules. These modules incorporate electronic controls to ensure that only authorised officers are able to approve and process purchases.

With the exception of the Rainbow Accounting System, certificates under Finance Regulation 45A(3)(b)(ii) have been issued. These certificates provide an assurance that the system controls and procedures can be relied upon by the users. This certificate is issued after extensive validation of the processes has been completed. A certificate for the Rainbow Accounting System is currently being sought.

It should also be noted that all creditor details from those systems as at 30 June each year are the subject of scrutiny by the Australian National Audit Office as part of their Departmental Financial Statements Audit.
(c) Access to the various accounting systems under my portfolio are available to auditors, Departmental officers and other officials on a need-to-know basis as required.

(1) No. An evaluation of the Commission's Law and Justice component is currently being conducted by the Office of Evaluation and Audit as part of the ongoing program of evaluations of Commission programs which the Office is required regularly to conduct.
