(2) All recipients of grant funding from ATSIC, pursuant to section 18 of the ATSIC Act are already subject to annual and recurrent evaluation and assessment of their financial management and use of grant moneys as a condition of continued funding under provisions set out in ATSIC's Funding Procedures Manual.

(3) The results of evaluations and audits conducted by the Office of Evaluation and Audit either at my request or at that of the Commission under paragraph 76(1)(f) are conveyed, by that Office, to me and to the Commission. Decisions on whether the results of the evaluations and audits will be placed on public record will rest with me or with the Commission as appropriate.

(4) Monies granted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporations by ATSIC have their source in money appropriated from time to time by Parliament for ATSIC. In that sense the money is public money but once it is given to an Aboriginal Corporation it is, according to legal advice, deemed at law to be the property of the grantee corporation.

Although grants to Aboriginal Corporations are subject to grant conditions the corporations have the same rights, privileges and discretions in the use of those funds as any private corporation, provided the funds are not used in a manner inconsistent with the general purposes of that grant.
The Aboriginal Legal Services are incorporated either under State legislation, or are incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976 (Cth).

Both regimes require their registered corporations to lodge annual audited reports and detailed income and expenditure statements within a reasonable time after the completion of each financial year. Both enactments provide for public access to such documents upon payment of a statutory fee.

In addition ATSIC would have documents dealing with individual grants, acquittals and other matters affecting funded bodies. Provision of documents by Commonwealth agencies is subject to the Freedom of Information Act, 1982 (Cth) and to its procedural provisions and its heads of exemption in appropriate matters.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: High School Students: Tax File Numbers

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that schools are being paid by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for each high school student that the school encourages to apply for a tax file number; if so, (a) what sum are the schools being paid for each student, (b) why is the ATO using this method to distribute tax file numbers and (c) what sum has been paid to each school involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. Schools are not being paid to encourage students to apply for a Tax File Number.

(a) Schools will be paid $3 per application processed in recognition of administrative costs incurred by schools which choose to participate in the Tax File Number School Service which the Australian Taxation Office has established.

(b) This Service will enable Year 10 students to apply for a Tax File Number in a cheaper and more convenient way than the usual application process, if they wish to do so. The ATO estimates that 80% of Year 10 students have a Tax File Number before the end of the school year.

The Tax File Number School Service is part of a new Student Education Program which is being established to assist teachers of secondary and tertiary level students to educate their students about tax and associated issues.

The introduction of the Tax File Number School Service will mean that students do not have to obtain the usual proof of identity documents and forward them to the Tax Office. Instead, schools which choose to be involved in the Service will certify the identity of students applying for Tax File Numbers. The Service will make it easier for young people, particularly those in remote areas without ready access to a Tax Office, to apply for a Tax File Number.
The Service is entirely voluntary and this will be emphasised to schools, teachers, students and parents.

(c) The Service was piloted in 68 Tasmanian secondary schools and then trialed in 23 Victorian schools. Payments to Tasmanian schools totalled $17,168. In Victoria, payments to schools totalled $2,328. No other payments have been made to date as the service has only just been launched on a national basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 February 1994.

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that veterans holding red cards must have served overseas in a war zone and white and yellow card holders may have been injured while on leave at home.
(2) Are red card holders entitled to fewer pharmaceutical benefits than yellow or white card holders; if so, why.

(3) Is a yellow card holder entitled to specific pharmaceuticals for an affliction, such as bowel cancer, which was related neither to war service nor to the recipient's service in Australia; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government issues Personal Treatment Entitlement Cards (yellow cards) to:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian World War I veterans, mariners and nurses;

PARA.TAB: Australian female veterans of World War II who have qualifying service;
Australian veterans who receive a Disability Pension at 100% of the general rate or higher;
Australian ex-Prisoners Of War;
Australian age or invalidity Service Pensioners who receive a Disability Pension at 50% of the general rate or higher;

Australian age or invalidity Service pensioners who meet the treatment benefits eligibility test (under the income and assets test) and who also have either a war or service related injury or disease, malignant neoplasia or pulmonary tuberculosis;
Australian veterans who were in receipt of a Disability Pension for pulmonary tuberculosis before 2 November 1978;
Australian veterans who receive an additional amount of pension for certain war or service related injuries, ie. amputation of a limb and/or blindness;
Australian age or invalidity Service Pensioners who are permanently blind in both eyes; and
Australian war widow(er)s if s/he is also a veteran and suffers from a war or service related injury or disease, malignant neoplasia or pulmonary tuberculosis

Specific Treatment Entitlement Cards (white cards) are issued to veterans who have a war or service related injury or disease, malignant neoplasia or pulmonary tuberculosis, for treatment of their accepted disabilities only.
Service Pensioner Benefits Cards (red cards) are issued to Australian veterans who:
have no accepted war or service related disabilities, and
have qualifying service, and
meet the treatment benefits eligibility test under the income and assets test for service pension.
It is possible that some white and yellow card holders may have disabilities accepted which were not incurred whilst serving overseas.

(2) Red cards holders are entitled to pharmaceuticals under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), from which some 1,200 drug items are available. Yellow card holders are entitled to pharmaceuticals under the PBS plus those listed on the Schedule of Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits. White card holders are entitled to pharmaceuticals under the PBS plus those listed on the Schedule of Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits but only for the treatment of their accepted disabilities.

The Repatriation Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits consists of some 350 supplementary items selected by the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Reference Committee to meet the special drug treatment needs of veterans with war or service related disabilities.
(3) Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, PTEC (yellow) card holders are entitled to treatment of all injuries or diseases, whether war related or not.

Australian veterans who have malignant neoplasia (cancer) are eligible to receive treatment for this condition, including pharmaceuticals, regardless of whether this condition is war related or not and regardless of which treatment entitlement card they hold. Red card holders who have cancer are issued with a PTEC card.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the agreed formula developed by his Department, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Finance for the net unit cost of assistance under his Department's labour market programs which are referred to in Table 4.2 at page 102 of the Committee on Employment Opportunities' discussion paper entitled Restoring Full Employment.
(2) What are the relevant (a) costs, (b) savings and (c) other statistics used to arrive at the net unit cost of assistance for each specific labour market program in 1992-93.

(3) Will he provide details of all work carried out by Dr Bruce Chapman for his Department since 1 January 1993, including (a) the subjects examined, (b) the findings and recommendations in each case and (c) the cost of each project including a breakdown of expenses such as travel and travel allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The net unit cost of each labour market program in Table 4.2 of the Committee's Report is arrived at by calculating the average gross unit cost of assistance incurred by the Department of Employment Education and Training (DEET). This gross cost covers the cost of providing training courses, wage subsidies etc. as well as income support where the latter is funded from a DEET appropriation. The net unit cost is derived by deducting from the gross unit cost the savings in Jobsearch and Newstart Allowances (JSA/NSA) accruing to the Department of Social Security (DSS) as a result of job seekers transferring from DSS benefits to a labour market program which provides DEET funded income support.
The complex formula developed by DEET, DSS and the Department of Finance to calculate the net costs (or program costs less JSA/NSA offsets) includes the following parameters:
duration of program assistance;
proportion of participants on JSA/NSA;
average JSA/NSA rates;
probability that participants would move off JSA/NSA without assistance;
possibility that participants may displace other jobseekers (ie net additional jobs created); and
possibility that displaced jobseekers would become JSA recipients.
The parameters used in these formulae are program specific and are derived from administrative, labour market and evaluation data. The parameters are updated each year.
(2) The following table sets out details of gross unit costs, savings in DSS Allowances and net unit costs for the labour market programs in Table 4.2 of the Committee's Report.

ANSWER.PARA: Program Gross Unit Cost Savings to DSS Net Unit Cost

PARA.TAB: (3) (a) Dr Chapman was asked to prepare a discussion paper on long term unemployment, its causes, consequences and some possible policy responses to the issue.
(b) The findings were published in a report in December 1993 (copies of which are available from the Department). A copy has been sent to the office of the honourable member.
(c) The cost of this consultancy was $50,000. A further $6,000 was provided for elements of research which Dr Chapman subcontracted to other individuals.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force: Right to Dismiss Members

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 22 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did the Minister's predecessor propose in the answer to Senate question No. 1477 (Senate Hansard, 9 May 1990, page 175) that a prerogative right to dismiss at pleasure from the Australian Defence Force co-exists with the statutory right to dismiss only for cause; if so, upon what legal authority did the Minister rely for that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Officers of the Australian Defence Force hold appointments at the pleasure of the Governor-General under section 16(1) of the Defence Act 1910 in the case of Army officers, section 12(1) of the Naval Defence Act 1910 for Navy officers and Air Force Regulation 72(1) for Air Force officers. The holding of an appointment at pleasure also provides the power to the appointing authority to terminate that appointment. In all cases, the Acts and Regulations stipulate that an officer will not be dismissed without written notification of the reasons and without being given the opportunity to show cause why such action should not be taken.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: UN Convention on the Law of the Sea

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea enter into force on 16 November 1994.
(2) Which states have (a) signed and (b) ratified the Convention and on what dates.
(3) Further to the answer to question No. 1706 (Hansard, 18 August 1992, page 108), what progress has been made in persuading the USA to support the Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Law of the Sea Convention provides for entry into force one year after the sixtieth ratification. On 16 November 1993 Guyana deposited its instrument of ratification of the Convention, bringing the number of ratifications to sixty. The legal effect of the ratification by Guyana will be to bring the Convention into force for the sixty ratifying nations on 16 November 1994.
(2) I attach a list of states which have signed and ratified the Convention including the date of signature or ratification.

(3) As confirmed in the answer to question No. 1706 (Hansard, 18 August 1992, page 108), Australia has been in direct and regular contact with the United States Government on law of the sea issues since 1981 when the House of Representatives conveyed its unanimous resolution on the Law of the Sea Convention to the United States Government. This contact has continued since that question was asked.

Australia, the United States and other countries have continued their participation in informal consultations taking place under the auspices of the UN Secretary-General to explore the concerns which industrialised countries, particularly the United States, have with the deep seabed mining provisions embodied in Part XI of the Law of the Sea Convention.

During the course of these consultations it has been acknowledged by all participants, whether from industrialised countries or developing countries, that global political and economic changes since the adoption of the Law of the Sea Convention in 1982 had raised questions as to the appropriateness of certain aspects of Part XI. The major advance at the most recent consultations has been the development of a text which was put forward by key delegations including Australia, the United States and other developing and industrialised countries. The text contains a draft agreement which identifies all major questions at issue between industrialised and developing states and which would institute a number of significant revisions to Part XI to bring it into line with current needs. The text has attracted widespread support.

At the most recent consultations, held from 4-8 April 1994, agreement was reached on the two major outstanding issues relating to Part XI, with all participating delegations generally accepting the resulting text. Negotiations were not, however, formally concluded because of a perception among developing countries that, as a matter of principle, those States which have not participated in the consultations should have the opportunity to study the text and express their views. The final round of the informal consultations will take place from 31 May-4 June 1994, with the first day set aside for

ANSWER.PARA: country statements on the text and the remaining three days for drafting changes and for the harmonising of language texts. Significantly, all participating delegations have agreed that the agreement will be adopted by a resolution at a resumed session of the General Assembly during the week of 25-29 July 1994.

PARA.TAB: Although some uncertainties remain, the Australian Government considers that an agreement on implementing Part XI of the Law of the Sea Convention is now within reach. This would enable Australia, as well as the United States and other industrialised countries, to give serious consideration to ratifying the Law of the Sea Convention, hence ensuring that it becomes the universally accepted law on the subject. Interdepartmental discussions have already begun the process of considering Australian ratification of the Law of the Sea Convention.

ANSWER.PARA: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE LAW OF THE SEA (LOSC)

PARA.TAB: (1) A contract to supply the Department of Defence (Army) with quantity 72 Hatz diesel engines and quantity 72 Darley HE500 pumpsets was awarded to Hatz on 22 December 1993.
(2)(a) Hatz Australia solely imports diesel engines.

(b) Hatz has a complete dynamometer testing facility to test engines and pumps to Australian Standards and has offered a two year warranty on the engine and pump, which it can meet, while providing after sales service.
(3) The tender documents specified that only the Darley HE500 pumpset could be supplied to meet the contract.
(4)(a) The Darley HE500 pumpset has been in-service with the Royal Australian Navy for four years. In addition it is understood the Darley pumpset has been in service with:
the Country Fire Service of South Australia for the past 13 years;
ACT Fire & Rescue Service for the past nine years; and
various industrial fire services, including oil rigs and mining companies in Australia.

(b) The Department of Defence is unaware of any Australian users of this pumpset who have had, or may have had any adverse technical, economic, performance, reliability or servicing reason for changing their source of pump.

(5) Department of Defence Army is unable to comment on US Department of Defense use. However, the pump has been in service with the Royal Australian Navy for the past four years and has proven to be a suitable and reliable equipment.

(6)(a) and (b) Prior to commencement of the tendering process an equipment survey was conducted by the Chief of the Army Fire Service of both `off-the-shelf' pumpsets from Australian manufacturers and the in-service pumpsets used by the Royal Australian Navy and Australian state fire services. The survey concluded that:
there was no acceptable Australian-manufactured pump capable of performing to the Army's specification; and
the Darley HE500 pump was the accepted in-service item which had been performing satisfactorily with the Royal Australian Navy and which met the Army's specification.

In addition, an independent Fire Risk Consultant's report commissioned by the Director General of Accommodation and Works-Army in 1992 and subsequently endorsed by the Chief of the General Staff Advisory Committee in 1993 recommended the upgrade of the Army's firefighting equipment including all the pumpsets. PARA.TAB: (7)(a) The restricted tender process is a procurement option available to the Army. It was exercised in this case because of the urgent safety nature of this equipment upgrade in combination with those equipment performance capabilities detailed in the specification.
(b) There have been no other known recent restricted tenders by Army regarding fire control equipment.
(8) The contract was awarded as a result of restricted tender action.
(9)(a) The following criteria were taken into account when considering the replacement of the pumpset:
The intended use of the pumpset and its specific performance requirements.
The urgent safety nature of the upgrade.
All known Australian manufactured pumpsets.
All pumpsets currently in service with the various Australian state fire services.
Pumpsets already in service in the Department of Defence.
Other pumpsets commercially available within Australia.

(b) The urgent safety nature of this equipment upgrade in combination with those equipment performance capabilities detailed in the specification and the limited availability of suitable equipment justified restricted tender action.
(10) No Logistic Command—Army personnel involved in this project provided oral assurances to any potential suppliers that public tenders would be called for the contract in early 1994.
(11) No Australian pump manufacturer contacted any Logistic Command—Army personnel involved in this project to discuss the contract requirements prior to the contract being awarded to Hatz.
(12) The Army complies with the ideal of procuring through Australian industry where feasible and cost effective. However, in this case there was no suitable Australian-made pumpset.
(13) Australian-made pumpsets will be considered in any future procurement of firefighting equipment provided the equipment meets Defence specifications.
